content:
Posted: February 24
												Personal Rating: 8.5 of 10Easily, this is one of (if not) the best superhero title I've played. The performance, acting, setting, performance, stability, sound, graphics, level design and control. The game is set within Arkham Asylum and there are several facilities that you can traverse between them Batman style like gliding between higher ground or simply run around. The map design is really good as in each place tries to be different and provide different strategy to tackle your goal. You have most of the common Batman tools at your disposal and there are really well implemented.Settings are immersive, its like you can feel you are the Dark Knight when playing; you feel righteous. Don't expect too much of heavy plot like any Batman animation you see but the story and settings really keep it inretesting.Another things that I really liked is how the story unveils more and more location and you don't really feel like you have been in the same place before although the game requires you to travel to the same facilities several times.Boss fight are satisfying as different fight require different strategy and not all button mashing action only. Content wise I think it is just right and they creators does not overkill the game by dragging the story and adding unnecessary features in the game simply to prolong the gameplay time.I have zero performance issue and I do consider the graphics to be really good considering the hardware requirement.The voice actors really outdone themselves as you can feel they really immerse themself to act, not just simply reading the script.Side quests such as collectibles will take sometime to tackle them especially the riddles. It is not really that hard but finding them can be challenging. One of the best feature in this game is how the environment changes with the story. It gives you a new perspective in the game and changes the mood entirely.

number of helpful: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												There have been many superhero games throughout the years.  Most of them have been sidescrolling "beat 'em ups" in the  vein of the Final Fight series.  Others were horrible adaptations like the Superman game for the N64.  Arkham Asylum has been, with few minor exceptions, one of the most on-point adaptations of a superhero property into a game that I have ever played.  First, the format, a 3-D "metroidvania/Legend of Zelda" type deal where new tools open new areas and items to get, plays nicely into the feel of the game.   That same format also helps with the "lone hero" feeling that is in many ways the essence of Batman.  You feel like yes, you are alone, but you aren't out of your depth.  Also, the classic animated series voices help set the tone of the game; dark with just a bit of humor here and there.The game world is lush and well rendered, created in that gritty style also befiting a game about The Bat.  Ruined sewers, secret tunnels, and crawling through airways and up walls all give this sense of being secretive, careful, and thought out.  The world you have been given to play in is tailor made to adhere to the common action/stealth tropes that exist in other Batman works.The combat and movement can be . . . halting at times.  In particular the "hold button to run" command, something that I thought I had seen the end of when analog sticks came to prominent use, feels forced and unintuitive.  When the combat flows, slighlty pauses on a big hit, and Batman is leaping to and fro kicking, punching and generally kicking♥♥♥♥♥ it looks good, and it feels good to be doing it, but there aren't any ways to "do" the one move you like, really.  And the combat system is at its best when you have maxed out all your available attack options.The fightable enemies are simple and never waver from the basic human stock of "Joker goon fight"; they are either unarmed, armed with a melee weapon, armed with a firearm, a stun baton, or they are giant mutant freaks.  This includes the "boss fights", making the gameplay and world far more engaging than the actual combat.  That said, most of the combat is short and simple.  I think the longest normal skirmish took maybe a minute.  And the best parts of combat aren't specifically the combat so much as the setpieces where you have high perches to disappear to.  You can swoop down, take out a goon, and then grapple up into the shadows, listening and watching as the other goons start to freak out as you take them down one by one.And finally the story, which at least matches the quality of the old animated Batman series movies for plots.  Joker has a crazy plan, and Batman has to stop him.  The winding way Bruce has to do this is what makes up the bulk of the game.  Some of the story points feel contrived, but overall, the story flows from point to point in a logical way.  What helps in this is that Batman himself often tells the player (and Oracle over his headset) the next step.  And when Batman tells you something in this game, a combination of the voicework and the writing just seems to make the next plotpoint make sense.With solid voicework, a lonely, beautifully crafted world, and a combat and stealth system that is only sometimes marred by its own trappings, this is a solid, wonderfully made title that anyone who counts themselves as a superhero fan in general or a Batman fan in particular should own.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2016
												Retrospectively, Batman: Arkham Asylum is the high point of Rocksteady Studios' Batman trilogy. It's a tight, focused experience with a deft tonal awareness, shaping a dark, grotesque setting for a plot that hits all the 'edgy Batman story' notes, relying on spectacle - supplemented by some pretty top-tier action and stealth gameplay - to see it through.Similarly to the way Asylum itself is the pinnacle of the Arkham series, Arkham Asylum's third-person melee combat is quite easily the best to be found within this genre. It's fluid and functional, with solid ability variation supplemented by superb animation and sound design shaping an experience that is - at its core - quintessential to the cheesy, ridiculously one-sided combat of superhero comic books. Despite the borderline omnipotence of Batman's combat ability, the fights never became overly unchallenging, as the game introduces new enemy abilities frequently enough to keep you juggling knives, stun batons and giant experimental abominations. Regarding stealth gameplay, Arkham Asylum utilises mechanics that necessitate a predatory approach - if you're spotted by armed enemies, you'll be dead in seconds. Creeping around in the shadows and picking off burly, shirtless men until they start to panic is great fun, but it tends to be even more one-sided than the combat. It's almost as though there's too much freedom to just hang out on a rooftop with the x-ray vision constantly turned on until a specific enemy moves far enough away from the group for you to drop down and take him out, and then rinse and repeat. The endless functions of the x-ray vision makes it almost irresponsible not to keep the thing turned on, despite the fact that it replaces pretty much all textures with various shades of dark blue. The somewhat 'Mary Sue' nature of most superheroes is probably the cause of troubles like this - people would complain if Batman didn't have tons of ultra-powerful gadgets like this. Regardless, it doesn't totally ruin the game's balance, it just tends to make a lot of encounters a touch too easy.Arkham Asylum is pretty aesthetically brilliant. Voice performances by long-time Batman and Joker voice actors Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill adds an air of authenticity to the dialogue, as does top-tier animation and some genuinely creepy underground sequences. While the plot is more of the same stuff you'll find in a lot of Batman comics (Arkham Asylum is primarily based on Grant Morrison's 1989 comic Arkham Asylum: A Serious House on Serious Earth), it's still good stuff. Not because of the storyline itself, which is samey and tedious, but because of the amount of work put into the various villainous characters, particularly the Scarecrow, whose subplot features some pretty interesting surprises along the way. It's in the depictions of established characters that the story shines, coming close to the 'definitive versions' that the endless superhero film reboots seem to be going for. Arkham Asylum really ramps it up towards the ending with some fancy setpieces that are actually very enjoyable. In general, the game shines as a rare example of a popular IP being adapted into a video game that actually manages to gel the elements of the Batman​ franchise with what makes video games inherently fun.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												First review i've ever wrote and this game deserves it.Where do I begin...Well, first off, the story. It's pretty freaking cool. You've got some of your favourite villains running amock on Arkham Island. Yay! Plus Luke Skywalker plays the Joker. Secondly, the gameplay. The combat system is so awesome. I played Arkham City before this and i always enjoyed the combat. IT'S SO BRUTAL! Plus you really feel like Batman. The stealth sections are really cool and allow you to feel like Batman even more, taking out neighbours from every angle without them even seeing you, soooo awesome!THE ATTENTION TO DETAIL IS SO PERFECT. I was never much of a screenshotting person, but this game has got me saving over 200 screenshots, some of simply batmans costume and others of me in the middle in a boss fight (judge me, I don't care, jks i probs will).This game does not have you constantly playing combat and stealth sections. Nononono. There are changes in gameplay. The scarecrow sections are so cool, and slightly psychological and creepy. I was never a collectible person, but I've been finding the riddler trophies around the map. Once you finish the game, you will have more gadgets to find lots of them. Plus the riddler puzzles are cool, but they can be hard.I never cared about attention to detail, but this game has got me to see video games in a new light. The story is pretty long and there are challenge modes if you finish the game. I suggest getting the game of the year edition because then you unlock a challenge mode where you just continiously fight thugs. So yeah, I love this game.

While the combat can be simplistic, it is flawless and combined with the stealth, gadgets, detective mode and all the puzzle solving really makes you feel like Batman. It presents an engaging story with quality voice acting (Mark Hamill!) and characters. Sadly, my only dislike about the game is the final boss battle as it was a little bit underwhelming. Last but not least, the atmosphere is great and the dark setting just completely immerses you in Arkham Asylum.It's also a great game for completionists as it gives you multiple things to keep you entertained. I've only played the campaign and found one or another obvious Riddler Trophy and got 66% of completion (finished it in 11,6 hours).A no-brainer for any action and/or Batman fan.➡️️Final Rating: 9/10

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is one of my favourite games of all time. I've played through this many times on PS3, which explains my low playtime as I already know what happens. Do I get bored of doing everything all over again? Nope. An interesting story, the best melee combat system in gaming, a stealth system with high variety, backtracking that dosen't feel boring and tons of lore and easter eggs are just some reasons why this game is amazing. This is the game that began the "Freeflow" combat trend in many recent releases, but none of them have matched up to the original. It's smooth, requires skill and not button mashing, and rewards people who can get into those high hit streaks. The stealth is great too. Multiple ways to take down and lure your enemies with some smart A.I to back it up. It may not seem hard at first, but it does get pretty challenging later on.There are also challenge maps that require you to get a certain amount of points with the freeflow system or perform certain takedowns with the stealth system. Extreme versions of these maps offer an even harder challenge with some unique takedown requisites.However, while the PC port is great, it is missing the Joker Challenge Maps which are exclusive to the PS3 and Mac versions of the game. If you have either of these, pick that version up instead as he is a very fun character to play as.The original freeflow game that began one of the best franchises in gaming still holds up to this day. Play it whether you are a Batman superfan or you have no idea what he is. Overall: 10/10.

												Second only to its successor, this game is the ultimate Batman medium. Forget about those movies, if you want a true Batman comic atmosphere - this is your stop. But you dont really need to be a Batman fan to enjoy in this great game.I've never heard about Rocksteady before this game, so I was a bit sceptic regarding previous Batman games, and also movies. Every fool can twist the famous Dark Knight to his will... And then - a mirracle. THE Holy Grail which we were searching for. Everything in this game - gameplay, story, character and level design can be described with a single word - genius. Absolutelly genius.Game starts with Batman returning Joker where he belongs - with other villains in the Arkham Asylum. But soon he falls into his trap, and the whole island is being under siege, as Batman has to uncover its secrets and mysterious reasons of Joker's (willing) return to the Asylum. Open world gameplay, and various characters to deal with, as more and more sections of the Asylum unlocks with your progress (including gadgets).After epic campaign you can play challenge maps which you unlock by solving Riddler's secrets in the campaign. From beating miscreants and breaking their bones, and doing the same in a bit different manner in predator maps. Its always fun listening thugs panicking progressively as more and more of them ends up knocked out in the shadows, or Joker mocking them for their failures.Either way, all recommendations from me.

content:

 Batman: Arkham Asylum I'm not a big fan of DC Universe, well the whole superhero series but I do enjoy watching the movies or playing the videogames. In this case we'll discuss about Batman: Arkham Asylum, the debut of the videogame series about our favorite bat, done by Rocksteady Studios. This game is in some sort the prototype that shaped the whole action genre in all these years. So this means it is a well done game. The game feels in all it's aspects a truly enjoyable gem, maybe unpolished but it remains indeed a gem.Pros:+ The action doesn't feel too clumsy+ Being Batman feels very authentic+ The design of the city is well handled+ The script isn't what we remember about the game but it surely isn't bad+ Our hero has a wide range of tools to fight the bad guys+ The game in PC is way better than console providing the game with better graphics+ The detective mode is a nice add-on and it is easy to use+ The game lasts approximately 10 hours, which isn't as bad+ In PC you can find this game very cheap+ The audio and the immersion are very polishedMediocre:~ Stealth actions aren't as rewarding as we could think~ The game may be too easy at lower difficulties  Cons:- The combat system seems a rip-off of the Assasin's Creed franchise- The combat combos are too easy you don't feel like you are doing them- If you want to clear the game fast you may be disappointed with the duration of the title Overall score:   9,1/10

content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												With the final chapter of Rocksteady's Batman: Arkham Trilogy out, Batman: Arkham Knight, I thought i should give my thoughts on the Arkham Games that I own on Steam. First Off, Batman: Arkham Asylum. Arkham Asylum is a very fun game with a very interesting story. This game follows Batman, who has just taken Joker to the infamous Arkham Asylum compound. The Joker takes control of the Asylum when he has killed the guards with him. Batman must face iconic Batman villains such as Harley Quinn, Bane, Scarecrow, Riddler, and more. The freeflow combat that everyone loves is in this game, but isnt as fleshed out as I wanted it to be. Many more things needed to be added to make the Arkham Experience the best it could be from the get-go. The predator rooms are very fun and challenging. And of course, The boss battles. Some of the boss battles are't that great like Joker and Bane, but some of them are some of the most creative boss battles out there like Killer Croc and Scarecrow. Overall, Batman: Arkham Asylum was a pleasant suprise in 2009 (a time when superhero games sucked). I very much recommend this game, Batman fan or not.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												There was an animated TV series in the early '90s called Batman: The Animated Series. It had a rather unique visual style that was later on dubbed as "Dark Deco" and was praised for being able to represent Gotham City as it is in the Batman comic books: a dark, Gothic-like place. Visual design was done via paintings and not really CGI and it was truly remarkable; it had a film noir-esque approach, as well. Mark Hamill (the guy who played Luke Skywalker) was the voice-actor for Joker and he did a very good job - Joker's laughter gave viewers the creeps.So, what Rocksteady did back in 2009 was that they took a bunch of actors working on this TV show almost two decades before and they brought them on board. All the main characters are voiced by the same people and the game's visual design is reminiscent of the cartoon. The music, the voice-acting, the sound effects, everything is top-notch in this game.Gameplay-wise Arkham Asylum is stunning: Batman can run, jump, glide, crouch and easily can get atop buildings by using his special gadget called the grapple gun. To be honest, beside the Assassins Creed franchise this is the 2nd one where your character is as fluid as it can get and controlling Batman feels just cool. In addition to this, fighting Joker's thugs seems equally easy and smooth: you go around hitting bad guys and occasionally you are prompted to counter the attack of an enemy. If you do this your so-called flow is not interrupted and you can go ahead hitting more bad guys thereby reaching a higher score which is eventually transformed into experience points. After a while you can level-up and unlock further abilities or upgrades to your gadgets.Gadgets! Oh yes! You have the Batarang and its various versions, you have an explosive gel which can be used to destroy weaker structures / walls and you have other cool stuff, as well. You need these gadgets to get into certain places to pick up the hundreds of collectibles found throughout the island. I like that throughout the story Batman gets stronger and better gradually which also means there are more difficult enemies you encounter (whose movements are more difficult to counter or you simply need to jump in order to avoid being hit).Detective Vision: You turn this on and you see everything in blue with certain objects highlighted in orange (objects and enemies you can interact with). It's almost like the Eagle Vision in the Assassins Creed franchise. This is a must for the predator challenges. Predator challenges take place in greater rooms indoors and you are required to take down enemies silently. If they see you they'll use their machine guns and even Batman can be riddled with bullets! You always have vantage points in these places (e.g. gargoyle statues on top of the walls) that act as safe havens - you can hide in these places and carefully plan your next move. You can attack from below: you can hide in vents or under grates and suddenly jump out of these places taking down your foes.Challenges: Further arcade challenges await you; you can play FreeFlow combats as well as Predator challenges and earn medals. I believe the GOTY Edition even adds some extra places to test your skills so the playtime with this game is around 40-50 hours at least!Rocksteady has done an amazing job with the Batman franchise! It should also be noted that this game is the first in a trilogy Rocksteady has been working on. While they are working on the 3rd and final installment labelled Arkham Knight a company called Splash released a prequel episode called Arkham Origins. I am currently playing this one and fully satisfied with it.All episodes are highly recommended and they are well worth their money even if not discounted.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2013
												The first thing that really stood out to me about Arkham Asylum was just how polished the game is.I'm serious, everything from the combat, to the detective mode, to the non-linear map design just screams "tested to perfection". It feels like the developers deliberately went into this game attempting to make a licensed title that didn't suck. And went above and beyond the call of duty inorder to do so.The premise of Arkham Asylum is the Joker has taken over and you need to go up against all the classic Batman villains inorder to eventually defeat your arch nemesis. What makes this game stand out, especially compared to other licensed titles is it's non-linearity. The asylum is riddled with alternate passages, secret areas, and numerous collectables alongside RPG elements. It generally feels like a lot of love went into this game, and if you fold the blade over 100 times the final result is one of the most innovative and polished titles out there.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												What can I say? It's the definitive Batman game and possibly one of the best comic book games ever made.The writing is top-notch, and the fact they got a lot of the VAs and writers from TAS (largely considered one of the best adaptions of Batman ever made, animated or otherwise) really makes it feel like what TAS would've been if it had the freedom of a PG-13 rating instead of being limited to a hard G-Rating (or PG in the case of movies like Mask of the Phantasm.). The background stuff like the interview tapes and hidden messages from The Ghost of Arkham we're also great. This is one of the few games I felt compelled to gather all the other stuff in.The gameplay is fluid and really captures the badass feeling playing Batman should entitle and gives you room to either be stealthy or go in swinging and fight everyone head-on with combat that feels satisfying and meaty due to the way the enemies react to hits and accompanying sounds of blows connecting and bones cracking.The graphics and art-design are great and it runs at a near flawless and consistant 1080p/60FPS on my 750ti. I say near-flawless because there's one huge problem:The implentmation of PhysX is horrid and the few areas that make heavy use of it suffer from severe FPS drops if you have it turned on.The only two flaws I can really list aside from that tech failure (which is minor since there's only like three short levels it effects) are the somewhat lack-luster boss fights and the weird save-system that only really triggers when you go through a door seperating areas.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												Batman AA is one of my all time favourite games. The love and respect that Rocksteady have shown to the DC franchise is legendary. This game oozes Batman lore at every turn with the Riddler's collectibles unlocking extras to read. Core characters are realised superbly, with the visuals complemented by the standout voice work of Kevin Conroy as Batman and Mark Hamill as Joker, both reprising their roles from the Batman animated TV series. Combat is fast and kinetic and gives a satisfying sense of Batman's power. An unlock system gives even more combat options and gadgets. The story is enjoyable and the Riddler collectibles are a fun distraction to pursue. The game is rounded out with a few combat and stealth standalone challenges.This is an easy game, even on the Hardest difficulty only a couple of spots present a challenge. It's a pretty easy 100% for achievement hunters. There is no Games For Windows Live in this version, which was perhaps its biggest fault previously. With that removed, I can't fault this game, it's 11/10 for me. Play it.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is a good game. It is the first "real" Batman game: you actually feel like The Bat, have his gadgets, and have a small world to explore. The plot is good, with villains popping up every hour but Joker staying the mastermind of them all. The graphics and gameplay are excellent. Sleeping Dogs has the exact same combat system (I like that one better, but this is the original). Arkham Asylum's combat system has a great free-flow feel, where you hit and block, and then you do a backflip and hit someone else, etc., but my main concern was that when I pressed the right mouse button when an enemy was attacking, Batman sometimes would not block. This got annoying and frustrating in the later missions, especially when Batman's decision not to block made you have to replay a section. Arkham Asylum has both stealth and action: stealth where you hide on top of gargoyles (almost every time) and take out the inmates one by one, and action where you take down five, ten, or even twenty of them. The map is big(Arkham City's map is much better though), but after you beat the campaign the world gets boring. Boss fights were often fun, but also often tedious and frustrating. Some of them are hard to understand if you do not read the hints- so do. The stun and knife inmates are pains in the butt just like in Arkham City, but with luck you can defeat them. The music is good, and there are unlockable challenges and trophies that look like statues. If you have time, play Arkham City and Asylum. If you don't, just play Arkham City because it's a much better game.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
												Batman: Arkham Asylum gets so many positive reviews for a reason. If you want to know why people like it so much, well, the combat system really is as amazing as it gets, the stages that involved sneaking around were extremely fun and intense and the general atmosphere of the game is done just right. If you like games that you can get 100% in without doing extremely tough tasks but getting collectibles instead, well, you won't feel disappointed. The game is set on the Arkham island, which, although smaller and less awesome than the one in Arkham City, does not disappoint at all and has many interesting secrets. I didn't think the story was anything that this game could be praised about, but it was not bad and once in a while you'll also get a nice dose of trippy sh*t from scarecrow sequences.The only thing I really didn't like was the boss fights, which were below average but still not horrible and this does not outweight the good parts of the game. Possibly the biggest disappointment was the final boss. The clever and tricky villain was just turned into another one of those big guys and most of the battle was just fighting with his minions.If you don't like comics or batman, I still reccomend playing this game, cause the gameplay did not disappoint. If you're looking for a game that you can get 100% in, this will also be the right choice, as getting all the achievements takes around 30-35 hours if you're not horrible at combat like me. The game is also not hard to run, so if you're like me and you're stuck with a PC that mosly runs 2D games, get ready for some 3D fun.

Kidding, this game is one of the greatest homages to the dark knight and all of his world's characters.Batman has just captured Joker and is escorting him into Arkham. Soon after he quickly takes over the entire asylum together with other classic batman's enemies. This simple premise is the beginning of the first chapter of the great Arkham Saga. We'll be impersonating Batman in this 3rd person view action and we can go through the entire and vast complex of Arkham to stop Joker and all his collegues. Gameplay is really simple actually and allows the player to learn quickly how to fight, then fight against big numbers of thugs simultaneously while, as usual, boss fights will take very different approaches. Really noteworthy is the Scarecrow's section. However the player can also use a stealth approach, especially in certain areas where you can hold an elevated position (sit on gargoyles), hide in vent grates and slowly approach thugs to silently take them down.Just like the entire franchise, Arkham Asylum uses the Unreal Engine, that allows the view of interesting and inspired buildings, sceneries and closed ambiences.+++PROs+++ STORY. Great storytelling, great direction in cutscenes with an incredible ending that requires a sequel. GAMEPLAY. You can fight all the criminals or hide and ambush them, and use all of batman's gadget. Simply Awesome CHARACTERS. Honestly it's really cool to see the characters portrayed so good in the game. REFERENCES. Endless References, cameos and homages to batman's and DC's universe RIDDLER. The Riddler's challenges are one of the best secondary missions ever. They're just puzzles but they show you parts of the world and make lots of references to other characters.---CONs--- BINDINGS. Key Bindings in a pre-Game Window only? in 2010? Seriously?I played this game on this machine:Intel Core i7-497016Gb RAM DDR3GeForce GTX 660Windows 10 Professional x64

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												Batman Arkham Asylum is the first in what would end up becoming a popular franchise. Its a third person action/adventure where you're tasked with stopping one of theJoker's nefarious new plans involving Arkham Asylum. It features a much darker story than saturday morning fare, more akin to the Christopher Nolan films and the comics.If you're a fan of batman already this game has everything you want: gritty story and visuals, all kinds of bat-gadgets, and satisfying hand-to-hand combat. The presentation is grim and sets a fantastic backdrop for everything that takes place. The voice acting is superb featuring many classic voice actors including Mark Hamil reprising his legendary role as the Joker. Arkham Asylum is a lengthy game looking at 12+ hours at the minimum, with lots to explore and secrets to collect. Despite all the content already available dont expect to see too many famous villains crammed into one game as the developers obviously had sequels in mind, but the villians it did give us fit into the story perfectly.>PROSFaithful to the franchiseDark and gritty visuals and presentationCombat and Puzzles are fun and hardly get boringBoss battles are varied and interestingFantastic Voice ActingGreat graphics with attention to detailHarley Quinn & Poison Ivy>CONSMinor bugs in the V1.1 ReleaseSometimes feels slightly repetitiveEnding could have been betterBottom line: A ruby the size of a tangerine.If you like batman, or if you like gritty dark superhero games, this is your game. It has everything you want and a little more. Now if you excuse me, im going to go play the sequel now. Recommended 8/10

content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is developed by Rocksteady Studios and published by Warner Bros. At first, I am not a huge fan of Batman or pretty much I am not a fan of comic books. Surprisingly, this is the Batman game that met its expectations for fans and comic book alike. The game sets in Arkham Asylum, playing as Bruce Wayne or Batman (state the obvious). The story starts where Batman is taking and apprehending Joker to the Asylum, causing it was a setup and controlling the asylum by Joker. I am not going to tell you much about the story, it's better to play the game to know about the story. Trust me, it's such a great Batman game to start with. The combat system is based on combo, score multipliers, dodges and counter attacks. There are gadgets to tackle obstacles throughout the story. You can upgrade your abilities by leveling up. Collectables all over the map (Riddler's Trophy, scarab wall and searching the answer for Riddler's challenge), like the backstory of Arkham Asylum, the interview tapes, the concept art and character bios to learn about their orginality.+ Pros+ Rich storyline+ Characters are obviously likeable+ Voice acting and musical score+ Freedom Open World (Kind of)+ Atmosphere and graphics of the game+ Combat system+ Extras or Collectables- Cons- Controls for Keyboard and Mouse are confusingly trickyThe verdict for this game's honest review is a must buy, like come on buy this game and you will love it every second, even if you are not a fan of Batman like myself. The story, the atmosphere, the voice acting, combat system and unlockables. You can find all of the extras after you finished the game and play some challenges. I don't find any game's technical flaws (unless I am a blind bat or not paying attention to details). I definitely recommend this game, just go buy the game.Updated: June 05 2015 @ 03:00am - removing the manga next to comic books sentence and finishing touches.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Boy, what a wonder!There’s much to admire in Rocksteady’s adaptation of the caped crusader’s fight against crime. BAA is atmospheric and engrossing, and the gameplay is varied and well designed, with a good mixture of problem solving and combat. The graphics are very good; the combat animation in particular is excellent. Even the controls of the PC version are well designed, which is not something you can often say about games that require a good deal of button mashing. There’s a pretty good storyline too with some sharp dialogue, and the voice acting is strong throughout, especially Mark Hamill as the Joker. My only real gripe is the way the viewpoint changes for the boss fights. It certainly makes them more challenging but it’s also a bit frustrating and, to my mind, unnecessary. But this is an excellent, well-made game and is highly recommended.4/5

												I've been hearing about the Arkham series for a long time, but hadn't jumped in till now, until the WB Humble Bundle came along, I jumped on that as fast as I could.Then several weeks, I finally beat the game.Graphics : For how old of a game it is, it still looks beautiful, and runs very well, even on less powerful hardware. I'm not that much of an expert in Graphical fidelity, but I know when something looks good, and Arkham Asylum definitely looks good.Story : Perhaps the weakest part of the game. Don't get me wrong, the story isn't bad. There weren't very many layers to the story in my opinion, and I couldn't get into the story that much. However, the voice acting that went along with the story was just amazing.Gameplay : The strongest part of the game, the freeflow combat system is symply amazing and really makes you feel like a badass, you just can't get tired of beating up on thugs and similar. However, all the greatest parts of gameplay are completely lost in the boss fights. Where as the gameplay is amazing whenever your fighting thugs, the boss fights limit you greatly.Overall, the game is amazing. Definitely worth a buy.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												An excellent game in all aspects! I'm not a huge Batman fan, but this game was so polished that I could see myself getting into the Batman world.As the titles says you take control of batman in arkham asylum fighting againts the evil…of course I mean Joker.The story reels out with an impressive way fighting different bosses which are villains from comic books.Also our character may solve various puzzles which are Riddle’s puzzle and we can learn various things about arkham location,friends and foes.Despite that, in-game we don’t fight with all famous villains that batman has instead of that, we can learn many things for them, by solving riddles puzzles.I hope some of them appeared on arkham city.Combat system is just awesome.Attacks,heavy attacks,counter attacks and combo attacks are the base ingredients of the combat system.Trying to hit all the enemies flawlessly is a bit of challenging which is the best part of the combat.As you continue, our character unlocks new finishing moves which can instant kill an enemy we choose and after that we continue our combo in order to not get hit.The last kill is in slow motion!When you are not in combat, basically you are what really batman is….a detective searching for clues for murders and other things.In order to follow the clues, you must use some of the gadgets you have from the start or either unlocked later like the spray which explodes etc.One amazing thing is that you can press a button and instantly the camera changes and go to ‘detective mode’ in order to see clues,vents and other things which keep in secret.Batman is stealth so many times in game, we can kill secretly one by one all the villains on a location where many enemies patrolling with the right sequence.Sounds are awesome, from grapple up to the opening of cape and voice acting.Graphics the same.UE3 did a VERY good job here.After you finish the main game, either you can walk around on arkham asylum either you can solve Riddle’s puzzles.Summarizing either you are a batman fan or not you will love this game.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												While Batman Arkham Asylum lacks many of the gameplay improvements and larger environments that later games in the series introduced, its linear design and single story thread offer something that later games in the series lost over time: focus. Arkham Asylum is a dense and highly detailed setting that is ripe for exploration. Tucked away everywhere are mysterious hidden rooms and passages which contain references to the Dark Knight's history and offer the player alluring tales about the dark secrets hidden within the asylum.The game's general art and character designs are also more true to the comic books' outlandish and extravagant art than previous games in the series are, as they opted for more gritty and realistic designs. This gives the game an exciting and somewhat fantastical tone that highly effective in making you want to progress through the plot, which itself is a highly well written and performed tale, that will hold your attention throughout the duration of the game.Neither the freeflow combat nor the predator encounter systems are as tight or varied as they are in later titles, but that isn't to say they're dull. They are both still rock solid in their handling and execution, and form the backbone to what I believe are, to this day, the game's strongest gameplay feature: its boss battles. In comparison to other games in the series, Arkham Asylum's boss battles are grand and have a sense of immense scale. Many of the bosses themselves are presented as gigantic titans which need to be brought down in some amazing manner, thus making the task of doing so a tense and highly rewarding experience. Other games, with maybe the exception of Arkham City, largely abandoned this style of boss fight making Arkham Asylum's maybe the best in the series.So while Arkham Asylum may not feature all the great gameplay advances achieved in later games, the manner in which it progresses in such a highly focused way, in terms of both its world and story, insures that players will have a superb gaming experience.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Asylum. A game started as by Batman fans, for Batman fans as a love letter. The one that started it all. The first Arkham game has aged rather well, and is still fun to play to this day. The story in my opinion is a bit better than City, (Due to the fact that this one I didn't figure out the plot by looking at the voice actors) The story starts like this: Batman has recently captured the Joker, who set off a large fire in Blackgate Prison, causing the Blackgate prisoners to be moved to Arkham Asylum. Batman escorts Joker personally to Arkham. While delivering him to his cell under heavy security, Joker manages to escape while Harley Quinn, has taken control over Arkham. Batman has to go after them for the first (Maybe) long night of things he could have never expected.  Combat options are very limited and not as refined compared to Arkham City, and Arkham Knight, but still has the Arkham feel to it which City and Knight just made better.The Predator options are also much less fun compared to City due to how little gadgets there are, and no grate, vent, or quick takedowns. But, the fan favourite, the Inverted takedown is in this game. All in all a great Batman game, and one people will remember as one of the better ones. I give this game, A 9/10

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												I didn't play this game until late 2015 (so a bit late to the party) and not until after playing Batman: Arkham Origins so my perspective is naturally compared against my experience with the later title. Since then I've played all of the Arkham titles and am a big fan.Arkham Asylum, being the first entry into the francise for Rocksteady, is the simplest of the bunch. The gameplay is far more linear and the graphics are noticeably simpler (mainly the cape). However, despite the minor drawbacks, if you've played any of the other entries in the series and enjoyed them, you will not be disappointed here. The gameplay itself is very similar and the story is great.If you've never played a Batman Arkham game before, I highly recommend that you do and you might as well start here because it is the beginning of the story (well, in a way Origins is). I had been away from gaming for several years (far too long) and it was Arkham Orgins that pulled me back in. The prospect of playing as Batman in an open-world 3rd person environment was the initial grab. The game mechanics and the story kept me hooked. The fighting mechanics are so much fun but take a bit of practice to really master. I'm not an expert on the Batman comics but I understand that the story here pulls from some of the most acclaimed comic material. And execution was made wonderfully with some notable voice acting talent from 'Batman The Animated Series.'

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												I can't stress enough how amazing this game is.  The game looks great to this day, and is very well optimized.  The combat is fun and flows so well, and with different types of enemies thrown in together it's always keeping you on your toes, making you change strategy mid fight.  There is always a surprise thrown in to keep it fun and engaging.  But that's not all this game is about, there is also Riddler Challenges.  Whether it is a characters Hat you must seek out in a room, a trophy, or a hidden question mark you can only see in detective vision.  There are over 70 of these challenges, it keeps the game fresh and add's a puzzle element to the game.Last but not least, if you were ever a fan of Metroid, or Castlevania, then you will love this game.  The level design reminds me so much of those two games.  Seeing a cracked wall with a Riddler Trophy on the other side but not having the right tool to get to it.  Basically a "come back later when you have this item".  The game is linear, but they do such a great job at streaming together the Asylum, and taking you to places you never thought existed.  You will be doing alot of back tracking, so if you miss an item don't worry, you are able to go back to anywhere in the Asylum.  The game is not short at all, and has you interacting with all of your favorite villians from Batman's universe.  The game is a blast and if you haven't played it yet, then there is something wrong with you!

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												There's not much point in writing an in depth review for Arkham Asylum given the wealth of positive reviews out there so, in short, this game makes you feel like Batman. I played using an Xbox controller and the controls and targeting system were so intuitive that there was no learning curve; I just went into Arkham and did some stealthy stuff, beat up a bunch of bad guys and propelled myself into the darkness with some crazy gadget. Job done, and I felt awesome.The best thing I could say about this game is that while everything feels so effortless, it's also quite difficult. I don't entirely understand how they managed to do that, but keeping that balance certainly isn't easy. Arkham Asylum does this so well that you just come out of the game feeling like a hero.I only have one bad thing to say about this game, and that is that I wanted to hang every bad guy from a gargoyle, but it's just not possible. The game even actively tried to stop me from doing so at one point, like I was a child being scolded for eating too much candy.10/10 would have myself commited again.

content:
Posted: April 16
												Arkham Asylum is one of the best games of all time. The first of Rocksteady's trilogy of Batman games, Asylum is perhaps the most clean-structured of them. Small area, vibrant foes, and one big plot in the background. Add to it the voices being those from the Animated Series and it just... fits. Seriously, Kevin Conroy as Batman, Arleen Sorkin as Harley Quinn, and the greatest Joker of them all, Mark Hamill... Yeah... just perfection.Add in the combat system (which took a little time to get used to) and it is excellent.The visuals are also striking... though you might miss most of it with detective vision having such an appeal to it. Which brings me to the gadgets, Batman's stock in trade. They are effective in their own way. And this game does set the stage for what comes after.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2013
												As much as I love playing creative indie games, it is really refreshing to play a game with a huge budget where they worked closely with Nvidia to optimize the graphics and make a 3D Vision ready game. What I mean by all of this is: Batman: Arkham Asylum looks gorgeous! There were even a few scenes that had a lot of PhysX effects going on that my GTX 670 struggled with. I wouldn't have guessed that it came out in 2009. One of my biggest pet peeves is when games that look great have cutscenes that have been rendered in 720p (I'm looking at you, Mass Effect series) but the only difference I could see in Asylum was that the cutscenes were not in 3D.I'm not a huge Batman fan, so I don't know who most of the villains are; I only learned about Two Face when I watched The Dark Knight. Arkham Asylum does a very good job of introducing the characters and giving their backgrounds. They even have a little bio section for each major character with both in-universe and real life facts about them. I could tell that most of the character designs were new takes on those characters, and I definitely think that they were done well. I found it a little odd that almost every single person in the game was ripped, but this is Batman after all.Mark Hamill did a phenomenal job voicing the Joker. He was easily the most interesting character tho listen to, and I intentionally died a couple of times so I could listen to him taunt me.Each main villain had a couple of levels devoted to them. My personal favorite were the Scarecrow levels because I got to relive some of the defining moments in Batman's life. By that I mean I got to see his parents die.The gameplay is pretty basic: left-click to hit people, and right-click to counter when they try to hit you. Some enemy types switch this up a little by making you stun them first or dodging behind them before you can hit them, but ultimately it only adds one extra button that you have to hit before taking them down.My favorite parts of the game were the rooms where there were a bunch of armed thugs in a large area, and I had to figure out how to take them down without being seen. It reminded me of the scenes in Batman Begins down by the docks where Batman did just that. Unfortunately I wasn't quite as good at it as the real Batman.The detective "puzzles" were fairly interesting, but usually very straightforward. I felt like I was doing less detective work and more just following a trail that the developers would only let me see if I turned on the special goggles.My least favorite parts by far were the boss battles. They were clearly constructed exactly the same way that boss battles were made back in the 90's. I was usually stuck on a platform below the much larger boss, performing the same actions multiple times while looking for patterns in their attacks so I knew when they were vulnerable.It took me a little over 10 hours to complete the story. It seemed like I wasn't missing much by not exploring heavily; the main missions took me all over the island. It would have been nice to have gotten more of the audio logs, which were pretty amusing, and I only found a fraction of the Riddler trophies. I'm definitely not a completionist.Overall I enjoyed the game a lot, and I would recommend that anyone who thinks Batman is the coolest play it. It's currently $20, which is a pretty reasonable price.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is pretty cool I guess.You play as a man with the world's deadest parents: Bruce Wayne who uses all of his dosh to become a lunatic in a bat suit. But he knows kung fu so its okay I guess. The combat is pretty satisfying for what it actually is. You have two buttons for combat that also handle gadgets like your spider-man web sling and your ninja stars. Also, you're a ninja. Neat. Unless you're playing on a keyboard where you have to pull some quarter-circle forward's street fighter♥♥♥♥♥♥just to throw your big dumb bat shaped ninja stars at ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who have it in their mind that just because there are two of them that they can take the big 6'3 angry man in the bat suit. Batman has a vast array of gadgets to hunt down his girlfriend: the Joker. These gadgets include: Batarangs, explosives, grappling hook, goblin darts, cancer vision, a car that you can't drive, action blanket, and his power frown. Oh yeah, and there's stealth, which is also cool. The big dumb mooks that try to kill batman (because that's worked before) sometimes have guns and you need to be super sneaky like the Burger King, only instead of delicious whoppers, you hand out pain. It's cool to see the mooks♥♥♥♥♥♥themselves once they realize that maybe trying to stop the one guy without super powers that has the ability to call himself a super hero is not the best idea. Should you play this game? Probably, I guess, I'm not your mom. I stuck around to get all the cheevos so my opinion is pretty great. I say this game is a solid 9/11. Only slightly better than Superman 64. The Alligator man boss fight was ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, though.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is one of the best superhero games I've ever played. I've never seen a developer do such an awesome superhero game since Spider-Man 2. It's a game where you play as Batman as he tries to stop the criminals within Arkham Asylum of succeeding in their plans of killing countless people. Why is this game so great? Well, there are a lot of reasons really. The gameplay. It's so good. Whenever I play fire this game up on my laptop and play on a challenge map, I enjoy just fighting enemies. The combat freeflow system is amazing, you fight seamlessly from goon to goon punching them, kicking them, breaking their arm, throwing them, the combat flows so smoothly. It feels so satisfying to fight enemies with the freeflow system that Rocksteady implented. Everything connects together so well. Other than the freeflow system, the stealth is pretty satisfying when you pull it off well. The gadgets Batman uses are pretty awesome, you can set traps for enemies while you lure them in. The gameplay in Arkham Asylum is awesome, Arkham City improves on it though.The story revolves around Batman and his usual foes as he tries to stop them from killing guards and tons of innocents. You get to fight iconic batman villains such as Scarecrow, Killer Croc, Joker, Poison Ivy and Bane.Joker is awesome in the game, laughing maniacally as he cracks his jokes. Mark Hamill does Joker justice, his voice is perfect. Kevin Conroy also did a great job as Batman.Get it even if you're not a Batman fan, it's amazing.Characters: 9/10Story: 8.5/10Gameplay: 9/10Sound: 8/10Overall: 9/10

content:
Posted: February 24
												Play as Batman, taking on violent and psychopathic criminals running rampant over Arkham! Arkham Asylum features puzzles, exploration, and backtracking, making it almost like a classic 3D platformer.Combat looks and feels extremely fluid, making it very satisfying to take on and transition between multiple enemies in a brawl. Can occasionally feel button mashy, but does a good job of punishing you for doing so, encouraging you to play reactively/predictively. Both the puzzles and combat feel hard enough to be rewarding, yet easy enough to rarely make you struggle.On top of the gameplay, theres plenty for DC fans, with backstory in the form of collectible interview tapes and bio's from classic villains from the series. Also Mark Hamill's performance as The Joker was amazing!

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												In this game you play as the one and only Batman as he takes on the Joker and his minions in Arkham Asylum. Arkham Asylum has lots of detail for a prison and you will be able to explore it as you look for the Riddler's Challenge trophies, interview tapes, and solve environmental puzzles (mostly just puns). Only complaint is that it only has 2 bosses practically. All the boss fights except for the Ivy one have you against tough Bane like inmates. But if you like Batman you will enjoy playing through anyways. A small complaint is that if you use xbox360e for your non 360 controllers it will disable achievements. I had to use it cause with my Wii controller pro because it inverted the right stick on both the X and Y axis.The combat is really fun too and requires more timing than how it looks on video. You also get to play with toys that are sort of like Zelda items since they open up new areas. And if you like the Batman franchise you will be rewarded with your favorite villains in audio interview and the spirit of Armaedus Arkham.

												Batman: Arkham Asylum (B:AA) is one of the most fantastic examples of a comic-to-video game crossover that has fans of both fully satisfied in story and gameplay. You control the Dark Knight and venture through the infamous Arkham facility using Batman's various gadgets, detective prowess and combat skills. Fans of the Batman and story-driven, action-packed video games should not pass up B:AA.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												I was pretty late to the party on this one. However, five years after release this title stands as one of the greatest games I've ever played. I've always been a huge fan of Batman, but I never expected to be immersed in that world and character so intensely. The gameplay is great, the story fits perfectly into the existing Batman mythos, and the visuals stand up TO. THIS. DAY. I couldn't believe how spot on they were with even the smallest details, and how well they fleshed out the geography of the Asylum. Just when you think the game would begin to get stale they throw you a curveball, or a different style of gameplay. Whether it be Scarecrow's fear gas induced hallucinations, or a mad dash from a raging Killer Croc, I was consistently entertained and surprised throughout. And I'm not a major completionist, but I couldn't help but solve everything the Riddler threw at me throughout the game.This game is timeless. 10/10, would Batman again.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												I'm not a big fan of Batman, having never read the comics or even seen all of the big new films.However, I enjoyed this game a lot.It's a solid adventure game set in an island prison.Iconic Batman villains have all made their way there and are running loose until you go punch them in the face.It has its rough edges here and there, but honestly, I had a great time with this.My main gripe, one that had me stumped for a good long while, was the 'investigate' mechanic.This is mapped to holding the left bumper (or whatever keyboard button switches on detective mode). Investigating things in the game is explained once at the very start, then used for optional collectibles and backstory, then suddenly, well past the halfway point, makes its return critical to the game's progress.I'd by then completely forgotten how to trigger this and the game doesn't re-explain the mechanic or even list it in the controls or help functions. I eventually had to dig through guides and walkthroughs for a refresher on how this core game mechanic worked.The rest of the game is totally fine though.Batman and its universe will always be a bit silly in a totally straight-faced way, but this outing definitely showed that it can be presented in a way enjoyable to non-fans as well.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 5
												-Shortcut Review-Cool, first entry of the Arkham series. Graphics look great for a game that's over 7 years old. It's an action, somewhat "open-world", adventure game with a subtle touch of eerie vibes. You might need to install NVidia drivers in order to play the game, especially if you carry AMD drivers. Story is intriguing, but not something that is not over the top or that has you at the edge of your seat. All the events are set at The Asylum. Literatly. Huge cast of villians and other characters from the comics including Batman, of course (duh). Control scheme is enjoyable and makes it easy to play as the Dark Knight. Technically, you can play the game as standalone, but it does leave you to play the entire Arkham series. -Full Review (Somewhat Spoiler free)-Overview: Now, if you're not familiar with the Batman franchise, at least note that this guy can just kick your♥♥♥♥♥by just glaring at you. He is an expert martial artist and an excellent strategist with a degree in physical humiliation. He is calm and level-headed at every alarming moment with a high sense of intelligence and problem solving. At this point in Gotham, Batman is a seasoned veteran, along with his partner, The Oracle, contains a notorious record for incarcerating villians at fault of violent crimes. This is where the Joker, aka the "Prince of Crimes", is finally caught by the Cape Crusaider and thrown into Arkham Asylum. However, all further punishment is thrown out the window as the asailant escapes and completely takes over the entire facility with the help of Harleyquinn and their henchmen. The combat system unlocks gadgets and skills once the player gathers experience points. These various gadgets include the classic batarang and batclaw as well as other weapons such as the explosive gel that explodes on walls and grounds. Batman gets stronger and more versatile: the more he's able to take down enemies and go into secret areas that are not so easy to reach. His "Bat Investigating" vision is the best out of his skills, because he is able to find hidden clues and figure out what gadget he must use when needed. As Batman explores further into Arkham Asylum, he constantly runs in radical moments where he has to free hostiles from his enemies before they are doomed. Batman is great at being incognito, so it's awesome gameplay when you go through small air vents and drop down on enemies from more than 10 feet high. Not only does Batman has to worry 'bout these hostiles, but he has to take down supervillians like Scarecrow, Killer Croc, The Riddler and more that are running loose in the facility. Each supervillian will challenge Batman through puzzles and some levels become platformers as Batman must survive every one of them. There are way too many sidequests that can be completed for rewards. About over 200 missions that can be fun, but then becomes a dragging chore after awhile. Kinda takes out the joy of game for me 'cause I gotta be aware of the sidequests. The Riddler will have Batman to find scattered trophies and footprints throughout the game. Also, Batman can unlock the origins of Arkham Asylum and gather patient recordings from supervillians to hear audio about his foes. Some gadgets can be useful such as the Batvision and clue scanner to find these achievements. Very fun game to play that doesn't require much thought. Best feats are the combant system and gagets. Not a fan for the huge disarray of sidequests because they're essential for 100% complete game. Cheers

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
												To be honest what Rocksteady did with Batman in its first iteration Arkham Asylum is nothing short of a master stroke for the 3rd person fighter/combat system that has reverberated throughout game design and thinking of 3rd person games to date.      Arkham Asylum is a triumph in every aspect. Combat, story (characters, voice acting, etc), atmosphere, sound design and even graphical fidelity. This game captures what it is to be batman and my god its DAMN FUN. The developers going into making Arkham Asylum said "What can we do to make you feel like batman right away, as soon as we give the player control we want them to feel like a bad(t♥♥♥♥♥(pardon the pun). You feel like batman, the way your character is animated and moves, the freeflow combat system has you jumping around bruising bad people until the cows come home with some of the most satisfying combat I have played to date.      Here is a huge thing for me, and for all Batman fans. I watched the cartoon as a kid. Kevin Conroy, Mark Hamil all brought the cartoon and that world to vivid life. Well guess what guys, they got just about everyone from the cartoon to revoice their characters in Arkham Asylum, Harley, Gordon, Batman, Joker, Scarcrow etc. It is an incredible cast and it immerses you so fully in the world you almost never want to leave. The world that Rocksteady has recreated is fantastic, with dark colors and almost a noirish feel to the game that sucks you deeper and deeper into the world. You truly ARE batman in this game. It reminds me of a mixture of the cartoon and Tim Burtons dark seedy take on Batman. It is truly a game to be experianced.     So would I recommend this game? Abso♥♥♥♥inglutely. If you enjoy 3rd person fighting games with smooth combat systems that just make you want to sing while you are playing them. THIS GAME IS FOR YOU. If you are a fan of the Batman universe, cartoon, or comics YOU OWE it to yourself to pick up and play this game. It is absolutely fantastic.I would recommend this game to just about anyone who enjoys a solid, FUN game in every aspect. I would honestly give this game a 9 out of 10. Top 20 in my list of favorite games of all time.See you in Arkham City Batfans. _Rog

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This review comes from an FPS-biased gamer, so it took some time (i.e. 4 years after this game launched) for me to play it, mostly because I bought it late, and partly because I was waiting for steamworks.Now that it's supported, GFWL is gloriously gone and the steam achievements are seamless. As for the game, the intro is nice and the visuals are impressive, but I found that the game really assumes that you know what you're doing and where you're going. The map system is terrible, and I found myself doubling back down corridors over and over to figure where the heck I was supposed to be. Half the items you see as you play the game you can't collect until after you've unlocked certain upgrades, which is frustrating, and frankly a poor way to convince a completionist to go back through all the levels he's gotten lost in and ask him to go find more trophies. Nevertheless, I did it all.The main campaign has a solid story and - as a person who is not intimately familiar with every villian - I enjoyed reading the back stories on the characters I unlocked. The immersion level is very good, and the controls are intuitive.Challenge mode gets a little frustrating, but it's worth it to see the achievements pop at the end.Overall: It's a solid Batman game with some flaws, and while it doesn't stack up for me with the top games, it's still a worthy endeavor.

GOTY라는 타이틀이 전혀 어색하지가 않다. 최고 단점으로는 연출에만 집중한듯한 힘빠지는 보스전. 그 구성과 여러가지 캐릭터성은 잘살린듯하지만 자세히 보면 그저 평소 전투의 연속된 측면이 많다. 리들러 챌린지는 도전과제를 달성한다는 재미와 아캄버스의 세계관을 좀더 잘알수있게 해주는 측면도 있지만. 누군가에게는 그저 안해도 그만인 숨은 트로피 찾기가 된다. 어찌보면 양날의 검같은 시스템. 여러가지로 많은 재미를 안겨주었지만 2회차 플레이의 동기화를 못찾게 해주고. 리들러챌린지의 반만큼만 사이드 미션이 있다면 어쨌을까라는 아쉬움도 많이 남는다. 너무나도 괜찮은 작품이기에 그만큼 사소한것도 아쉬워지는 작품이다.

												Critically acclaimed Batman: Arkham Asylum returns with a remastered Game of the Year Edition, featuring 4 extra Challenge Maps. Batman Arkham Asylum has one of the best combat i have ever seen in video games, the takedowns, the punches , kicks are just superb. The Game offers a variety of different things so you will not get bored of playing, If you don't want to play the missions, you can do challenges or riddles. Every Aspect of Batman Arkham Asylum is Superb. Loving this game so far. I still need to play Batman Arkham City but so far this is my favourite superhero game. Definitely Recommend playing.10/10 Fantastic Game.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is one of the best third-person stealth-action games ever made, and the best video game released by Rocksteady Studios so far. It's a fun and immersive game whether you're a DC fan or not. While the game plot is based on the comic books and not the movies, you don't need any prior experience with either to really enjoy the atmosphere created by the developers. All the action takes place on the island-bound asylum known as Arkham. Environments range from run-down morgues to a crumbling neo-gothic mansion, all of which look lush. Assisting the Joker is his army of convict henchmen who can be dispatched using vicious hand-to-hand combat moves. With no real special powers , Batman relies only on his training and gagdets. Luckily the hero can counter his enemies' close-quarter combat moves with ease, and the animation is breathtakingly fluid.

												A metroid-vania style beat em up which is probably the closest you'll ever come to actually being batman. The fighting engine is simple but really satisfying, with a combo systen that rewards skill. For a console port the visuals here are really nice, especially if you have an Nvidia card. The game makes very good use of physx with fog that shifts as you walk through it and tiles smashing off the floor as you introduce it to mooks heads. The boss fights were a bit rubbish and the ending was a letdown though.The second game which I don't own on PC is equally good, but with tons more content.

COMPLETED 100%A fine game, typical of Unreal Engine 3 structure, that is flawless in design and gameplay. The fighting mechanics is amazingly fluid and smooth and it's simple for Batman to easily leap around to enemies, even those far away from him, with the press of a button. Game is technically open world; small in size but non-linear with different distinct separate areas to explore. Can't find anything bad to say about the game but it's easy to see why it's rated so highly. IMO The Amazing Spiderman game is better than this though.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												For those who don’t already know about this treasure I only discovered and played recently Batman: Arkham Asylum is an excellent story action/stealth action game, any Batman or DC fan would love.Pros; Nice fighting mechanics (I played Mad Max before this and read many reviews about how the fighting style was similar this is just as good with sometimes better visuals when you unlock the moves), you will take on small to large groups of enemies in a smack/counter moves. For those who enjoy Stealth based games this has plenty, I’m not a big fan of this genre but was pleasantly surprised it didn’t take over and was easy to get into and perform those silent take downs without being seen. Some nice boss/villain fights to keep you entertained. A few minor puzzles and collectables in the form of Riddler riddles, some of which require you to grapple, climb or just scan areas in far off corners. Excellent story as mentioned before as Batman battles an array of villains as well as a nice steady progress as the henchmen themselves get harder to defeat.Cons; Personally the only thing that slightly annoyed me was the Scarecrow sections as the game seemed to switch from 3D to a strange 2D style, this also occurred in a few fights towards the end. Not a big issue but did confuse me as the normal game view and ability to move the camera were just fine.Overall and excellent game that holds up to many even to this date well worth is asking price even more so if on sale, thumbs up!

content:
Posted: February 26, 2011
												Lets start things off with Metal Gear Solid. That game was my of all time favorite. No other game could touch the espionage play and the fantastic story. Untill Batman Arkham Asylum bummped MGS as My #1. With repect to MGS it is bested just slightly. A very close second on my list. Thanks MGS for a long standing above the rest. Now BAA takes the spotlight. This game follows the feel of Batman Dark Night with the voices of Kevin Conroy as Batman and Mark Hamill as Joker. (I honestly believe BAA could not have done well with out thier voices) Also Bat gadgets to suit the moment. Great fighting controls. Dark brooding music and it would not be Batman without detective work.  As you are looking for clues, Joker is throwing verbal comical abuse to your efforts in finding him and you can't help but smerk and even bust out laughing!  Also, lots of extra challenges for when you finish the game. Online score charts show how well you do against the world. GET THIS GAME!  ***** #1 all time fav

												Batman: Arkham Asylum is the greatest comic book videogame of all time -- and the Game of the Year Edition just adds to that. This is an adult Dark Knight story that is well-told, packs some truly fun gameplay elements, has topnotch voice talent, and feels like it's part of Batman canon. If I have to nitpick, I wish the cutscenes looked better as they can distract from the tale and that the AI was a bit more responsive, but those are tiny flaws that shouldn't distract from the big picture. Rocksteady nailed what Batman is supposed to feel like. Fans, rejoice.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
												Despite never being a fan of the DC Universe I always heard and thought great things about Batman Arkham Asylum. I was surprised when I first played it really hooked me up. The combat was probably the thing that got me most excited, it felt so satisfying to just punch guys in the face and do all those crazy moves. Another thing I really liked is that despite Arkham Asylum having a linear story they do give you the feel that you are allowed to go anywhere you want in Arkham Island and explore, I really appreciate when they do that and as you unlocked more gadgets backtracking came into place in case I wanted to get all the trophies and solve all the riddles which I actually didn't. The graphics are pretty good looking and I really like the grim atmosphere of the Asylum. Ocasionally there are some "puzzle" and stealth sections which I think they are important because they bring someone of a variety to the gameplay. Despite the enemies kept being the same over and over I feel like the boss battles made up for it. That said I really enjoyed my time with Batman Arkham Asylum but I really couldn't be bothered with getting all the collectibles and playing each challenge but overall I do think it is a great game.

												Its more of a thinking man's puzzle game with a pretty solid fighting/combat system.  The emphasis is more on detective work than just straight beat 'em up in an alley, and thats not as bad as it might sound.  If you watched the 90s cartoon, you'll love this.  Original voice acting with a lot more adult theme to it (swearing, skimpy female costumes) and the story is actually really good if a little bit predictable (spoiler: batman wins lol!).  The challenges are pretty hard and IMO not worth much, but they're still there.  TL;DR: This is a good value at $7.50 or lower.

Un tad jokers izmuk un sakas terors arkham island.Speles turpinas un ari turpinasies ar banditu sisanu.nosakuma tas skita neinterasnti bet kad sakas upgrade un kombo taisisana aiziet liela azarta.Un tad paradijas riddlera miklas kas man pasam bija viss interesantaka lieta, bet kas ari aiznema speles ilgako dalu.Man patika ka vini betmenu nenosauca par supervaroni bet gan par pasaules labako dektektivu un kas skita pa visam logiski.Speles laika tu iegust visadas papildmantinas un kuras tu uzlabo.Speles minusus uz reiz redzeju jo es tads malacis saku nu ar arkham city. Protams tie bija svarigas lietas ka: lidosanas laika nomerket un izsaut uz vietu kur velies.Saja spelet bija vel leksanas poga(spelejot arkham city tu doma kpc nav),bet izradijas pa tiesam lieka spelejot.Spelet pec iziesana pagarinas ar riddlera miklam kas liek padomat bet saja dala tas ir atri izpildamas.(ja tev vel ir karte).Par atminejumiem to iegusti citu cilveku biografiju un vel 3d telus vari apskatit.Spele vel ir chalange mods kurs ir neliels, bet grutaks neka arkham city. Ir 2 veidi sado visiem pa seju ar lielaku kombo vai ari sado konkreta veida cilvekiem pa mapi ejot abos gadijumos ir ieteicams dabut visus upgrade citadi bus gruti vai nevaresi iziet.upgrade klasts bija loti normala daudzuma.Spele man skita aizraujosa ari tas ka bija bosu rezims.Spele man ilga tikai ap12h izejot SP un ari ridlera miklas visas. Bet vel nav iziets challange mods ta ka es to citigi daru.So spele iesaku visiem un loti rekomendeju nopirkt visas 3 dala.  Mans vertejums 9.1/10

content:
Posted: March 4
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is the greatest comic book videogame of all time -- and the Game of the Year Edition just adds to that. This is an adult Dark Knight story that is well-told, packs some truly fun gameplay elements, has topnotch voice talent, and feels like it's part of Batman canon. If I have to nitpick, I wish the cutscenes looked better as they can distract from the tale and that the AI was a bit more responsive, but those are tiny flaws that shouldn't distract from the big picture. Rocksteady nailed what Batman is supposed to feel like. Fans, rejoice.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												For those who don’t already know about this treasure I only discovered and played recently Batman: Arkham Asylum is an excellent story action/stealth action game, any Batman or DC fan would love.Pros; Nice fighting mechanics (I played Mad Max before this and read many reviews about how the fighting style was similar this is just as good with sometimes better visuals when you unlock the moves), you will take on small to large groups of enemies in a smack/counter moves. For those who enjoy Stealth based games this has plenty, I’m not a big fan of this genre but was pleasantly surprised it didn’t take over and was easy to get into and perform those silent take downs without being seen. Some nice boss/villain fights to keep you entertained. A few minor puzzles and collectables in the form of Riddler riddles, some of which require you to grapple, climb or just scan areas in far off corners. Excellent story as mentioned before as Batman battles an array of villains as well as a nice steady progress as the henchmen themselves get harder to defeat.Cons; Personally the only thing that slightly annoyed me was the Scarecrow sections as the game seemed to switch from 3D to a strange 2D style, this also occurred in a few fights towards the end. Not a big issue but did confuse me as the normal game view and ability to move the camera were just fine.Overall and excellent game that holds up to many even to this date well worth is asking price even more so if on sale, thumbs up!
