content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												If you add up the time spent in all my games across all my platforms, you will find that I have sunk the most time into this game. Regular, game of the year, special 3D, They all serve for excellent excuses to replay this game. If you're wanting to get into Batman then this is actually a great jumping off point as the lore and characters are so incredibly accurate to the canon of the Dark Knight. I will admit that the physical gameplay is rougher than in the later games so if you go from Arkham City to this then you will feel like you're moving through syrup at times. But this is the game that started the others off and cemented the Arkham games in the public spotlight, and you can tell why while playing, even the collectibles feel fun and interesting to the very end. Stealth, combat, and story all come together to make an unforgettable game that truly makes you feel like the Batman.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												Great game based on one of the greatest superheroes of all time--Batman. The combat is immersive; if you ever played Spiderman, the combat mimicks that of Spidey and counter measuring your enemies is very satisfying. Nothing beats dodging and throwing Mike Tyson punches and spin kicks to thugs. Majority of buildings and structures are mountable with your Batlaw to scout areas for enemies or to strategize how to pick them off one-by-one. The latter will apply to situations when there are enemies with machine guns as bullets take a good chunk of Batman's health. Yet this is where it gets fun; you as The Dark Knight can use the Batclaw to mount on a gargoyle and press Y button to hang an unsuspecting thug onto the gargoyle while he screams "Let me down!" Others nearby will hear their comrade and rush to him. What do you do? Grapple to the next gargoyle and repeat. You can also take them out silently by sneaking behind them or using certain gadgets. For enemies with only fists and melee weapons, you can just zerg in and counter when necessary. Graphics are amazing as are the movie-like cutscenes. The voice acting is superb. I recommend playing with Physics on. I played with the GTX 295 with Physics set to High and it was outstanding. The game is very fun. Only part what I viewed as tedious was Croc and his lair. Scarecrow was literally creepy and disturbing. Poison Ivy was, well, hot! The final battle to the game's conclusion was a great experience. Simple but challenging. I'm now playing Arkham City. Plan is to play the whole trilogy and Arkham Knight as soon as it releases.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												Ah, Batman Arkham Asylum. The beggining to a fantastic series, and the greatest Batman videogame series of all time. Simply a masterpiece.Where do I start?Arkham Asylum is unique compared to the other 3 games (I include Origins, no hate), because it's not open world. So you don't have a huge playground to play around with. It also has the most difficult stealth and combat, and other things, due to lacking double counters, double takedowns, knockout smashes, quickfire gadgets, the dive bomb, and most importantly, quick escapes with the Grapnel Boost/Accelerator or the Smoke Pellet. Here, armed men actually pose a challenge. That makes you think more tactically and plan ahead, more than the other games.Definitely recommended.I recommend to play the whole series in this order : Asylum, then City, then Origins, and finally, Arkham Knight. Trust me.9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												I know I'm very late posting this review, but I'm going to do it anyway.TL;DR:Pros:- Smooth combat system (choice of beat-em-up or stealth)- Be the Batman. Use his gadgets.- Learn more Batman lore than you knew existed- Engaging and new plot- Dynamic Dialogue- Appealing art style and graphicsCons:- Controls on Mac were a little hard to get used to, but you can change your keyboard bindings, and I believe you also have the option of playing with a gamepad.Breezy's full review: Batman: Arkham Asylum is hands down the best video game based on a comic that I've ever played and one of the best games overall in my collection. I remember playing the demo at my local GameStop and being sort of skeptical as it just seemed like another beat-em-up. Flash forward to about 5 years later and I'm so glad that I was wrong.    The story is refreshing and encapsulating. The dialogue is great (a lot of times humorous, a lot of times epic, only sometimes corny). Like everyone else says, the combat system is the most fluid I've seen in a video game, though I much prefer the "Predator" style of combat (taking out enemies stealthily) in the game. Being the Batman and getting to use all his gadgets (Batclaw, Detective Mode, explosive gel, batarang (in the form of the normal, multiple, explosive, and remote controlled)), and appearances by both the Batmobile and the Batwing were definitely a treat.   I honestly have to say that the Riddler trophies were my favorite part of the game. When the trophies were first introduced in the game I really had no intention of collecting all 240 of them. But the developers did something very clever and linked character backgrounds to most of the trophies. Some of the trophies take the form of interview tapes with Arkham inmates, Chronicles of Arkham (cryptic messages left by Amadeus Arkham to be found and deciphered), or simply scanning the environment as a visual answer to one of the Riddler's riddles. Of course, there are actual trophies you can find, but I much prefered the ones that would provide some background on the characters. Before this game, I had minimal knowledge of the Batman universe. When I discovered that the trophies could actually unlock character bios (and some nice viewable character trophies), I became obsessed with finding them. Through the character bios and other various forms of the trophies, I became educated on more of the Batman universe than I thought I would want to know. But don't get me wrong, every detail about a character or asset in the Batman world interested more than the last.   Actual gameplay wise, I probably beat it in about 12-13 hours. However, as you can see from my hours played, I spent a lot more time in the game than that. What was I doing? Collecting trophies, of course. Also, I spent several hours in the challenge maps where you rack up points by seeing how long of a combo you can get on enemies or you complete predator challenges, where you must knock out enemies in a specific way (i.e. break through a glass ceiling to take out an enemy). The GOTY Edition DLC  offers you the choice of playing as the Joker in these challenge maps, and it's pretty awesome and a nice change of pace from playing as Batman. End note:My only real prior knowledge of Batman came after Christopher Nolan's Dark Knight Trilogy and that was about the extent of it (besides watching a few episodes of the animated series growing up). The movies were great, expecially the Dark Knight, but they didn't really expand on the Batman universe, but instead focused on dark realism. This game, however, seemed to capture the wonder and atmosphere of the Batman comics and various animated series. I guess you could say that Batman has gained a Batfan. Thanks for reading.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Thouroughly enjoyed this game, I had previous experience with this game a few years ago but only now had the motivation to complete the story. The combat is fluent but can be repititive but still manages to stay satisfying, especially when using the batclaw for finishers and extended combos. Graphics are great for the time it was released and showed very little graphical errors (though some pixelation during the final cutscene). The riddler adds a lot of exploration and keeps your eyes open for anything and everything, not to mention spending a hell of a lot of time circling your camera around rooms in detective mode to find riddler trophies. The main plot had little depth but the riddler and the colectibles you gather than tell individual character stories are very promising for anyone who enjoys a thourough story. I'm yet to try any of the other modes but I can definitely recommend the game for its generally satisfying gameplay and interesting start to the Arkham game series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												The original and still the best in the series.It's more focused environment leads to a more tightly crafted game that just begs to be explored. While the later games in the series offer a more open ended approach with arguably more things to see and do, in practice they seem to offer little more than filler between heavily scripted events. While collectibles, secrets and side missions often feel like chores in the later games, they feel like meaningful reasons to fully explore the asylum with appropriate rewards on offer. Each area is filled with unique assets and small, rememberable details. The riddlers side missions task you with photographing scenes that are unique to various characters from the Dark Knight universe which helps to direct the player toward these specially crafted, and unique in-game assets.The combat system, while arguably too simplistic, is a delight to control as you see Batman stringing insane combo's together effortlessly disarming, and countering incoming attacks. Every kick, punch, grapple and counter is animated well making fights seem appropriately realistic and violent. The combat is assisted by some excellent audio leading to some satisfying crunches, cracks, and smacks as bones break and fists collide with faces.The metroid-vania aspects of the game are implemented well, with each upgrade offering the oppertunity to revisit locations throughout the game.The story is well told and the voice acting is excellent throughout, although I felt the final parts of the story were anticlimactic with the final boss fight in particular being tedius and frankly, rather silly. Seeing the Joker turn into a roid-raged meathead seemed rather out of character, and a little far-fetched - even for a comic book super villain.On a technical level, the game still looks great to this day and runs exceptionally well. A mid-range pc should be able to run this game on maximum settings with a solid 60fps.All-in-all it's a ground breaking game and in my opinion one of the best games of it's generation. A true masterpiece.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												After Spending 16 hours on the story mode (normal difficulty), I now think it would be a good idea to recommend this game.I'm just gona get down n'dirty here instead of talking mince :- Openworld type environment where the facilities on the island can be classed as "levels"- A nice blend of linear & non-linear level design so you are not left running about like a lost soul.- Game gradually ups the difficulty of the fight scenes.- Fight scenes seem to blend modern day gaming with the old arcade button-basher-combo type deal.- Plenty of opportunities to stealth it up if you are that way inclined.- Cool Story...- I am not a batman fan tbh, but now I have cravings for watching a batman movie or something.- Plenty of side challengers to keep you busy in tandem with storyline.- A little bit of dark humour from the bad guys.- Batman needs to lighten up abit :pI will defo be purchasing the other arkham games in the future when they are back on sale....afterall, I am a budget gamer :).

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Batman: Arkham Asylum needs no introduction. It won massive amount of awards including game of the year award. It simply shines in every single category. Graphic is dark and beautiful just like a real stealth game should have. GamePlay is fantastic, I can’t believe how good controls work on PC. I heard on few occasions that people complain to the lack of combat moves but with all the gadgets at your disposal I see no problem there. Story is great and entertaining throughout the whole game. The only thing I saw as a bummer was combat challenges which were a bit too much for my taste and made me frustrated on several occasions. But since that’s the only problem I see in this entire game I see no reason why you shouldn’t own this game on your PC. So go on and grab this 8/10.

content:
Posted: February 22
												This game started the entire Arkham series off with great style and flow! This game started a great time to be a Batman fan. The gameplay is amazing, the looks of the game back in the day were amazing and still hold up well now 7 years later! The story was also an amazing immersive world with loads of lore and backstory all over the place with collectibles challenges and more to try throughout Arkham Asylum. There was a lot of depth for the first outing as the caped crusader. He was brutal, calculated and smart giving a very large dynamic of things to do throughout the game. The biggest innovation was the combat system Rocksteady created, and they held up thsi combat system with small changes here and there to improve it and alter it slightly. The gameplay is changed up with the addition of gadgets that allow a whole different set of combo's for you to change up the gameplay with. The world is amazing, the detail is amazing and this game is amazing. Worth a buy!Tl;dr, amazing game, buy it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2012
												What is there to say about the famous Batman that has not already been said? Batman is my favorite hero, hands down. Maybe that makes me slightly biased in this review, but Batman: Arkham Asylum is exactly how a Batman game should be for long-time or even newly-born fans. I am not inclined to lie about him being a "super" hero, because he ultimately does not have super powers. His gadgets make him a super being, BUT he does not have super-human abilities, unlike his nemesises or other "super" heroes in likeness of Superman and whatnot. He drives a Batmobile; I mean, who does not love this guy? The two main parts about this game that stood out to me the most are not only the constant action throughout the entirety of the game (fighting mechanics, flying mechanics, and the like), but the Scarecrow and the Joker are what make this game what it is. Without spoiling the game for anyone who has not indulged in this experience yet, Scarecrow plays an epic part in this game; it is one of my favorite parts in gaming history. The Joker is hilarious; he kept me laughing consistently, which is a plus in any game. This game is stunning, graphics wise; the gameplay is absolutely one hundred pecent fun, one hundred percent of the time; the story-line is full of character, as there are an extensive amount of villians in it; basically, this game is perfection at its finest hour. Everything about it is exhilerating. Sometimes, more so than not, games are disappointing when they are hyped up, but this one is as pleasing as pie, unless you are into cake. It is not by any means a short game either, so if you enjoy a decent amount of gameplay, this is your match. You will not be disappointed, trust me! I have played over 1,000 + games, and this is one of my favorites.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												This game has been released for a long time and only at this time of my life I had the chance to play this game. And all I can say is "Let's get this party started!"Ding d-ding, dong! First of all, I really love the environment and the character models, specifically on their details. Voice acting is also great, especially Mark Hamill[www.imdb.com]. Profoundly speaking, the perfect voice actor for Joker – "He’s crazy, you know" – but the secondary characters and enemy henchmen have poor variety in voice-overs. Speaking of henchmen, with the freeflow combat system you can really ”Eat punks like these for breakfast.” You can seamlessly chain together unlimited combos not just with your barehands but with your “bat prefixed" gadgets as well. And speaking of gadgets, it’s pretty sweet if you will be able to utilize all of these in the game especially on solving the puzzles and of course with the help of the Detective Mode – I mean why wouldn’t Batman have a detective mode? He’s the WORLD’S GREATEST DETECTIVE! Plus to that, the hidden challenges and unlocking the secrets of Arkham Asylum really spice it up for Batman for being a detective. Another thing I also love is the silent takedowns – that pretty sums up Batman being the "Dark Knight" – and the convenience of hiding from the henchmen. They’ll just be surprised that you came out of nowhere and say, "That guy freaks me out.” Well, I finished the game on normal. I’ll have another go on hard and see if it will be more difficult for me to hide from the henchmen. And the last thing is about the boss fights. It’s pretty good they have some different variations. But somehow, for me, they kinda seem littler easier than the fights with the mobs LOL. Especially the final battle!All in all it’s a 9/10! See you in Arkham City, Bats!


Arkham Asylum 
A Screenshot of Batman: Arkham Asylum GOTY Edition

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												Superheroes have had issues with past video games, often being inaccurately portrayed or having  glitchy gameplay (I'm looking at you Superman 64). Thankfully though, this game isn't one of them. You've probably already heard all of the praises being sung over the Batman: Arkham series, so I'll keep this short: This game is amazing. Wonderful gameplay, fast-flowing action, a bunch of wacky characters to match wits against and enough challenges to keep you busy for quite a while. Oh, and you get to play as Batman of course.The game consists of Joker taking over Arkham Asylum and Batman having to stop him, battling inmates, rescuing guards and sneaking around taking down thugs in the most Batman ways possible.Just as the Dark Knight Trilogy defined Batman on film, the Arkham series defined Batman in games, setting a standard to which all future superhero games should aspire to.BE THE BATMAN ;)

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												Amazing game. Anything you read online about this game being one of the best is true. But, I strongly recommend you play this installment of the Arkham series before any other, because the games only get better.Combat: Depending on the hardware you are running, it can be anywhere from erratic and choppy to fluid. If you can hold a steady 30 frames, then you can really appreciate the combat. Upgrades give you more options in how you take down thugs, and boss fights are challenging and rewarding.Stealth: Stealth missions really require you to stop and think about how you want to handle a room. Be wary of line of sight as well, because if you can see them, they can see you. Note: Not as refined as the next titles in the Arkham series.Environment: Everything looks and feels like a true Batman story. The environment is dirty and gritty, and you know you're Arkham just by looking around. It's a nice mix of high-security technology and Gothic architecture.Do recommend, 10/10

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Very Good Game.I liked the combat system, it's fun kicking♥♥♥♥♥as batman while getting very high combos.Only thing i didn't like was the "Counter" didn't work all the time.I right click right when i'm told, and it wouldn't counter the enemies, constantly causing me to die many times.I tried at different times when it appeared, and it didn't matter, it still failed.Now getting to the positives. + Mark Hamill as the Joker was VERY WELL Done. + Person that did Batman's Voice was also good. + The Story was pretty good, good pacing, and didn't seem to get "too over the top". + Story was also a pretty decent length, which is good. I hate very short campaigns in games. + The game has PLENTY of side things to do, such as all the Riddler Trophies, as well as other things. + Game has a good mix of easy and challenging moments as you progress through the game. + Fun to take out very big groups of enemies while getting very high combos. + Many different Gadgets Batman has, which can be upgraded as you progress through the story. + Scarecrow's trolling "fake game crash" made me laugh.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2013
												Batman Arkham Asylum is an action\adventure "super hero" game.So after many average and horrible batman games is Batman Arkham Asylumworth trying ? well I can answer your question right away.You start the game when batman caught the most famous villian the Jokerand sents him back to prison ( Arkham Asylum ) where he should be belong,even though the guards should be able to do the rest, batman sense that something isn't quite right and that he should keep his eye on Joker after all Joker gave up so easily almost without a fight. After what it seems that the Joker well be sent to his place, Joker escaped killing the guards in his way and somehow controlling all the asylum in a blink of an eye. Now it up to batman to stop Joker and find out what was Joker's planning all this time.Gameplay : the combat is great and fluid almost perfect, it combines stealth approach, puzzles and riddles and of course brute force. This is the first game that will make you feel that you are the batman that you are in cotrol of your gadgets, fighting style and detective's skills.I can rest assure you that Batman Arkham Asylum gameplay is one of the best there is to offer.Story : its been a long time since I was so interested in a game's storyline,the cutscenes\dialog\twists are just great. You will be suprised and thrilled by what will come next, also lets not forget about the characters which all of them are amazingly done. Graphics : What can I say ? beautiful,amazing,outstanding and perfectly fit to the batman's art style. One of the best I have seen in 2009 and even today its just plain impressive.AI + difficulty : this is where I think that Batman Arkham Asylum could be better,while the game has diffrent enemies and every boss fight is unique, still the gameis too damn easy even on the hard difficulty, only the challenges gives the feeling that I might actually lose.Music + Sound : I can't say too much cause the only thing that comes in my mind is the word "Perfection" Summary : Batman Arkham Asylum trully deserves the "Game of the year" title of 2009, one of the most suprising,impressive and outstanding games there is to offer and God help those who didn't play the game yet. The only thing that bothers me was the difficulty which was too easy for me, but overall I'll give this game a 9.5\10

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												In a word: playable.Don't get me wrong, I did enjoy this game, but it didn't wow me the way I expected it to. After years of hearing praise for the story, combat system, etc, I decided to give it a try, but I'd say it's only about 40% fun and 60% frustration.Pros:-Decent graphics that still hold up 7 years later.-Good looking designs for Batman's rogues gallery, especially Joker who, looking more like the classic version, was a welcome change from the now stagnant Heath Ledger version everyone was obsessed with at the time.-Believable story (even with the body sized ventilation shafts and conveniently placed gargoyles).-Hearing the voice actors from Batman: TAS was pretty cool.-Cool gadgetsCons:-Navigation was a royal pain. I had to constantly check the map to see where I was going, and backtrack every 5 minutes.-The Riddler challenge is a distracting side quest that I ultimately gave up on.-The fighting mechanics gave me a headache. Countering only worked half the time, and it would constantly go into slow motion, which is hard to control. To be fair, it did set the standard for other combat styles, such as Shadow of Mordor, which requires a bit of strategy but actually works if you know what you're doing. Here, I basically just spend the whole fight clicking and mashing the spacebar, because I'm not in control at all.Overall, I did enjoy it, but I would not put it in my top 5.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												If you haven't played this yet you're missing out on something special.3D brawler gameplay that actually works combined with the genuine sensation that you ARE the Batman.  It's got all the qualities we've come to know and love the Dark Knight's ongoing mythology for, with a decent roster of Gotham's criminally insane lining up to take their shot at the Bat.  The story is beefed up with an excellent script and voice acting fit for the ages.  Mark Hamill's out-of-the-box psychotic Joker brings a wry smile to your face with every one-liner.Arkham Asylum's gameplay is semi-immersed in stealth.  Enemies who are armed with guns are dangerous if faced directly, so the game teaches you how to move around and take out foes one by one.  Difficulty is scaled up with the acquisition of more gadgets, so adaptation of new techniques becomes paramount to Batman's survival - as it should be.A special mention is deserved for the game's audio and visual presentation which pump a gritty, suspenseful atmosphere into  the experience.  Arkham Asylum could have easily faultered on these qualities, but it doesn't.    There is really no excuse for you not to have played Arkham Asylum.  Nobody expected it to do what it does with such grace and respect for its source material.  Just buy the bloody thing and play it if you haven't already; you'll soon realise what all the fuss is about.

												Batman Arkham Asylum is one reason why I like the superhero genre games. The reason being that is that you play as the Dark Knight himself and using his gadgets. The synopsis of the game is Batman captures The Joker and brings him to Arkham Asylum to be kept there, but all along it was a trap as Joker wants to takeover the Asylum for himself. The Joker escapes from his captivity and is on the loose. Now the Greatest Detective has solve this problem by trying to find the Joker within Arkham Asylum and ask him what he really want to do.  The gameplay is amazing with features like Detective Mode which makes you see everything in X-Ray vision but it useful to see if there is any of Joker's Thugs is in the room. The abillty to use the batarang is amazing and to use the Batclaw which can bring down walls. Overall I think that this game is worth a buy if you are a Batman fan or if you like stealth and beat'em up genres.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
Batman: Arkham Asylum really stands out as one of the best superhero video games out there (another one being its sequel, Arkham City, but more about that in another review). The gameplay is rock-solid in a Metroidvania-esque fashion, the voice-over work is fantastic with many classic voices returning (like Mark Hamill as the Joker and Kevin Conroy as the Dark Knight himself), and the story is well-written and satisfying for the most part.The whole game takes place on Arkham Island, where the Joker has gained control over the titular insane asylum. The location is really atmospheric and is a very believable setting for a Batman story, in a little contrast to the setting in Arkham City which had a little more creative freedom applied to it (again, more on that in the future).The main story is a bit on the short side, but combined with the Riddler challenges and the combat/predator challenges, it will keep you busy for a good 20-25 hours for 100% completion. Not too shabby.It isn't possible to review Arkham Asylum and not mention the simple, yet satisfying freeflow -combat system. It takes little skill to beat up the bad guys, but racking up massive combos takes some work and is very enjoyable. What's even more pleasing than beating them up directly is the stealth, or "predator" sections, where you use your environment to your advantage and take out your enemies without being seen.You might enjoy this game even if you don't like Batman. Under the Batman -shell is a rock-solid game that is without question worth picking up. Who knows? Maybe you'll start to like the series after playing this?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												A good plot, interesting villains and of course the ability to beat the living daylights out of various thugs while proclaiming "I'M BATMAN!" What more could you want? A gun that shoots shuriken and lightning? Don't be absurd, you know Batman's rules...If this is your first foray into the Batman Universe beyond the Christopher Nolan films, you might find this Batman and his villains to be less "gritty" and "realistic". However, if you even consider this to be a flaw, you'll soon forget about your gripes as the writing and voice-acting draws you in and makes you forget that there ever could be a different Batman.The main storyline is top notch and the various collectible items side quests keep you playing well beyond beating up a Titan-enhanced Joker with explosive fists .Overall a well-crafted, immersive game.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2011
												Being a fan of Bruce Tim animations, open worlds and upgrade collection, Arkham Asylum scratched an itch.  This is one instance where a license appears to have been handled correctly with a competent product.  Hearing the old cast, wielding Batman's arsenal and using stealth to take down enemies were all immensely satisfying.However, I had two problems with the game:1) Arkham Asylum traps the player inside boss battles.  Want to explore and upgrade?  Tough.  The game decided to autosave.  You're stuck playing a frustrating minigame with questionable resemblance to normal combat.2) Enemies don't respawn.  When solving riddles, this is good for decreasing travel time.  However, I didn't learn the bulk of the combat basics until the final battle.  I focused on stealth, rarely counterattacked and made it through with a low combo count.  By the time more advanced techniques were necessary, I had removed every opportunity to experiment from the story.  Practice in the challenges.

												I had purchased this a LONG time ago and let it sit around while I was playing other things. I've really regret doing that. This is such an amazingly fantastic game that you will not want to put it down.The voice acting is second to none, you got the stellar Kevin Conroy (whom you may know from the Justice League / Unlimited cartoons) voicing Batman, and Mark Hamill as the Joker as the main protagonist and antagonist. Harley Quinn also makes an appearance in an outfit you won't soon forget, as well as a number of other key Batman villains with varying purposes and roles.The combat system is immensely satisfying, as you level your character up, you gain more techniques to use against enemies (whom you can fight upwards of 8-13 in some instances) and they are all quite useful once you get them into your routine.I cannot recommend this game highly enough, what an amazing Batman game this turned out to be!

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Still the best Batman game in the Arkham series and probably the best Batman game ever made. The story involves Batman catching Joker easily after a recent robbery and, coincidentally, Joker's gang moved to the Asylum because of an issue at the Blackgate Prison - once inside the Asylum, the Joker escapes and taskes control of the Asylum and prepares to unearth something far worse than what you initially suspect. You play as Batman trying to unearth this plot and once again stop the Joker.To this day, this game still has amazing visuals, Batman himself covering around half the screen, looks the part and stands strong and confident as the character should as well as the texture work on his suit are top notch - the rest of the game fairs the same, since the game has been given an outstanding amount of care and work into every area you go through. Not one area in the game feels exactly the same as another even if they look similar. Very stellar work of textures all around overall.I don't say this is the best Batman game out there for no reason - gameplay is pretty basic "Brawler" style with very minor puzzle solving, but what makes this game different, from, say a game like Assassin's Creed - is the "Free Flow combat system" the game has. The combat is slightly similar to the first Assassin's Creed, except - the flow combat system allows Batman to basically jump from one foe to another in a very fast manner, almost rythmically, to get a combo counter to go as high as you can while still making it challenging by giving the foes still standing a fighting chance and implementing counters. You can also explore the entirety of the Arkham Asylum as you unlock areas and you can do a variety of things while exploring, you can face groups of enemies scattered around, you can do Riddler Challenges - whom are a bunch of mini puzzles scattered around the Asylum that involves the use of Batman's Detective Mode, these range from finding a specific item found in the area or marks that require the Detective Mode to find and a "Complete the Mark" type of game that involves you scanning the area from specific places to complete a full mark, etc - Riddler trophies, and a bunch of case files to find out more background information on Batman characters and villains (as well as the history behind Arkahm Asylum) that are often very well realized and fun to hear. The Detective Mode & Gadgets: You'll be using these a LOT on your trudge through Arkham Asylum. Ranging from the standard Batarangs and Grappling hook (used for mundane objectives such as getting to and pulling out vents from hard to reach places, etc), the Explosive Gel (Used a lot to surprise enemies, to find weak walls to find trophies and secrets and to progress in the story as well!) and a bunch more. The Detecive Mode helps you analyze weak walls to use your Explosive Gel on and other gadgets as well as analyze enemy/allies conditions and, more important later on in the game, to find out which enemies carry weapons or are special enemies.).So in general, if you ever wanted to know and feel what a life in the day of Batman is, this is definately your game, more so than the sequels (imo). From the excellent assets and sound to follow it up with, and the pitch perfect gameplay to go along with it, this sits as one of my favourite video game experiences and currently my best experience playing as the legendary Dark Knight.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
REVIEW: BATMAN: ARKHAM ASYLUMAs I have mentioned in my review of Portal 2, I am behind the times when it comes to the latest games, and one of the many games on my ‘to-play’ list was Batman: Arkham Asylum. Finding it cheap in a store was great, as it meant that I could finally give it a go. But would I find it any good?In Batman: Arkham Asylum, Batman has caught the Joker (again), but, suspicious at the ease at which the Clown Prince of Crime allowed himself to be captured, Batman decides to escort the Joker to his cell. Unfortunately, the Joker was counting on this. Not only was he planning on being caught and returned to Arkham Asylum, but he planned on Batman being there as well. Batman must fight his way through the asylum, confronting some of his most persistent adversaries, from Bane to Poison Ivy. But what is the Joker after? What is Titan? And can Batman stop the Joker’s plans?While I’m not that big a fan of the Batman comics in particular, I have read many of the graphic novels, including one that seems to be an inspiration for this game: Arkham Asylum: A Serious House on Serious Earth. That was an intelligent but harrowing mind-screw of a book that clearly inspired more than a few elements. The story, while not at complex epic levels, is good for what it is: a comic book story transferred to a computer game. I’m surprised that, given how Paul Dini (of the serious but still kid-oriented animated series) wrote it, how adult the game seems. Which goes to show my ignorance. Graphics-wise, the game is beautiful. I am sure that there are more games out there that look better (including Arkham Asylum’s direct sequel, Arkham City, which I am currently playing), but I am not a person who wants their game’s graphics to be ultra-realistic, as long as the graphical style is enjoyable, and that it is. The character design, for the most part, is actually quite excellent, though I am a little bemused at the rather fetishized appearances of Harley Quinn and Poison Ivy, even compared to their comic book versions.Sound-wise, it is quite immersive and atmospheric. The voice acting is enjoyable, with particular, if predictable, praise going to Mark Hamill as the Joker. I know him more as Luke Skywalker, so to hear him play the Joker is a revelation. The sound effects all work, and the music helps give an edge of dread, without it missing the Elfman/Zimmer edge of the Batman atmosphere.Gameplay wise, the game is somewhat mixed, although this is partly because this game was developed first and foremost as a console game rather than a PC game. I played on easy simply because of an apprehension I had about the control scheme, and I still found the game challenging, partly because I used a keyboard and mouse as opposed to a controller. That being said, the combat is enjoyable, if a little repetitive, and the Predator Sequences (sequences where one must attack stealthily) are challenging, but in a mostly good way. The gadgets all lend not only to the gameplay, but to the feeling that one is actually Batman. There’s even a few sequences where the World’s Greatest Detective (as Batman is hyped as) actually does some detecting. The sidequests of the Riddler Challenges are actually quite enjoyable and taxing, and nothing beats that little thrill of satisfaction when you beat one of them, and while Riddler accuses you of looking them up on the internet, you actually just found almost all the solutions on your own. My only real complaint, other than the control scheme, is that, even with the Riddler Challenges, the game was over rather swiftly.Overall, Batman: Arkham Asylum is an enjoyable game that is really how Batman should be played. Flawed, but still enjoyable and highly recommended.RATING: ****

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
Soviet's Fast ReviewsVisuals+ Graphics look smooth and have decent amount of texture detail+ Animations of characters and combat are fluid and look organic- Certain areas have flat textures- The game is often too dark and some things blend into each otherGameplay+ Controls feel solid and performing combo moves is fairly easy+ Glide mechanic and gadgets are fun to use and feel solid- Some of the voice acting feels stiff and doesn't really fit the situation at certain moments- Missions are all over the place and can be tedious to run between buildingsOverallBatman Arkham Asylum throws you right into the eyes of Bruce Wayne/Batman as he transports the Joker to the criminal institution known as Arkham Asylum. The story is quite rich and introduces various characters from the comic books as well as some pretty cool features like the Detective Mode which lets you see the enemies through walls, items hidden in cracks, and switches to activate. Combat is smooth, though the limited combo list can make the constant fight sequences seem a bit tedious. Despite its age and the launch of other sequels, Arkham Asylum is still very fun to play and the story is definitely one of the best of any franchise to date. If you're looking for a great superhero title, check Arkham Asylum on your list of games to purchase.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												Batman Arkham Asylum is an amazing, third person, action game. The gameplay is very fluent and fun once you get the hang of it, and I have absolutely no complaints about that. The gameplay is probably my favorite part about this game, the story on the other hand was interesting as well. The story seems to reflect the way the old Batman comics used to be, and definitely feels like a Batman story, which is good. Overall, the game is definitely worth the money and is loaded with hours of beating up criminals and grappling around the place. It did not feel very repetitive at all, in fact, it did a lot of things right to make sure you enjoy the game such as little hidden unlockables, different enemy types and environments, and fun bosses. Pick this game up right now if you can, or wait until a sale because it goes on sale pretty often.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												This is still today one of the best games i have ever played. This game proved that a comic book based videogame can be great, instead of a lot of movie tied videogames that tend to suck. It has a mix of classic and modern gameplay, that blends together well. You start the game by bringing Joker again to Arkham Asylum, but soon he breaks free and takes control of the entire island. The story in this game is superbly written, and the villains fantastic, like Scarecrow with fear gas, Poison Ivy with plants, and of course Joker, the main villain star. The gameplay is breaked into 3 types: exploration, where you progress through the asylum, discover new places, enjoy the graphics, relax, and find collectibles and solves riddles, with plenty of easter eggs. But not everything can be collected right away, you'll need to obtain new gadgets and come back later. The combat is simple and fluid, using a button to attack and another to counter mainly, with a few more tricks. But the enemies aren't varied, with only 2 or 3 that will require another tactic, and a mini-boss that's very recicled. Lastly there's the stealth sections, where you must plan and take down Joker goons in a room without being detected. It sounds cool, but it's more random than i would like. It's still enjoyable though. In the end, this isn't exactly an open world game, but more of a linear, focused story that works very well here, although it's a bit short. But after finishing the story and collecting everything, there's still the challenge mode, where you will face some combat challenges where you need to keep a combo to earn a high score, or face some stealth sections where you must take down Joker goons with some extra requirements. This challenges are harder than the story mode, but still doable. This game is a must buy on sale, but the game have crashed 2 times and there's a bug where the game exits if your internet connection gets cut off. This last one is annoying, because you will lose progress, and get frustrated. While this game no longer has DRM other than Steam, it seems that some code is still unintendedly present. But despite that it's still a great game, and while the core mechanics are much improved in Batman Arkham City, this one has the best story and villains, because it's more focused.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												With Batman being back in the film news I finally got the inspiration to start going through the Batman games. First on the list is Arkham Asylum, which is now over 5 years old. The good news is, the game didn't feel old at all. Looks and runs great!The game takes place in the island of Arkham Asylum where Joker and his mischievous friends escape and it's up to you to put an end to his plans. Featuring the original "arkham style combat" that is now a coined phrase for games like Shadow of Mordor, it plays well and is challenging enough to keep it interesting while providing some fun tools to experiment with.I do have a few complaints towards the options system. You can only edit your keys before starting the game and there is no option to edit mouse sensitivity. You have to go tweak some config files to change the sensitivity values around which is rather slow to finetune.Batman Arkham Asylum is a good game that functions well as an introduction to the series. It provides a fun and dark playground to mess around in. There's a good chunk of the core gameplay but also a bunch of collectibles and optional content that can keep you going longer if you so desire. Definitely checking out Arkham City next!Beat the game in 12 hours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2012
												What is there to say about the famous Batman that has not already been said? Batman is my favorite hero, hands down. Maybe that makes me slightly biased in this review, but Batman: Arkham Asylum is exactly how a Batman game should be for long-time or even newly-born fans. I am not inclined to lie about him being a "super" hero, because he ultimately does not have super powers. His gadgets make him a super being, BUT he does not have super-human abilities, unlike his nemesises or other "super" heroes in likeness of Superman and whatnot. He drives a Batmobile; I mean, who does not love this guy? The two main parts about this game that stood out to me the most are not only the constant action throughout the entirety of the game (fighting mechanics, flying mechanics, and the like), but the Scarecrow and the Joker are what make this game what it is. Without spoiling the game for anyone who has not indulged in this experience yet, Scarecrow plays an epic part in this game; it is one of my favorite parts in gaming history. The Joker is hilarious; he kept me laughing consistently, which is a plus in any game. This game is stunning, graphics wise; the gameplay is absolutely one hundred pecent fun, one hundred percent of the time; the story-line is full of character, as there are an extensive amount of villians in it; basically, this game is perfection at its finest hour. Everything about it is exhilerating. Sometimes, more so than not, games are disappointing when they are hyped up, but this one is as pleasing as pie, unless you are into cake. It is not by any means a short game either, so if you enjoy a decent amount of gameplay, this is your match. You will not be disappointed, trust me! I have played over 1,000 + games, and this is one of my favorites.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												This game has been released for a long time and only at this time of my life I had the chance to play this game. And all I can say is "Let's get this party started!"Ding d-ding, dong! First of all, I really love the environment and the character models, specifically on their details. Voice acting is also great, especially Mark Hamill[www.imdb.com]. Profoundly speaking, the perfect voice actor for Joker – "He’s crazy, you know" – but the secondary characters and enemy henchmen have poor variety in voice-overs. Speaking of henchmen, with the freeflow combat system you can really ”Eat punks like these for breakfast.” You can seamlessly chain together unlimited combos not just with your barehands but with your “bat prefixed" gadgets as well. And speaking of gadgets, it’s pretty sweet if you will be able to utilize all of these in the game especially on solving the puzzles and of course with the help of the Detective Mode – I mean why wouldn’t Batman have a detective mode? He’s the WORLD’S GREATEST DETECTIVE! Plus to that, the hidden challenges and unlocking the secrets of Arkham Asylum really spice it up for Batman for being a detective. Another thing I also love is the silent takedowns – that pretty sums up Batman being the "Dark Knight" – and the convenience of hiding from the henchmen. They’ll just be surprised that you came out of nowhere and say, "That guy freaks me out.” Well, I finished the game on normal. I’ll have another go on hard and see if it will be more difficult for me to hide from the henchmen. And the last thing is about the boss fights. It’s pretty good they have some different variations. But somehow, for me, they kinda seem littler easier than the fights with the mobs LOL. Especially the final battle!All in all it’s a 9/10! See you in Arkham City, Bats!


Arkham Asylum 
A Screenshot of Batman: Arkham Asylum GOTY Edition
By: Zeb

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												After playing this on console quite a lot, and being a big Batman and DC fan, I decided to buy this for PC.It captures Batman as for what he really is; a badass hardened by traumatic experiences and many close death encounters.The story is executed to a very good standard, encorporating a lot of the classic Batman villians such as the Joker (of course), Harley Quinn, Killer Croc, Scarecrow etc. It is also a rather simple story to understand as it features a standard plot to take over Gotham brought up the Joker, but in a way that truly shows off his evil genius.The combat is rather fluid, if not unimpressive but it works. You have the basic combo chaining attacks with an element of counters.The lack of some iconic characters such as Two-Face, Mr. Freeze and The Penguin allows the game to immersify the player into the other characters a lot more; making it feel not so crowded.Graphics are superb, with near to no lag found within my first few hours of playing, even when loading into the main island.There is an element of search and explore aspect, as you look to find certain Riddler Trophies as part of a sidequest to accompany the main story. There's also a stealth aspect as you look to avoid armed minions who can deal fatal damage, thus you have to intelligently pick your moment to take them out from above.The voice acting and audio in general is rather brilliant, with many voice actors reprising their roles from some of the older cartoons.The tone of the story is rather adult, as it should be for a Batman game. Featuring traumatic situations and murder.All in all, this is a good game I'd seriously recommend whether you're a Batman fan or not.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												I know I'm very late posting this review, but I'm going to do it anyway.TL;DR:Pros:- Smooth combat system (choice of beat-em-up or stealth)- Be the Batman. Use his gadgets.- Learn more Batman lore than you knew existed- Engaging and new plot- Dynamic Dialogue- Appealing art style and graphicsCons:- Controls on Mac were a little hard to get used to, but you can change your keyboard bindings, and I believe you also have the option of playing with a gamepad.Breezy's full review: Batman: Arkham Asylum is hands down the best video game based on a comic that I've ever played and one of the best games overall in my collection. I remember playing the demo at my local GameStop and being sort of skeptical as it just seemed like another beat-em-up. Flash forward to about 5 years later and I'm so glad that I was wrong.    The story is refreshing and encapsulating. The dialogue is great (a lot of times humorous, a lot of times epic, only sometimes corny). Like everyone else says, the combat system is the most fluid I've seen in a video game, though I much prefer the "Predator" style of combat (taking out enemies stealthily) in the game. Being the Batman and getting to use all his gadgets (Batclaw, Detective Mode, explosive gel, batarang (in the form of the normal, multiple, explosive, and remote controlled)), and appearances by both the Batmobile and the Batwing were definitely a treat.   I honestly have to say that the Riddler trophies were my favorite part of the game. When the trophies were first introduced in the game I really had no intention of collecting all 240 of them. But the developers did something very clever and linked character backgrounds to most of the trophies. Some of the trophies take the form of interview tapes with Arkham inmates, Chronicles of Arkham (cryptic messages left by Amadeus Arkham to be found and deciphered), or simply scanning the environment as a visual answer to one of the Riddler's riddles. Of course, there are actual trophies you can find, but I much prefered the ones that would provide some background on the characters. Before this game, I had minimal knowledge of the Batman universe. When I discovered that the trophies could actually unlock character bios (and some nice viewable character trophies), I became obsessed with finding them. Through the character bios and other various forms of the trophies, I became educated on more of the Batman universe than I thought I would want to know. But don't get me wrong, every detail about a character or asset in the Batman world interested more than the last.   Actual gameplay wise, I probably beat it in about 12-13 hours. However, as you can see from my hours played, I spent a lot more time in the game than that. What was I doing? Collecting trophies, of course. Also, I spent several hours in the challenge maps where you rack up points by seeing how long of a combo you can get on enemies or you complete predator challenges, where you must knock out enemies in a specific way (i.e. break through a glass ceiling to take out an enemy). The GOTY Edition DLC  offers you the choice of playing as the Joker in these challenge maps, and it's pretty awesome and a nice change of pace from playing as Batman. End note:My only real prior knowledge of Batman came after Christopher Nolan's Dark Knight Trilogy and that was about the extent of it (besides watching a few episodes of the animated series growing up). The movies were great, expecially the Dark Knight, but they didn't really expand on the Batman universe, but instead focused on dark realism. This game, however, seemed to capture the wonder and atmosphere of the Batman comics and various animated series. I guess you could say that Batman has gained a Batfan. Thanks for reading.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												Superheroes have had issues with past video games, often being inaccurately portrayed or having  glitchy gameplay (I'm looking at you Superman 64). Thankfully though, this game isn't one of them. You've probably already heard all of the praises being sung over the Batman: Arkham series, so I'll keep this short: This game is amazing. Wonderful gameplay, fast-flowing action, a bunch of wacky characters to match wits against and enough challenges to keep you busy for quite a while. Oh, and you get to play as Batman of course.The game consists of Joker taking over Arkham Asylum and Batman having to stop him, battling inmates, rescuing guards and sneaking around taking down thugs in the most Batman ways possible.Just as the Dark Knight Trilogy defined Batman on film, the Arkham series defined Batman in games, setting a standard to which all future superhero games should aspire to.BE THE BATMAN ;)

I’ll have another go on hard and see if it will be more difficult for me to hide from the henchmen. And the last thing is about the boss fights. It’s pretty good they have some different variations. But somehow, for me, they kinda seem littler easier than the fights with the mobs LOL. Especially the final battle!All in all it’s a 9/10! See you in Arkham City, Bats!

												Batman Arkham Asylum is an amazing, third person, action game. The gameplay is very fluent and fun once you get the hang of it, and I have absolutely no complaints about that. The gameplay is probably my favorite part about this game, the story on the other hand was interesting as well. The story seems to reflect the way the old Batman comics used to be, and definitely feels like a Batman story, which is good. Overall, the game is definitely worth the money and is loaded with hours of beating up criminals and grappling around the place. Pick this game up right now if you can, or wait until a sale because it goes on sale pretty often.

												Arkham's magnum opus (so far). Recognise but put aside the crisp combat and the fascinating villains. Making the setting a small, secluded island was the best decision they made. This linear approach meant they could make Batman the focal point rather than the world around him. The game simply made you feel like Batman with an agenda through its straightforwardness. Being devoid of trivial distractions like overly elaborate riddler challenges, ringing phone chases, frustrating AR training and silly ballon hunting only aided the game. Less is more in this instance. The definitive comic book superhero game.

												The first in a great series This is the first of the Arkham sereis and it started a great game series that I enoyed all the way through. This is my least favorite of the 3 games I have palyed, but maybe that will change after I play Arham knight. who knows. This dose not mean that the game is bad, but it is the least original, in terms of story, and for me the story is one of the must important  thing for these games.The game is a exploration and fighting game, based in the batman universe. The good thing about this, is all of the vilans you get to see, since this game takes place inside Arkham Asylum witch is not really a prison but more like a psycority place, that will help bad guys to become good guys. The gameplay is split up into three major parts. There is the fighting part, witch is played out by using the right mouse button to hit a person, the right mouse button to counter, and the middle mouse button to confuse, you aim at a person by using the mouse, and you have to be fast to counter and hit, without getting hit youself. Along the game the enemyes get harder, and there must be used new tacktics to defeat them. You will also get more items along the way whitch will help you in combat.There is a part I don`t get with that logic. Along the way, Batman pics up equpment that he finds useful, but I raise the qeustion; whoulden`t it be better if you brang along your awesome gear to begin with? He gose through so many areas, where these items whould have helpt along the way, but they do this so you of couse can`t unlock everything right away.The secound game fetures is stealth, where you must use stealth, in order to take care of heavy eqeupt enemyes. Here you have to be patiencent and plan your strategie in order to not get spotted.The last part are some puzzels that the Riddler have scattered throughout Arkham. This is the best Riddler challenge acourding to me, and they are very cleaver made.The music in this game is very glomy and it`s good at setting the mood of this dark and dangourus palce. There are also challenges you can do outside of the main game, that can be fun to do now and again. The story is the best part of this game, after Batman captiers the Joker, the Joker escapes and make Arhkam run amok. This is a plan that the Joker have planed all along, whitch you will discover if you paly the game. Along the way, you are going to meet iconic Batman villans such as Bain, Killer Crock, Poison Ivy and Harly Quen. The most iconic boss to me was Scarecrow. that made you trip out and experince a wiered nightmare senario that made for some awseome scenes for the game.If you explore some of the Riddler chalenges, you get to know the story of a lot of diffrent Batman charecters, whitch is really cool.This game is really good, thumps up. 7 out of 10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2013
												The gaming world was a different place before Arkham Asylum.  We had wanted a hero, a villain, nay anybody whose shoes we could step into and viscerally and believably beat the living crap outta people and feel like Jackie Chan.  Until Batman Arkham Asylum arrived, we didn't know just how badly we had been missing a game that could make you feel like billy big ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and boy did it deliver.  Gaming brawlers had come a long way since Streets of Rage and now they would never be the same again.  Indeed, this style of combat system has become the norm for 3rd person melee combat RPGs but not all manage to recreate the fluidity and satisfying perfection of Rocksteady's design.In my eyes, the combat is what makes this game.  Its freeflow design is so tactile, responsive and has fantastic, bone crunching feedback that it feels unbelievably satisfying.  With such a simple set of inputs (at least initially), the game encourages you to perfect timings and combos rather than simple button mashing, and the skill and complexity only rises as the Batman acquires more gadgets and skills himself.  The combat system is so well honed and refined that by the end of the game, a skilled player can launch feet first into a large group of henchmen and seamlessly take every last man down with well over 10 distinctly different moves, a variety of gadgets, dodges, blocks, stuns, jumps, kicks, punches, throws and numerous other martial art moves, all tied together into a 50 move combo without ever taking a single hit.  The end result is simply stunning to watch and pure joy incarnate to execute yourself.  To top it off, the skill balance is just about perfect as to do something like this is neither unrewardingly simplistic or frustratingly impossible.  Admittedly there is the very rare moment when the Batman doesn't mercilessly assault the particular henchman you intended him to and it throws off your combo as you try desperately to think ahead to the next limb mangling move, but this is so rare as to be no more than a petty annoyance.  The one thing I'm not so sure about though is that the Batman only seems to knock the goons out.  Now I've cracked some skulls as the Batman and I'm sure it's been well beyond the stresses and forces the human body can take, no matter how muscle bound the henchmen may be.  I'm pretty sure the Batman kills some people here.But Batman is so much more than the combat even though the game could probably stand up on its jaw crunching merits alone.  The other set of mechanics that play so perfectly into the theme and gameplay of Arkham Asylum is the Batman's ability for stealth and this really does enable you to approach situations in a variety of ways and is particularly great at enabling the Batman to take down enemies unawares or launch into combat with the element of surprise at hand.  Similarly to the combat, the Batman gains gadgets and skills that enable more advanced stealth techniques and takedowns and again enable the player to develop some quite complicated and nuanced tactics.  Combine these skills with the combat and here you have the perfect marriage of mechanics that makes you feel like the Batman more so than the vast majority of games make you feel like the intended protagonist.  That feeling of swinging from gargoyle to gargoyle before gliding down, batcape unfurled, onto a completely unsuspecting group of goons and perfectly beating them up in a flawless combo is quite simply, unmatched.Additionally, Arkham Asylum is a deep dive into who is, in my humble opinion, the greatest and most interesting super hero going, with a ton of lore and atmosphere that really makes you feel like you're not just the Batman but you really are walking through his world.  The plot is fantastic, although arguably shoe horns so many Batman villains into one place that it feels a little too dense at times but even this plays well into the compact setting of Arkham Asylum and the wider plot.  Overall, the presentation and content is outstanding with even the little extras, that are commonplace in free roam worlds, forming an interesting addition to the game and provide a view into Batman lore.  You can either take it or leave it, but at least it's not pointless fluff like so many other games seemingly have with audio logs that add sod all to the story or atmosphere.  These really do add a little bit of extra detail which as a Batman fan, I genuinely enjoyed.  Finally, it's the little details that I really noticed on my second playthrough on PC that just made me fall in love with the game again.  The wear and tear to the batsuit and the Batman himself as the night at Arkham progresses, and the five o' clock shadow that develops through the night just cements that feeling of immersion this game achieves so well and really makes you feel you're battling through a protracted nightmare of the Joker's design.A particular highlight for me is the voice acting which is just outstanding and not since Metal Gear 1 with David Hayter's rough, gravelly Solid Snake have I been so enamoured with the voice behind the mask.  Kevin Conroy as the Batman hits the nail on the head, returning to the glorious Michael Keaton style of Batman; unassuming, suave and charming richboy in a batsuit.  Arleen Sorkin is great as Harley Quinn, Wally Wingert pulls off a toned down Jim Carey style Riddler which I think strikes a great balance, and Dino Andrade as The Scarecrow is utterly menacing, matching his sinister presence in the game perfectly.  Perhaps Tom Hardy's Bane would have been the icing on the cake but the star performance undoubtedly goes to the legendary Mark Hamill of the Joker who plays him perfectly and creates a really interesting counterpoint to the Batman and helps deliver the whole game.I'm yet to play the remastered edition but rest assured, I certainly will and I'm looking forward to what will be my third playthrough.  This will undoubtedly go down as a classic of its generation and a mechanic defining game to boot.This review is from my website:  https://wingedtankard.wordpress.com/2017/04/03/batman-arkham-asylum/

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												There are alot of things I like about this game, and may I don't. Let me go into a little more detail.What does it for me in this game is that it has the perfect atmosphere for a Batman game. It's dark, gritty, relistic, disturbing, etc. In other words, it is everything that a Batman story should be. Everything from the voice actors, to character design, to art style, it all perfectly encapsulates what I think of when I hear the word "Batman" or sit down to watch/play something related to the Dark Knight. Where this game really frustrated me, though, was the actual gameplay mechanics themselves. I have many gripes with it. I will organize my complaints into neat sections here.I felt the gadgets were rather lacking. There are only 5 main ones with others that you can get by buying special upgrades. However, they're all related to movement, mostly. First of all, you get the batarangs. The problem with them is that they suck. They can't be used to take down an enemy, only stun them for half a second, which isn't enough time to take enemies down before they recover and shoot you to death. It would have been much more fun to throw the batarangs like B-man does in the tv shows and movies: disarming henchmen or flat out knocking them out. Obviously this would make the game too easy because the batarangs are infinite, but an easy fix would have been to make the 'rangs limited in quanitity, and you pick them back up after a fight or something. This also would have made the game more realistic and added an element of strategical item management. The second gadget is an explosive spray that can be detonated at will. The problem with this gadget is it's rarely usuable in combat or stealth sections. It's pretty much only used to open up new areas for finding stupid riddler trophies or other pointless unlockables.The remaining gadgets I have no problem with in and of themselves. One is the batclaw, which is a firable hook that can pull objects or enemies to you. It's phenomenal when trying to carefully take out groups of gunmen, or even in basic melee combat. Another is a sonic sequencer, which can be used to hack things, is very useful, as well as provides a fun mini-game to counter-point the action. Lastly, there is a horizontal line gun which is solely for movement. Cool, but nothing spectacular.Overall, the game could have used a lot more gadgets, especially ones like the batclaw that have multiple uses in and outside of combat. I would have loved to see bolas, throwable smoke or flash pellets, or maybe that goo he throws on faces in the movies. Basically, stuff that breaks up the monotony of combat and provides alternative ways to take down gunmen without getting shot full of holes or just give an extra edge in melee (more on that later). What I'm getting is that I want to be able to do all the cool things that we consider iconic of Batman, rather than costing by soley on the batclaw.Which brings me to the next thing: melee combat. There are a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of parts where you're in a room and can't leave until you beat up all the thugs (like an arena shooter). I hated these parts because they aren't very interactive. You just click left mouse repeatedly to have Batman kick/punch guys. The game auto-manages all of this for you, having Batman jump wildly around the arena doing complicated moves and such. The only time the game requires player input is when you need to block (at which point an enemy gets a blue thing above his head and you're supposed to press right mouse to counter). Half the time though, Batman won't counter even if you do press right mouse, leading to some quite frustrating deaths or loss of combo points. The other problem with this system is because the game manages the combat for you, Batman could end up moving across the room to punch someone in an area you didn't want him to go (such as some kind of enviormental hazard you need to stay out of). Overall, you're going to get really frustrated at times due to lack of control, as well as just being bored. The only times this combat was fun was when they introduced special enemies that you couldn't take down just by left clicking, you have to do other things that require player input. However, these enemies were few and far between, the game electing to throw hordes of zombie-like regular henchmen at you most of the time. None of the gadgets were that useful in these sequences. It would have been nice to be able to use something to even the odds, or just make combat more dynamic, interactive, and tactical. Another thing I want to complain about is camera angles. Many times during boss battles, the camera angles suddenly shift on you and I found it annoying as absolute hell. It's supposed to make the game more "cinematic" or dramatic or something, but it just♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off. Suddenly all the directions are messed up so that foraward is actually right or something like that. Why couldn't they just keep the camera behind Batman's shoulder? It's not fun to die to something like that over and over.The last complaint is that they copy the premise of the baine fight over and over again. I can't really say more without doing spoilers, but just realize that there is one thing you will be doing over and over and over in this game.My final verdict is "meh". It's not too bad if you're a huge Batman fan like me, most likely you'll force yourself through it because you enjoy the characters. Also, it is an old game which you can most likely get cheap or even on sale. If this was a brand new title that wasn't related to the caped crusader, I would definitely give it a thumbs down.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is simply a must-buy.It provides the perfect beginning to some of the most impressive Batman games we've come to see in recent years. From the innovative free-flow combat system to the gadget assisted stealth of the Silent Knight challenges. You'll see some nostalgic clashes with some of Gotham's most feared. Arkham Asylum places Batman into a gritty, intense and industrial-esque environment as he relentlessly pursues The Joker, whose murderous trail of havoc has laid waste to some of Arkham's finest. Batman is trapped, not just physically in the Arkham complex, but also by a sense of duty to stop this madman in his tracks. From hunting Riddler's tough-to-find Trophies, to exploring the Island, you'll be battling your way through hordes of inmates whilst using an array of gadgets and brutal martial arts.Be ready to be immersed in a well crafted storyline as you step into the Dark Knight's titanium boots. I'm excited for you because you're gonna' love every second you play...as well as every bone you shatter!

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												Remember the broken launch of Arkham Knight and the marketing saying "Be the Batman." This and its sequel Arkham City ultimately do a better job of immersing you in the world of the Dark Knight. Unlike Arkham Knight this game runs well and feels like a competent port. I played through this game on PS3 and have picked it up here on Steam as well. The game is fairly linear in its structure but its narrative is tight as you explore the Arkham facility in an effort to thwart the Joker's nefarious plot. Along the way you will battle countless thugs who melt beneath well timed counters and combo attacks. The game has a nice balance of both melee combat as well as stealth sections that allow you to utilize Batman's various gadgets and tools. See a guard walking underneath where your perched on a Gargoyle? Drop down and sweep them up and let them hang. One of the more novel mechanics is a detective mode that has you scanning the environment for clues. Its also useful in detecting enemies and identifying their movement patterns. As you progress you earn XP which can then be used to unlock various upgrades. Speaking of Unlocks, the game has a hearty helping of them ranging from interview tapes to riddler challenges and trophies to find and collect. Being the first in the series its an excellent entry point for newcomers and bat fans alike.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
Product received for free
												Ah yes, the one that started it all. Batman: Arkham Asylum. Or as I like to call it, Batman: Begins. Begins to actually make good Batman games that is! Man, I remeber playing Batman on the SNES and whoo boy, that a pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥ I mean, it was pretty damn bad. You didn't know what to do half the ♥♥♥♥ing time and the graphics looked liked somone was trying to make an homage to the earlier Mortal Kombat games(I thought they were better to be honest). So granted, my first experience with a batman game with 2-D fighting controls was a bummer. Lo and behold though, it would be years later when the DC franchise would pull itself up by the bootstraps and finally implement a fighting scheme that would not only complement the amount of enemies on screen, but also give inspiration to other games later as well. Not saying it's wholly original, nothing ever is, but it did refine it and give it nice shoe polish. Punching feels good and your attacks have impact. You actually FEEL like a super-duper detective in a skin tight suit(Schumacher fans will be disappointed), enacting your hero fantasies of yore. I never really thought stealth could be done in a batman game, but Rocksteady has proven me wrong. Takedowns from the highest perches to the lowlyest floor grate always feel smooth and satisfying. Snipers feel a bit cheap though, even when you're busy doing doing full nelsons to avoid enemy fire, or when you unexpectantly got shot from the back because you didn't see somone line up a perfectly placed shot in the guard tower adjacent to you. In short, it's a short game; took my only about 7-8 hours to beat, but well worth the experience. If you enjoyed Kevin Conroy in the 90's Batman animated show, bleed your fan-boy heart out.

Posted: May 18, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is not only an excellent Batman game; it is an excellent game. Structured as a metroidivania, Batman AA offers a refined gameplay formula of the genre. Everything is finely tuned, the pacing, the encounters, the story segments and it all fits together nicely in what is probably the best game of 2009. Unreal Engine 3 is put to good use as the game looks very good. The free flow combat engine makes use of contextual animations and at the time of the game's release it was groundbreaking. The original voice actors of Batman and the Joker are used in the game. All in all, this is THE best superhero game ever released, in my opinion. If you want to be Batman, play Arkham Asylum.
