number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2013
												The gaming world was a different place before Arkham Asylum.  We had wanted a hero, a villain, nay anybody whose shoes we could step into and viscerally and believably beat the living crap outta people and feel like Jackie Chan.  Until Batman Arkham Asylum arrived, we didn't know just how badly we had been missing a game that could make you feel like billy big ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and boy did it deliver.  Gaming brawlers had come a long way since Streets of Rage and now they would never be the same again.  Indeed, this style of combat system has become the norm for 3rd person melee combat RPGs but not all manage to recreate the fluidity and satisfying perfection of Rocksteady's design.In my eyes, the combat is what makes this game.  Its freeflow design is so tactile, responsive and has fantastic, bone crunching feedback that it feels unbelievably satisfying.  With such a simple set of inputs (at least initially), the game encourages you to perfect timings and combos rather than simple button mashing, and the skill and complexity only rises as the Batman acquires more gadgets and skills himself.  The combat system is so well honed and refined that by the end of the game, a skilled player can launch feet first into a large group of henchmen and seamlessly take every last man down with well over 10 distinctly different moves, a variety of gadgets, dodges, blocks, stuns, jumps, kicks, punches, throws and numerous other martial art moves, all tied together into a 50 move combo without ever taking a single hit.  The end result is simply stunning to watch and pure joy incarnate to execute yourself.  To top it off, the skill balance is just about perfect as to do something like this is neither unrewardingly simplistic or frustratingly impossible.  Admittedly there is the very rare moment when the Batman doesn't mercilessly assault the particular henchman you intended him to and it throws off your combo as you try desperately to think ahead to the next limb mangling move, but this is so rare as to be no more than a petty annoyance.  The one thing I'm not so sure about though is that the Batman only seems to knock the goons out.  Now I've cracked some skulls as the Batman and I'm sure it's been well beyond the stresses and forces the human body can take, no matter how muscle bound the henchmen may be.  I'm pretty sure the Batman kills some people here.But Batman is so much more than the combat even though the game could probably stand up on its jaw crunching merits alone.  The other set of mechanics that play so perfectly into the theme and gameplay of Arkham Asylum is the Batman's ability for stealth and this really does enable you to approach situations in a variety of ways and is particularly great at enabling the Batman to take down enemies unawares or launch into combat with the element of surprise at hand.  Similarly to the combat, the Batman gains gadgets and skills that enable more advanced stealth techniques and takedowns and again enable the player to develop some quite complicated and nuanced tactics.  Combine these skills with the combat and here you have the perfect marriage of mechanics that makes you feel like the Batman more so than the vast majority of games make you feel like the intended protagonist.  That feeling of swinging from gargoyle to gargoyle before gliding down, batcape unfurled, onto a completely unsuspecting group of goons and perfectly beating them up in a flawless combo is quite simply, unmatched.Additionally, Arkham Asylum is a deep dive into who is, in my humble opinion, the greatest and most interesting super hero going, with a ton of lore and atmosphere that really makes you feel like you're not just the Batman but you really are walking through his world.  The plot is fantastic, although arguably shoe horns so many Batman villains into one place that it feels a little too dense at times but even this plays well into the compact setting of Arkham Asylum and the wider plot.  Overall, the presentation and content is outstanding with even the little extras, that are commonplace in free roam worlds, forming an interesting addition to the game and provide a view into Batman lore.  You can either take it or leave it, but at least it's not pointless fluff like so many other games seemingly have with audio logs that add sod all to the story or atmosphere.  These really do add a little bit of extra detail which as a Batman fan, I genuinely enjoyed.  Finally, it's the little details that I really noticed on my second playthrough on PC that just made me fall in love with the game again.  The wear and tear to the batsuit and the Batman himself as the night at Arkham progresses, and the five o' clock shadow that develops through the night just cements that feeling of immersion this game achieves so well and really makes you feel you're battling through a protracted nightmare of the Joker's design.A particular highlight for me is the voice acting which is just outstanding and not since Metal Gear 1 with David Hayter's rough, gravelly Solid Snake have I been so enamoured with the voice behind the mask.  Kevin Conroy as the Batman hits the nail on the head, returning to the glorious Michael Keaton style of Batman; unassuming, suave and charming richboy in a batsuit.  Arleen Sorkin is great as Harley Quinn, Wally Wingert pulls off a toned down Jim Carey style Riddler which I think strikes a great balance, and Dino Andrade as The Scarecrow is utterly menacing, matching his sinister presence in the game perfectly.  Perhaps Tom Hardy's Bane would have been the icing on the cake but the star performance undoubtedly goes to the legendary Mark Hamill of the Joker who plays him perfectly and creates a really interesting counterpoint to the Batman and helps deliver the whole game.I'm yet to play the remastered edition but rest assured, I certainly will and I'm looking forward to what will be my third playthrough.  This will undoubtedly go down as a classic of its generation and a mechanic defining game to boot.This review is from my website:  https://wingedtankard.wordpress.com/2017/04/03/batman-arkham-asylum/

content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												You are the Batman. What more needs to be said? Arkham Asylum does a wonderful job in capturing the essence of the Dark Knight as you battle your way through various villains to regain control of the island.  While it will feel repetitive at times, you will beat groups of baddies to a pulp or pick them off one-by-one. In addition, you can scratch you world's greatest detective itch by solving Riddler challenges. Of course, the voice work of Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill complete the immersion. The free-flow combat system probably works best with controller but keyboard and mouse will function. While you will indeed feel powerful enough to take on hordes of enemies, at times it will be frustrating (particularly for challenges) when the game has trouble figuring out who you are trying to target. This becomes more noticeable during some boss fights when you cannot control the camera.The stealth portions of the game are the highlight. Sometimes there will be an instant fail state, but most of the time you are able to plot out (thanks to the x-ray power of detective vision) the manner in which to clear a room. Nothing like dropping down from a gargoyle and stinging up a thug, then counter circling the enemies and picking them off as they try to help their comrade. Riddler Challenges are puzzles and collectibles which provide optional puzzles and collectibles for you to hunt down providing lore for many characters as well as recordings of psychological sessions.  Some of these will require exploration and back-tracking but they are optional. There is also a leveling-up system to increase abilities and health, but this is not a skill tree, so it does not allow for customization.You can expect to spend 20-30 hours to complete the game (and one playthrough will probably be enough). While not a challenging game, at at times repetitive, it is a worthwhile experience even for the non-Batman fan as a lot of care went into creating this game.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												TLDR: Play as the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Batman sneaking around Arkham Island punching bad guys in the face. Excellent story, game mechanics, and voice acting. All around awesome game.  9.5/10Batman Arkham Asylum is one of the first great comic book games that I’ve played. In fact, the Arkham series is the only comic game series that springs to mind other than the various Spider-man games which were fun, but had serious technical problems. This game came out around the time of the second Christian Bale Batman movie, but has a completely different story and probably follows the comic / animated series much closer. But unlike in cartoons, people die in Arkham Asylum… a lot of them.*Story spoilers*When the game begins, Batman has captured Joker and is transporting him to the asylum on Arkham Island, where the criminally insane are kept separated from the people of Gotham City.  In a peculiar coincidence, a recent fire at the Blackgate prison in Gotham has caused hundreds of additional criminals to be temporarily housed in Arkham Asylum. So not only are there a bunch of super criminals (Killer Croc, Poison Ivy, Scarecrow, etc.) there’re also hundreds of Joker’s minions all in the same place. Of course it’s all a set up, and Joker is now exactly where he wants to be, king of the lunatics running the asylum.Batman Arkham Asylum is played in the third person perspective on a relatively small “open world” map. You can probably run across the length of the island in less than 10 minutes, but a lot of the action takes place indoors (buildings bigger on the inside than outside). You can play Arkham Asylum like a stealth game for a lot of the encounters, but when it comes time to fight, the combat system is generally hand to hand punching, similar to Sleeping Dogs.  You have a utility belt full of tools and weapons but your greatest advantage in battle is the “counter” where you hit the counter button when you see an enemy about to attack, and Batman will automatically reverse the enemy attack and put the attacker in his place. This basically means that while you’re kicking and punching your enemies into submission, you are practically immune to damage if you always counter in time. There could be 20 bad guys and they wouldn’t touch you if you keep an eye on the attack warnings and have decent reflexes. Bosses are a different story though, and they add some variety to the mix.Pros:+Excellent story and voice acting, particularly for the Joker who is your main enemy taunting you from behind his army of thugs. A lot of familiar Batman enemies also show up to waylay you. The Scarecrow sections are probably my favorite story-wise.+The combat and movement (gliding) mechanics are very well done. You can move through the maps with ease aided by your “detective mode” which is an augmented reality vision where you can see enemies through walls and detect interactive objects in the world. It’s kind of similar to the Thief 2014 “focus” or the Tomb Raider 2013 “survivor instinct.” The only drawback is that it turns your vision into a kind of x-ray type enhanced imaging, and you don’t see the well-drawn details of the world around you. I probably spent about half the game in detective mode. Cons:-Nothing really… unless you hate collecting objects after finishing a game’s campaign story. There are a ton of Riddler “puzzles” and collectibles to be found all over the island. By the time you finish the game’s story you will probably be about 50% complete according to the game’s progress meter. To get 100% you pretty much have to find every collectible and beat every “challenge map.”Overall, Batman Arkham Asylum is a game everyone should play, if only to prove to yourself that awesome comic book video games are possible. The game was bundled in the Humble WB bundle a year or so ago and shouldn’t be hard to find at under $5. The Game of the Year edition (the only one Steam carries) has additional skins and challenge maps, but no extra campaign.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												For a long time i have been putting off playing the Batman: Arkham games, idk why but I just have, so recently I decided that I wanted to finally sit down and play through them all, so obviously I saw it fit to play through the games as they were released. Batman: Arkham Asylum, is a great game, though fairly linear. (it is techincally "open world" but basically keeps you on the path of the story line, exploration is basically just to find riddler secrets) that being said the story is very interesting and will keep you hooked for your whole playthough, although it will not take very long at all to finish, just shy of 11 hours and thats including taking time to stealhfully take out the enemies one by one, and going off ocassionally to back track to a riddler secret that at the time I first noticed it I didn't have the right gadget to get it. So the game is short but is for sure worth playing through! With the game being almost 7 years old the graphics are very beautiful and the characters look detailed and wonderful. Note that this game does have an fps cap at 62 fps (I know strange, why not just 60?), so don't be expecting to get 200 and so on here, but that doesn't matter. the game plays smooth the whole way through and no problems with crashing or any of the sort! So happy I got around to playing this game and know I understand all the hype surrounding this series!

Posted: June 10, 2015
												This isn't the kind of game I'd usually try out, but having picked it up cheap I decided to give it a go. Overall it turned out to be a great experience. A great game with a lot of variation between the different modes and situations Batman finds himself in. I especially liked the stealth missions and riddle solving. The combat was more of a mixed bag, and I found myself sincerely hating several of the fights, mostly the titan hencman fights, which I found a lot harder than most of the boss fights. Doing those fights with a mouse and keyboard was useless, requiring me to connect a game controller to my system for the first time ever. With the controller, those fights were doable (but still frustrating), but playing the rest of the game with it was really awkward. In the end I ended up switching between mouse/keyboard and controller as the situations saw fit. More or less requiring a controller to complete the game is a big drawback in my book, but overall this game still deserves a recommendation.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is not only an excellent Batman game; it is an excellent game. Structured as a metroidivania, Batman AA offers a refined gameplay formula of the genre. Everything is finely tuned, the pacing, the encounters, the story segments and it all fits together nicely in what is probably the best game of 2009. Unreal Engine 3 is put to good use as the game looks very good. The free flow combat engine makes use of contextual animations and at the time of the game's release it was groundbreaking. The original voice actors of Batman and the Joker are used in the game. All in all, this is THE best superhero game ever released, in my opinion. If you want to be Batman, play Arkham Asylum.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												When I bought this game, I thought it would be funny to write a review of this game with just the words "I'm batman", but after playing, I realized that this game deserves a better review. So let me sum up a few pros and cons of this game.under these pros and cons I will explain them a little.+nice storyline+decent controlls+third person view+character bios+nice graphics+variation of opponenents+amazing joker+second batcave?+riddles+decent voiceacting+after-death-cutscenes-stable internet connection required-last bossfightHere the more in-depth explaination:The pros:The reason why I like the storyline is because you can see that the developers thought about it. the Joker pretty much creates some fun in the game while you're busy fighting his little ♥♥♥♥♥es.When I first saw the controlls, I thought they were somewhat odd, but after half an hour of playing I understood why they were made this way, and they actually feel really nice once used to it.I usually prefer to play games in first person view, but the third person view really fits this game. That way you can anticipate on attacks of henchmen and you will be able to counter them. It's also just nice to see the movements of Batman's cape.Another nice feature of this game is the character bios. The developers wrote a small background of pretty much every important character in the game. It also shows some facts of the characters, like when they first appeared and what their real names are (if known). But most of all I like the character bios because of the interview tapes you can collect in the game. They are quite funny and give you a little more information.Even though I played this game on a laptop with an intel pentium 4 processor and an on-board videocard, the game looked really great. Better than I expected.Another cool thing is that the Joker is not your only oppononent. You will also come across Harley Quinn, Scarecrow, The Croc, Poison Ivy, Bane, and Victor Zsasz. All of those have to be fought in another way, which brings some variation in the game. They also have different types of henchmen. The unarmed will have to be fought directly and with brute force, while the armed will have to be approached sneaky. There is also a difference between unarmed henchmen. Some will be really unarmed, while others use knives or kind of tasers. I also really love this Joker. They created him like a combination of Heath Ledger and the guy who played the Joker before him. Some may like it, some may not, but since this game is not in Gotham, Batman will not have it's batcave in this game. To give the feeling of a batcave, the developers made a secret second batcave on Arkham Island.To make it a little harder to complete this game, they created some riddles. Some are easy to solve, but since there are more than 200 riddles, you might take a while to actually solve all of them, mainly because most of them are actually not easy to solve.I'm a guy who loves to hear things and does a lot with his ears, so I hate it when there are crappy voiceactors in a game. Batman: Arkham Asylum actually uses decent actors, which makes it a lot more nice to play for people like me.In a lot of games you die, and you just resurrect, but in Batman: Arkham Asylum you die, and you get a little cutscene from an opponent, who's captured you and acts like he's about to kill you, which makes it less boring to die.Now the cons:When you play this game with an unstable connection, the game will suddenly stop once the connection is lost, and it will bring you back to the main menu. This caused me to start over a few times. It's really annoying when this happens mid-bossfight, because you will have to do everything from the bossfight once again. A serious problem which shouldn't be necessary since this is not an online game. The last bossfight against the Joker is pretty dull in my opinion. you pretty much have to do the same thing 3 times which is not really something the Joker would let you do.I overall rate this game 9.3/10

content:
Posted: July 9, 2013
												The gaming world was a different place before Arkham Asylum.  We had wanted a hero, a villain, nay anybody whose shoes we could step into and viscerally and believably beat the living crap outta people and feel like Jackie Chan.  Until Batman Arkham Asylum arrived, we didn't know just how badly we had been missing a game that could make you feel like billy big ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and boy did it deliver.  Gaming brawlers had come a long way since Streets of Rage and now they would never be the same again.  Indeed, this style of combat system has become the norm for 3rd person melee combat RPGs but not all manage to recreate the fluidity and satisfying perfection of Rocksteady's design.In my eyes, the combat is what makes this game.  Its freeflow design is so tactile, responsive and has fantastic, bone crunching feedback that it feels unbelievably satisfying.  With such a simple set of inputs (at least initially), the game encourages you to perfect timings and combos rather than simple button mashing, and the skill and complexity only rises as the Batman acquires more gadgets and skills himself.  The combat system is so well honed and refined that by the end of the game, a skilled player can launch feet first into a large group of henchmen and seamlessly take every last man down with well over 10 distinctly different moves, a variety of gadgets, dodges, blocks, stuns, jumps, kicks, punches, throws and numerous other martial art moves, all tied together into a 50 move combo without ever taking a single hit.  The end result is simply stunning to watch and pure joy incarnate to execute yourself.  To top it off, the skill balance is just about perfect as to do something like this is neither unrewardingly simplistic or frustratingly impossible.  Admittedly there is the very rare moment when the Batman doesn't mercilessly assault the particular henchman you intended him to and it throws off your combo as you try desperately to think ahead to the next limb mangling move, but this is so rare as to be no more than a petty annoyance.  The one thing I'm not so sure about though is that the Batman only seems to knock the goons out.  Now I've cracked some skulls as the Batman and I'm sure it's been well beyond the stresses and forces the human body can take, no matter how muscle bound the henchmen may be.  I'm pretty sure the Batman kills some people here.But Batman is so much more than the combat even though the game could probably stand up on its jaw crunching merits alone.  The other set of mechanics that play so perfectly into the theme and gameplay of Arkham Asylum is the Batman's ability for stealth and this really does enable you to approach situations in a variety of ways and is particularly great at enabling the Batman to take down enemies unawares or launch into combat with the element of surprise at hand.  Similarly to the combat, the Batman gains gadgets and skills that enable more advanced stealth techniques and takedowns and again enable the player to develop some quite complicated and nuanced tactics.  Combine these skills with the combat and here you have the perfect marriage of mechanics that makes you feel like the Batman more so than the vast majority of games make you feel like the intended protagonist.  That feeling of swinging from gargoyle to gargoyle before gliding down, batcape unfurled, onto a completely unsuspecting group of goons and perfectly beating them up in a flawless combo is quite simply, unmatched.Additionally, Arkham Asylum is a deep dive into who is, in my humble opinion, the greatest and most interesting super hero going, with a ton of lore and atmosphere that really makes you feel like you're not just the Batman but you really are walking through his world.  The plot is fantastic, although arguably shoe horns so many Batman villains into one place that it feels a little too dense at times but even this plays well into the compact setting of Arkham Asylum and the wider plot.  Overall, the presentation and content is outstanding with even the little extras, that are commonplace in free roam worlds, forming an interesting addition to the game and provide a view into Batman lore.  You can either take it or leave it, but at least it's not pointless fluff like so many other games seemingly have with audio logs that add sod all to the story or atmosphere.  These really do add a little bit of extra detail which as a Batman fan, I genuinely enjoyed.  Finally, it's the little details that I really noticed on my second playthrough on PC that just made me fall in love with the game again.  The wear and tear to the batsuit and the Batman himself as the night at Arkham progresses, and the five o' clock shadow that develops through the night just cements that feeling of immersion this game achieves so well and really makes you feel you're battling through a protracted nightmare of the Joker's design.A particular highlight for me is the voice acting which is just outstanding and not since Metal Gear 1 with David Hayter's rough, gravelly Solid Snake have I been so enamoured with the voice behind the mask.  Kevin Conroy as the Batman hits the nail on the head, returning to the glorious Michael Keaton style of Batman; unassuming, suave and charming richboy in a batsuit.  Arleen Sorkin is great as Harley Quinn, Wally Wingert pulls off a toned down Jim Carey style Riddler which I think strikes a great balance, and Dino Andrade as The Scarecrow is utterly menacing, matching his sinister presence in the game perfectly.  Perhaps Tom Hardy's Bane would have been the icing on the cake but the star performance undoubtedly goes to the legendary Mark Hamill of the Joker who plays him perfectly and creates a really interesting counterpoint to the Batman and helps deliver the whole game.I'm yet to play the remastered edition but rest assured, I certainly will and I'm looking forward to what will be my third playthrough.  This will undoubtedly go down as a classic of its generation and a mechanic defining game to boot.This review is from my website:  https://wingedtankard.wordpress.com/2017/04/03/batman-arkham-asylum/

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												This is where it all began - most likely the coolest superhero game series ever, even with the problems it suffered later (the not exactly innovative Origins, and the buggy launch of AK). And what a start it was! Even today, the game looks really dang good, and the atmosphere rocks still! Don't be misled by my low number of hours... I did buy this game when it came out (back then, still with the horrible Windows Live system), and played it like crazy, and just was given AA and AC for free because I bought AK a while ago, and just started replaying this one AGAIN. And it still is one of the best entries in the series. AC might be bigger, AK more technically advanced, the other games have more gadgets and stuff, but this still has such a great vibe to it, and a cool story. The intro (even though it gets a bit long on your 2nd, 3rd, ... playthrough) is a great start, and off you go, exploring the huge Asylum, which is split up into different segments.You can focus on the story and go for that mostly, or you can try to find all the Riddler secrets and interrogation tapes, which will tell you more about the villains.If you have played any of the more recent ACs, Shadow Of Mordor or any of the newer Batman games, the gameplay will be fun, and you will be familiar with the controls. Hitting, combos, blocking, etc. The game runs perfectly well on my system, and I think that you really SHOULD get it if you haven't tried it yet, especially when it is on sale. One of the coolest games of the recent years, a totally great entry to the Batman-franchise (the game really does justice to the Batman we all love... the cool, enigmatic, torn, threatening one), it still looks great and is fun, and there are some very cool moments in there, especially those that are related to the fear toxin. The boss fights might be more varied and interesting in later games, but still, they are fun in this one (and less "waaayy too long" than they were in Origins), and I think it's decently challenging...and a ton of fun.If you love Batman, or the games I mentioned above, if you wanna see how the Arkham-franchise began with a killer game, get this game! Right now, during the xmas sale, its five Euros, so GET IT!Pros:- Runs perfect, even on highest settings, and has aged very well- Still looks great- Awesome atmosphere and voice-acting- Challenging yet not unfair- Some great sequences and writing- Fun combat- Some VERY creative scenes. Killer Croc's Lair was one of my favorites, as it was very suspenseful. Cons:- Boss fights are not as varied as in later games, ymmvYMMV: The game is pretty short...I finished the whole story in 8 hours on this playthrough. Didnt do any challenges, and didn't find all ridler-icons, but focused mainly on the story. However, better 8 hours of a great game than 60 hours with tons of repetition and filler, right?It was VERY VERY enjoyable, but some may find it too short, or too linear... the storyline dictates where you go, and the Asylum is segmented, not as open as AC. Still, an AWESOME game even today, and if you can get it for a low prize, don't hesitate!

content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												You are the Batman. What more needs to be said? Arkham Asylum does a wonderful job in capturing the essence of the Dark Knight as you battle your way through various villains to regain control of the island.  While it will feel repetitive at times, you will beat groups of baddies to a pulp or pick them off one-by-one. In addition, you can scratch you world's greatest detective itch by solving Riddler challenges. Of course, the voice work of Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill complete the immersion. The free-flow combat system probably works best with controller but keyboard and mouse will function. While you will indeed feel powerful enough to take on hordes of enemies, at times it will be frustrating (particularly for challenges) when the game has trouble figuring out who you are trying to target. This becomes more noticeable during some boss fights when you cannot control the camera.The stealth portions of the game are the highlight. Sometimes there will be an instant fail state, but most of the time you are able to plot out (thanks to the x-ray power of detective vision) the manner in which to clear a room. Nothing like dropping down from a gargoyle and stinging up a thug, then counter circling the enemies and picking them off as they try to help their comrade. Riddler Challenges are puzzles and collectibles which provide optional puzzles and collectibles for you to hunt down providing lore for many characters as well as recordings of psychological sessions.  Some of these will require exploration and back-tracking but they are optional. There is also a leveling-up system to increase abilities and health, but this is not a skill tree, so it does not allow for customization.You can expect to spend 20-30 hours to complete the game (and one playthrough will probably be enough). While not a challenging game, at at times repetitive, it is a worthwhile experience even for the non-Batman fan as a lot of care went into creating this game.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												TLDR: Play as the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Batman sneaking around Arkham Island punching bad guys in the face. Excellent story, game mechanics, and voice acting. All around awesome game.  9.5/10Batman Arkham Asylum is one of the first great comic book games that I’ve played. In fact, the Arkham series is the only comic game series that springs to mind other than the various Spider-man games which were fun, but had serious technical problems. This game came out around the time of the second Christian Bale Batman movie, but has a completely different story and probably follows the comic / animated series much closer. But unlike in cartoons, people die in Arkham Asylum… a lot of them.*Story spoilers*When the game begins, Batman has captured Joker and is transporting him to the asylum on Arkham Island, where the criminally insane are kept separated from the people of Gotham City.  In a peculiar coincidence, a recent fire at the Blackgate prison in Gotham has caused hundreds of additional criminals to be temporarily housed in Arkham Asylum. So not only are there a bunch of super criminals (Killer Croc, Poison Ivy, Scarecrow, etc.) there’re also hundreds of Joker’s minions all in the same place. Of course it’s all a set up, and Joker is now exactly where he wants to be, king of the lunatics running the asylum.Batman Arkham Asylum is played in the third person perspective on a relatively small “open world” map. You can probably run across the length of the island in less than 10 minutes, but a lot of the action takes place indoors (buildings bigger on the inside than outside). You can play Arkham Asylum like a stealth game for a lot of the encounters, but when it comes time to fight, the combat system is generally hand to hand punching, similar to Sleeping Dogs.  You have a utility belt full of tools and weapons but your greatest advantage in battle is the “counter” where you hit the counter button when you see an enemy about to attack, and Batman will automatically reverse the enemy attack and put the attacker in his place. This basically means that while you’re kicking and punching your enemies into submission, you are practically immune to damage if you always counter in time. There could be 20 bad guys and they wouldn’t touch you if you keep an eye on the attack warnings and have decent reflexes. Bosses are a different story though, and they add some variety to the mix.Pros:+Excellent story and voice acting, particularly for the Joker who is your main enemy taunting you from behind his army of thugs. A lot of familiar Batman enemies also show up to waylay you. The Scarecrow sections are probably my favorite story-wise.+The combat and movement (gliding) mechanics are very well done. You can move through the maps with ease aided by your “detective mode” which is an augmented reality vision where you can see enemies through walls and detect interactive objects in the world. It’s kind of similar to the Thief 2014 “focus” or the Tomb Raider 2013 “survivor instinct.” The only drawback is that it turns your vision into a kind of x-ray type enhanced imaging, and you don’t see the well-drawn details of the world around you. I probably spent about half the game in detective mode. Cons:-Nothing really… unless you hate collecting objects after finishing a game’s campaign story. There are a ton of Riddler “puzzles” and collectibles to be found all over the island. By the time you finish the game’s story you will probably be about 50% complete according to the game’s progress meter. To get 100% you pretty much have to find every collectible and beat every “challenge map.”Overall, Batman Arkham Asylum is a game everyone should play, if only to prove to yourself that awesome comic book video games are possible. The game was bundled in the Humble WB bundle a year or so ago and shouldn’t be hard to find at under $5. The Game of the Year edition (the only one Steam carries) has additional skins and challenge maps, but no extra campaign.

												The first in a great series This is the first of the Arkham sereis and it started a great game series that I enoyed all the way through. This is my least favorite of the 3 games I have palyed, but maybe that will change after I play Arham knight. who knows. This dose not mean that the game is bad, but it is the least original, in terms of story, and for me the story is one of the must important  thing for these games.The game is a exploration and fighting game, based in the batman universe. The good thing about this, is all of the vilans you get to see, since this game takes place inside Arkham Asylum witch is not really a prison but more like a psycority place, that will help bad guys to become good guys. The gameplay is split up into three major parts. There is the fighting part, witch is played out by using the right mouse button to hit a person, the right mouse button to counter, and the middle mouse button to confuse, you aim at a person by using the mouse, and you have to be fast to counter and hit, without getting hit youself. Along the game the enemyes get harder, and there must be used new tacktics to defeat them. You will also get more items along the way whitch will help you in combat.There is a part I don`t get with that logic. Along the way, Batman pics up equpment that he finds useful, but I raise the qeustion; whoulden`t it be better if you brang along your awesome gear to begin with? He gose through so many areas, where these items whould have helpt along the way, but they do this so you of couse can`t unlock everything right away.The secound game fetures is stealth, where you must use stealth, in order to take care of heavy eqeupt enemyes. Here you have to be patiencent and plan your strategie in order to not get spotted.The last part are some puzzels that the Riddler have scattered throughout Arkham. This is the best Riddler challenge acourding to me, and they are very cleaver made.The music in this game is very glomy and it`s good at setting the mood of this dark and dangourus palce. There are also challenges you can do outside of the main game, that can be fun to do now and again. The story is the best part of this game, after Batman captiers the Joker, the Joker escapes and make Arhkam run amok. This is a plan that the Joker have planed all along, whitch you will discover if you paly the game. Along the way, you are going to meet iconic Batman villans such as Bain, Killer Crock, Poison Ivy and Harly Quen. The most iconic boss to me was Scarecrow. that made you trip out and experince a wiered nightmare senario that made for some awseome scenes for the game.If you explore some of the Riddler chalenges, you get to know the story of a lot of diffrent Batman charecters, whitch is really cool.This game is really good, thumps up. 7 out of 10

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
 You Don't Play Batman...You Are Batman  Batman: Arkham Asylum  is brilliant in almost every way. From a technical perspective: the game looks great, the animations work mostly well, the textures look great and the audio is brilliant (especially the voice acting). The game mechanics give the players the feeling that they are Batman instead of only playing a character who can be replaced by another. The player can easily take out multiple unarmed enemies, via the freeflow fighting system, but needs to be careful when they are armed (predator mode). These gameplay modes give the game more variety and are incredibly well made. The items are based on Batman's utility arsenal and can be used in a variety of different ways, next to their original purpose. The only thing that could have been better is the story, which is very comicish (even for a game that is based on a comic book), but leads to the better story in  Batman: Arkham City . Rating: 5/5

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
Batman: Arkham Asylum is easily one of the best superhero games ever made.Pros: Graphics, Sound, ControlsCons: Gameplay, RealismBatman: Arkham Asylum is the first Batman game to truly glimpse into the adventures of the Dark Knight.  From the gritty, dark atmosphere to the nervous, superstitious ramblings of the inmates, every detail creates a sense of not just playing Batman, but being Batman.  Simple controls allow for excellent combat sequences or tight, stealthy getaways.Although some parts are truly innnovative, such as those with the Scarecrow, others are much more monotonous.  Finding all the Riddler trophies (not the actual, more interesting riddles) can sometimes feel like a glorified pixel hunt.  Some mechanics simply break the realism: Gotham should have spent more money on the concrete walls that are literally being pulled apart instead of the indestructible laser gates right next to them.Still, Batman: Arkham Asylum truly captures what it feels like to be the Dark Knight.9/10

content:
Posted: October 22, 2012
												One of the better adaptations of Gotham. The story plays excellently and the combination of stealth and fighting mechanics is fluid and intuitive. The voice acting by Joker and his dialogue in particular is brilliant. The soundtrack is mostly ambient, although the creepy diegetic music from Joker's radio station is effective. This game features a very effective use of the Unreal Engine 3, especially with the sharp textures and lighting effects. Be weary however that the PhysX effects are EXTREMELY taxing on a non-NVIDIA chip. Excellent game with a great story, good voice acting and a rich game world.8/10

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												When I bought this game, I thought it would be funny to write a review of this game with just the words "I'm batman", but after playing, I realized that this game deserves a better review. So let me sum up a few pros and cons of this game.under these pros and cons I will explain them a little.+nice storyline+decent controlls+third person view+character bios+nice graphics+variation of opponenents+amazing joker+second batcave?+riddles+decent voiceacting+after-death-cutscenes-stable internet connection required-last bossfightHere the more in-depth explaination:The pros:The reason why I like the storyline is because you can see that the developers thought about it. the Joker pretty much creates some fun in the game while you're busy fighting his little ♥♥♥♥♥es.When I first saw the controlls, I thought they were somewhat odd, but after half an hour of playing I understood why they were made this way, and they actually feel really nice once used to it.I usually prefer to play games in first person view, but the third person view really fits this game. That way you can anticipate on attacks of henchmen and you will be able to counter them. It's also just nice to see the movements of Batman's cape.Another nice feature of this game is the character bios. The developers wrote a small background of pretty much every important character in the game. It also shows some facts of the characters, like when they first appeared and what their real names are (if known). But most of all I like the character bios because of the interview tapes you can collect in the game. They are quite funny and give you a little more information.Even though I played this game on a laptop with an intel pentium 4 processor and an on-board videocard, the game looked really great. Better than I expected.Another cool thing is that the Joker is not your only oppononent. You will also come across Harley Quinn, Scarecrow, The Croc, Poison Ivy, Bane, and Victor Zsasz. All of those have to be fought in another way, which brings some variation in the game. They also have different types of henchmen. The unarmed will have to be fought directly and with brute force, while the armed will have to be approached sneaky. There is also a difference between unarmed henchmen. Some will be really unarmed, while others use knives or kind of tasers. I also really love this Joker. They created him like a combination of Heath Ledger and the guy who played the Joker before him. Some may like it, some may not, but since this game is not in Gotham, Batman will not have it's batcave in this game. To give the feeling of a batcave, the developers made a secret second batcave on Arkham Island.To make it a little harder to complete this game, they created some riddles. Some are easy to solve, but since there are more than 200 riddles, you might take a while to actually solve all of them, mainly because most of them are actually not easy to solve.I'm a guy who loves to hear things and does a lot with his ears, so I hate it when there are crappy voiceactors in a game. Batman: Arkham Asylum actually uses decent actors, which makes it a lot more nice to play for people like me.In a lot of games you die, and you just resurrect, but in Batman: Arkham Asylum you die, and you get a little cutscene from an opponent, who's captured you and acts like he's about to kill you, which makes it less boring to die.Now the cons:When you play this game with an unstable connection, the game will suddenly stop once the connection is lost, and it will bring you back to the main menu. This caused me to start over a few times. It's really annoying when this happens mid-bossfight, because you will have to do everything from the bossfight once again. A serious problem which shouldn't be necessary since this is not an online game. The last bossfight against the Joker is pretty dull in my opinion. you pretty much have to do the same thing 3 times which is not really something the Joker would let you do.I overall rate this game 9.3/10

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												First, if you haven't played BM:AA, then do it. You don't need this review.You're Batman. The good Batman, from the animated series, with the GOOD Joker...you know, from the animated series. Batman gets locked in Arkham's grounds and goes around beating up mentally unstable people with the most fluid and dynamic fighting controls ever put into a game. My only criticism is that Batman's "detective" mode is monochrome, and super useful, so that large portions of the game will be played with that viewpoint on. The game itself is so lovely and detailed that I hated using detective mode because I felt like it was taking me out of the game.I think if the developer's had used it as an augmented reality type view, it would have worked better.Oh, also, buy this if you love beefy beefcake weightlifters and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ schoolgirls.10/10, would be Batman again. And again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2
												Great atmosphere, with the Joker giving constant commentary on what you're doing, he's always one step ahead of you so you're constantly playing catch-up. The arkham island consists of 5 buildings (medical, botanical, mansion, treatment, and penitentiary), as well as the sewer system. Most action take place in one of these buildings, so you usually don't have much open space. The rooms and corridors are beautifully detailed, thought.The combat system is simple to learn, but difficult to perfect. While the combat looks really cool, it lacks a bit of variety. The predator, aka stealth, sections of the game, where you take on multiple enemies armed with guns, are perhaps the most entertaining part of the game. Too bad there's few of them. They also become easy once you realize the power of the unconcious enemy + explosive gel/triple batarang combo. The enemies feel too unaware, even on hard mode. They are never a real threat unless you get recklessly aggressive. But still, it's good fun picking them off one by one and have them running around in total distress.I do wish the boss enemies were more interesting, they all just involve dodging attacks and throwing a batarang at the right moment.

content:
Posted: January 1
												I'll never forget when this game originally came out. Initially, there wasn't a HUGE amount of fuss surrounding the build-up to it. Gaming publications and sites were quietly wary about it due to it being another licenced game, but then the game came out and we all know what happened then. I first played it right as it came out so weren't 100% sure what I was getting into. Within about 10 minutes, I knew there was something special going on here as the presentation was just fantastic. Following Joker as he gets wheeled into Arkham Asylum felt very different to what I was experiencing with a lot of action games recently, which had lost a lot of steam. About an hour into the game, I then realised this wasn't just your bog-standard action game. Suddenly I was dealing with puzzles, hidden collectables, a gripping story which really drew me in and the now popular free-roaming gameplay which the Arkham series became loved for. There's loads of Batman villains in the game, including such classics as Riddler, Killer Croc, Clayface, Poison Ivy, plus loads of references to further villains. The Riddler challenges are one of the best parts of the game. He'll have you hunting for wind-up teeth, hidden Riddler question marks, and the best part is hunting for actual riddles which reference Batman characters from over the years.The combat is simple enough in-game and you often find yourself taking on 5 - 10 goons at a time with ease due to the great range of moves on offer for the Bat. A combo system ensures you feel like a proper bad♥♥♥♥♥ and you#ll only ever die because you lose your flow and can#t get back into the rhythm of the battle. Basically, it'll have been your fault!Graphically, the game is still gorgeous even now after 8 years. The locations never feel empty with all the clutter and props on view, the characters all look very unique, and the whole thing comes across very sharp. I'm not one for getting into the intricacies of graphical properties, and polygons, shaders, AA, frame rates etc. I simply boil it down to it looks great and carries out the function it's intended to.Voice acting is carried out here with expert aplomb, with Mark Hamill especially standing out as always playing The Joker. With the exception of Harley Quinn, all characters sound fantastic and their voices truly fit the menace needed by them. Harley unfortunately is a squeaky annoyance who wouldn't go amiss in 'Singin' in the Rain'. Outside of the voice-work, the mood is set well with audio cues hitting at the right times and the ambience provided by a very fitting set of sound effects which always keep reminding you of where you are. Music is great, sounds like bintage Batman movie soundtracks. The game provides a long first time experience for the average gamer, and can easily get a good few extra hours on top if you want to 100% it. Enjoy this enough and you'll definitely want to go on and try out the sequels with Arkham City being the pinnacle, and Origins unfortunately feeling a little stripped back.OVERALL:[/b]Graphics: 10/10Gameplay: 9/10Lifespan: 9/10Audio: 9/10Overall: 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Played through on Hard first try, got about 80% of all of the collectables and secrets (there are hundreds). Very well made game, and rife with awesome Batman info/lore.The ONLY complaint I have with this game is the combat system. The combat isn't very complicated because there are many parts where you need to neutralize enemies in stealth, as any good Batman should. The problem here is that, because the combat is stretched so thin between straight up fighting and stealth, it does neither perfectly. STEALTH - Stealth is a very wishy-washy thing in this game, and because everything in a room is illuminated the same, you don't know if you are in hiding or if a gargoyle you've perched on is not actually putting you in the shadows. You can't fight enemies with guns straight up, so you are frequently forced into the stealth role.HAND-TO-HAND - Much of the straight up combat in this game is luck-based. Not all of it, but enough to be minorly frustrating in Hard mode. There is a 'counter' button while you're fighting that can counter an enemy's basic attack, but the prompt to counter shows up only 50% of the time, and even at that rate, it is very unlikely that you hitting the correct button will actually counter the enemy's attack because you're already in full swing of your own attack.And here inlies the main problem with this game - the 'difficulty'. Because of these certain flaws in the combat, the way the developers ramped up the difficulty was by not making certain enemies harder, but just simply putting more enemes in the combat with you. That isn't very good game design, in my opinion. Because not all attacks are properly counter-able, the more enemies you're fighting, the more you're at the whim of the randomness of the game and how the enemies approach you. I have often found myself having to replay some battles where I play noticeably worse, but win the overall battle becaue of the random way certain enemes approach or attack you.Yes, this is a fantastic game, but it's minor flaws turn into glaring ones during certain parts of the game. I would still highly reccomend it, but maybe not for a scaling challenge, but more for batman and adventure / collect-em-all fans.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
Product received for free
												Ah yes, the one that started it all. Batman: Arkham Asylum. Or as I like to call it, Batman: Begins. Begins to actually make good Batman games that is! Man, I remeber playing Batman on the SNES and whoo boy, that a pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥ I mean, it was pretty damn bad. You didn't know what to do half the ♥♥♥♥ing time and the graphics looked liked somone was trying to make an homage to the earlier Mortal Kombat games(I thought they were better to be honest). So granted, my first experience with a batman game with 2-D fighting controls was a bummer. Lo and behold though, it would be years later when the DC franchise would pull itself up by the bootstraps and finally implement a fighting scheme that would not only complement the amount of enemies on screen, but also give inspiration to other games later as well. Not saying it's wholly original, nothing ever is, but it did refine it and give it nice shoe polish. Punching feels good and your attacks have impact. You actually FEEL like a super-duper detective in a skin tight suit(Schumacher fans will be disappointed), enacting your hero fantasies of yore. I never really thought stealth could be done in a batman game, but Rocksteady has proven me wrong. Takedowns from the highest perches to the lowlyest floor grate always feel smooth and satisfying. Snipers feel a bit cheap though, even when you're busy doing doing full nelsons to avoid enemy fire, or when you unexpectantly got shot from the back because you didn't see somone line up a perfectly placed shot in the guard tower adjacent to you. In short, it's a short game; took my only about 7-8 hours to beat, but well worth the experience. If you enjoyed Kevin Conroy in the 90's Batman animated show, bleed your fan-boy heart out.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												I was skeptical about this game when my friend first told me to get it. I'm not a fan of fighting games, and while I think Batman is both on of the best superheroes and one of the most interesting ones, I didn't really think a game like this--developed originally for the Xbox 360 and ported to PC--would do well. Boy was I wrong. Not only are the graphics surprisingly good, the audio (voice acting, fighting sounds, etc.) makes me feel like Batman. In particular, the voice acting is definitely some of the best I've heard in a video game. The fighting, though rather redundant, is still incredibly fun, though I did notice that countering enemy attacks was difficult. I may have been bad at it, but since I'm fine with it in the sequel to this game, Batman: Arkham CIty, I think it may have just been a minor issue in this game. The boss fights, while redundant, are quite fun and actually quite challenging. Furthermore, the story of this game is remarkably good. I never felt like I was playing through a fighting game with a story tacked on; it felt like a fighting game built around the story, in a good way. The atmosphere was top-notch and made me feel like Batman. To summarize:Pros-great atmosphere, solid gameplay, good graphics and audio, surprisngly good story, delivers an authentic Batman experienceCons-Issues with countering, boss fights can be redundant, hard to get used toOverall, I'd highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Finally got around to playing this, and I don't know what took me so long. This is brilliant. Batman as he always should have been. The game plays out like a 3D Metroidvania, rewarding exploration with tons of secrets to find, most of which you won't be able to get until Batman gets new abilities. The fighting system is fun and fairly intuitive, but the stealth mechanics are my favorite - the experience of being Batman has never come more alive than when I stalked my enemies from the shadows. The music never really spoke to me, but the art and presentation is excellent. The acting is exceptional on all sides, but Mark Hamill's Joker steals the show - as he should.BEST PART - Picking off a group of thugs one by one while they have no idea where I am, and the baddies left standing get more and more terrified.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												The first game in the Arkham Series, Arkham Asylum is nothing short of brilliant.  The plot revolves around Batman trapped in Arkham Asylum, run by the Joker. Along the way Batman fights to survive, and questions his sanity. He questions if he should be in the Asylum himself. Along the way he meets members of his great rouges gallery. The voice actors are brilliant. Kevin Conroy is great reprising his role as Batman from BTAS or Batman the Animated Series. In my mind, he is the one true Batman. Mark Hamill is hilariously dark as the Joker also reprising his BTAS role. You can see the fun these men are having playing their roles, and you can totally buy there long infamous history. The character designs are spectacular, the best being the Scarecrow.  As far as gameplay goes its top notch.  In the story there are some difficult parts, but I being a casual gamer, dont think  many gamers will have much trouble. I'd give the game a 10/10, but the thing that does not make it reach that is the sheer formulelic boss battles. I'm not a huge gamer, but when you add one small differnce to every boss battle, I was never suprised. the final boss battle is  the worst part of the game, in the sense that the game throws everything at you, which makes it seem really far from the brilliance of the first part of the game.An great expirence. 9 out of 10

content:
Posted: November 24, 2013
												This is still and perhaps always will be, at least in my opinion, the Batman game fans deserved. Set in a closed space, the Arkham Asylum, which is pretty significant to fans of the Batman universe, the game is also filled with references and characters from the series and the adventure feels like a high quality one-shot graphic novel.The atmosphere is palpable, the combat system is designed to flow smoothly with combos and the design also encourages the use of stealth and detective abilities.This game is closer to a Batman comic than any live action movie to date, with the great voice talent of Mark Hamill as the Joker, so if this doesn't feel like Batman, nothing ever will.(I would also recommend Arkham City to a somewhat lesser extent and to an even lesser extent but still worth your time, for the retro games fan in you, check out The Adventures of Batman & Robin on SNES and Genesis.)

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is a pioneer which changed the landscape of superhero genre in the gaming industry. Story is well written, as you will feel tension in the atmosphere. Joker pulls all the strings and you must fight the odds. It starts off with Joke being escorted to his asylum under Batman and Arkham Asylum's watchful eyes but Joker manages to escape and turns the asylum into his playground. You must save the people in the asylum and stop this madness that Joker had planned all along. The voice acting is top-notch. One can listen to Joker or the Riddler talk all day. The Scarecrow bit in the game is one of the best gaming moments ever. I loved the tone of many super-villians in an asylum with Batman. This game changed the whole landscape for the superhero games.You will feel like Batman as you will owerpower most of the thugs. Different gadgets are used to solve puzzles and move ahead in the story. The sleath mechanics are well done too and one of the best parts about stealth is how after you take out one of the enemies the fear slowly grips other enemies as they become aggressive but as soon as the numbers start dwindlling they start to panic, this machenic is one of the best in the gaming history. Boss fights on the other hand were a bit too easy and lackluster. Also there is some odd detective work which was nice. Of course, there is the good old fashioned brawling there too. Graphics and atmosphere are good as they capture the tone of the dark and gritty world. Art-style is also very good. Environmental design is brilliant and there a twisted sense of character in every area you’ll discover. This claustrophobic cove of madness oozing terror has to be one of the best settings in video-games.It has everything you would like from an immersive world, great storyline, sleath, detective work and old fashioned brawling. What else do you want? So, are you a Batman fan? buy this game, even if you are not one you will still love this game and is inarguably one of the best superhero games ever.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19
Greetings! As you probably know, Batman: Arkham Asylum is the first and the most critically acclaimed game of the newest Batman series in which you slip into the role of Batman himself fighting well known criminals and masterminds with fitting voice actors and design. Whilst playing the normal story mode you unlock certain challenges where you either fight criminals or need to master some stealthy tasks. Story Mode: The main part of the game takes place in - surprise surprise - Arkham Asylum. I cannot say too much about the story itself without spoilering anything, but except for a relatively weak and unsatisfying ending it can be -with its fantastic atmosphere- labeled as a quite classic one; well known in the Batman universe. You would probably be able to finish the story itself in a few hours but luckily there are 240 riddles placed all over the fully explorable map which are all in all relatively easy to solve once you get used to them with some exceptions. Solving riddles rewards you with some XP, new challenges, sometimes a biography entry in your database or an interview with well known characters of the Batman Universe. Combat System:Before I go into further details, I quickly want to explain the usage of experience points (which you naturally get when fighting enemies and solving riddles). There are around 20 updates for your Batman character categorised into improvements for you armour, your combat/stealth skills and additional techniques and items to use. It is worth noting that there are no skill trees you have to choose from, in the end you will most likely have every upgrade. The combat system itself is fairly simple. You usually deal with several enemies at once (even though only one attacks after the other whilst the rest waits) using a simple block and hit method at the beginning and then, as the game proceeds, more complicated combos and techniques will be 'unlocked' and learnt as more special enemies are entering the game. Even at the hardest difficulty the fights usually don't pose a big threat if you aren't aiming for perfection. However, the combat system being fairly easy does not change the satisfaction and the enjoyment that come with winning and participating in a fight due to the constant usage of nicely looking animations (especially for 2009) and the creation of a smooth flow during a fight.Challenge Mode:Once you have finished with the story mode and everything that it contains many turn to the Challenge Mode that has then been unlocked. It consists of several combat and stealth challenges with the latter one always containing 3 objectives that you have to fulfill. Acing every single one of them will surely take up some time and will probably lead to some frustration since trying to perfectly complete a combat task really shows all the possibilites that lie within this combat system which you usually don't necessarily need to master or explore in the story mode. So, overall if you are looking for a Batman game with a nice atmosphere, a decent story and an interesting background information on the Batman universe to explore, and a combat system that isn't too hard but still fun I'd recommend buying this game out of the whole series despite its age. If you aim to enjoy every aspect of the game I'd probably say that this game has an average playtime of 18 hours.Thank you for your attention, one person who has read this far.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2013
												Okay, so when was the last time you picked up a game nowadays and there wasn't shooter mechanics involved? Batman: Arkham Asylum just so happens to be proof that the action-adventure genre can still survive and do extraordinarily well in terms of profit amidst a plethora of other games that do the same old thing all over again. A lot of the gameplay reminds myself of older adventure games, and mixes it up with brawler action stuff which is good, but those with less than an average competence with button-press timing may find that the flow of combat is often interrupted and can at times be infuriating. The narrative is pretty much standard Batman with the twist that you face multiple of his most notorious villains, with Joker being a sort of pseudo-kingpin with a master plan. Add on the voice talent of Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill reprising  their roles as Batman and Joker respectively, and you definitely feel like this is an authentic Batman experience. All in all, if you haven't played Arkham Asylum by now, you really REALLY should, as it is (and was) a refreshing change of pace to the usual product. P.S. Kudos to whomever was in charge of putting those collectibles in the right places. Solving a puzzle to get the shiny thing is way more rewarding than just running around everywhere to find a feather perched at the top of a random building.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
												Just got this today along with Arkham City. $5 bucks each!! Wow... Almost 7 years old and this game feels as great as it did the first time I played it back in the Peasant Station 3's golden days. It's a game that never bores you from beginning to end and it encourages you to find every unlockable.What to say about Arkham Asylum? This game revolutionized the way we play games. It brought so many innovations to a time when games were starting to feel so repetitive, uninspired, buggy and generic. The surprising thing was that this game was based on a DC superhero world; something that was considered a stigma in the gaming world. Almost no superhero game has ever been good, or interesting enough to engage people who are not into comics. Yet Batman Arkham series threw this misconception away and brought a magnificent piece of gaming software at the same time.So many games have tried to copy the Free-Flow system, but non have succeeded. This combat system is the 'pièce de résistance' of the Arkham series and will have you craving for fights. And I love how the game does so well at not overdoing it. It gives you just enough fights throughout the game so it is always exciting, without falling into repetitiveness. And still,  at the end, it rewards you with a mode were you can beat as many henchmen as you like.Appart fromt he wonderful combat system that it's such a treat to watch and perform, the game also engages you in stealth as well as playing the detective. It manages to wrap all this into an immersive story with a very dark style never seen before in a Batman game. It even manages to sneak some horror elements, which does fantasticaly well! Definitely a surprise for the first-timer.I really can't find any negatives on this game. It plays brilliant, looks wonderful for being a 7 year-old game, amazing soundtrack and sound effects. great voice acting (we've got the official Joker's voice: Mark Hamill), gorgeous and badass character designs, engaging story even for the non comic fan, and the list goes on.This game is a classic on its own right and it will go into history as one of the greatest and most influential games of the past gen.Graphics: 8/10 It's a 7 year old game but it still looks fenomenal. The PC version benefits from sharper textures, light effects and 60fps. It almost does not look as old as it really is.Sound: 7/10 The soundtrack alone is epic! But it suffers from volume spikes. Cutscenes are too loud. Something that many games suffer from.Controls: 9/10 You got to play this with a controller. Once you do, you find yourself with one of the most responsive, smooth and intuitive controllers there is. Developers really put an effort in them.Gameplay: 9/10 This game is in a league of its own. Back when it came out, there was nothing like it. Brilliant fighting mechanics! Great ballance between stealth, beat'em up, exploration and even horror, making this game feel interesting from beginning to end.Story: 8/10 Simple, but engaging. That darker, more mature Batman game no one really asked for, but oh boy, thank the gods we got!

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												Let’s just start with the obvious: one does not have to be a comic fan to enjoy this game. And in that extremely impossible case that you somehow missed all the movies (even Nolan’s ones) here’s a quick recap. Bruce Wayne whose parents were tragically murdered is insanely rich, dresses in a suit that resembles a bat and beats the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of all kinds of bad guys while using cool gadgets. In a devilishly insane logic of superhero comic villains caught by our hero all end up in a special kind of jail which happens to be also a madhouse. It’s Arkham Asylum. Obviously, it turns out badly; asylum is overrun by criminals, and it’s up to Batman to stop them. That’s it without spoiling too many details. After all the game is set in a separate universe which tends to follow the usual canon, but also steps out of the bounds here and there. And this is a big deal for those, who can distinguish Earth-2 from say Earth-15.The plot revolving around events of one night and set in one place results in a rather tense game. First in the series Arkham Asylum may lack the extent, size and polish of its successors, but it has that unique feeling of being trapped inside an insane maze. These corridors, buildings, underground and open air sections are so tightly stitched together, that there’s practically no room to make a breathe, unless developers intended to let you. This is non-stop rollercoaster ride accelerating to the limit and beyond it, until you finally fall in the abyss of total madness, lose all sense of time and spend sleepless night with the game. Rocksteady Studios not just break the fourth wall with this game, they destroy it with a power of nuclear explosion. Carefully crafted props, marvelously fluid animations, diverse gameplay varying from famous “flowing” combat to stealth, puzzle solving, detective mode and beyond that. And ultimately the story. I won’t spoil you the exact scenes happening in the middle of the game, but they are simply outstanding in their ability to convey a feeling of lunacy overcoming Batman in this nuthouse.Gotham Knight’s labyrinth path expectedly twists and bends in way that returns the player to previously visited areas with a new set of toys. That differs in tone and simplicity from most of the hard-core metroidvanias. Rather than just giving tools to overcome some obstacles game gently pushes you in the right way making sure you won’t struggle with trying to figure out what to do next. It’s not a game about exploring, though there are some clever hidden optional areas containing secrets and unobvious puzzles; but that’s for those who just can’t get enough of Arkham Asylum. When it comes to the main progression route the game won’t let off your hand. And while in general that would be a major flaw in my eyes, this time it isn’t. One can say that it’s just a matter of perspective, matter of taste; that you can’t just drop off the player in the middle of nowhere nowadays and hope, that’s he’s clever and curious enough to figure his way from the starting point towards the ending. That may be true… it actually is true, I must say, but that’s beside the point. That’s the matter of taste. Back again to perception of it. Here we have that idea of lunatic luna-park, the goal of filling player with madness. And you can’t just stop and let player wander without breaking that feeling and pace. You ever had that weird nightmare where you run in circles seeing same place again and again not being able to comprehend how many times you did it, not being able to break the cycle? Even if you haven’t, I think you can get it. And that pardons Rocksteady Studios.This was a breakthrough for the video games back in 2009, and it still is a stellar interactive experience whether you care about Batman comics or not. And the actual secret for this success turns out to be rather simple. It doesn’t matter if player is a fan of Bruce Wayne, it matters that developer is. It’s that special attention to the tiniest of details like animation of the main character’s coat or getting original voice-artists from Batman: The Animated Series (including genius Mark Hamill, playing Joker). And this passion just won’t leave anyone indifferent. At least when it’s accompanied with such brilliant execution of gameplay mechanics. Let’s just say that a fair number of games released since then simply copied Arkham Asylum freeflow combat system. And none of them came even close.
