content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												Well it´s been a while since we enjoyed a good Batman game  OST HARDLY RELATED  but this game is quite interesting...Rocksteady Studios brought us this game in 2009, thats 3 years after Urban Chaos their first game (which was quite good IMO) so i´ve been waiting the Goty Edition of this game for a while and it´s time to talk.It uses the Unreal Engine 3, built by the awarded Studio Epic Games, and it uses very well the LCPP (Lightning Calculations Per Pixel) and the HDRR (High Dynamic Range Renderer) allows you to behold all the scenery created for the game.The plot is awesome, a twisted Joker instigate an elaborate plan to gain the control of Arkham Asylum, trapping Batman inside with all the maniacs and foes that he has been imprisioning all these years. As you see it´s simple but full of shades among the different corridors of the Asylum. During the game you´ll find some of the most famous villains, and every boss fight hides messages as references for their comic-story.As for the gameplay. Actually its fun, it has some fails of course but you can still enjoy the combat. You can counter, attack or stun your enemy with the Freeflow combat, this system also allows Batman to move fast between your targets, chaining different combos with your gadgets in order to get over with.If you don´t want to fight all day you can use predatory tactics. The predator combat is based on the stealth, silent knockbacks, takedowns, drops or even using your gadgets (like explosives) to destroy walls or roofs in order to tilt the odds in your favor.After this you´ll be rewarded with XP, which are used to:-Improve your physicall armor.-Unlock combat moves & Gadgets.-Get Health upgrades.What about the enemies? Well, they react to your own acts as Batman. If they find inconcious allies their "fear" will raise, altering their behavior. And this means that they´ll change their patterns. They can shoot on sight, disable your predator points (gargoyles for instance), move to another part of the scenario, stay together with their allies forcing you to change your tactics.The design is hilarious and was complete in 2 years, one of the developers spent these years just designing Batmans Cape, just for make it move realistically. It´s not about the cape, it´s about the work, effort and love that this developers made to make this game shine. Even the writing, they though that more characters (like Freeze) will not fit into this game, due to discrepancies with Joker and because he doesnt have personal grudges against Batman. They though this with nearly every antagonist and they only use the ones who makes sense with their plot.Talking about characters...the developers WANTED the voices of the Animated Series made by Paul Dini. In fact Dini was helping with the writing of it. So they took Mark Hamill as Joker and Arleen Sorkin as Harley Quinn respectively...and Kevin Conroy for Batman. Nothing more to say guys 10/10 in dubbing.Finally, the game also has a lot of content even when you finish it. A lot of riddles, Joker Teeth, Riddler Trophies, Chronicles of Arkham, Patient Interviews (audios talking about the different stories of the villains) and combat Challenges.Must Buy Guys.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Bueno, ha pasado un tiempo desde que disfrutásemos de un buen Batman OST HARDLY RELATED pero este juego es algo interesante...Rocksteady Studios nos trajo este juego en 2009, es decir 3 años después de su primer juego Urban Chaos (decentillo IMO), así que estuve esperando un tiempo hasta pillar el formato GOTY y es hora de hablar.Su motor gráfico es el Unreal Engine 3, usado por el aclamado estudio Epic Games, y usa muy bien sus características como el LCPP (Lightning Calculations Per Pixel) y el HDRR (High Dynamic Range Renderer) permitiendote contemplar toda la escenografía y efectos creados para el juego.La trama es increíble, un Joker retorcido que instiga un elaborado plan para hacerse con el control del sanatorio mental de Arkham, atrapando a Batman dentro con los maníacos y todos los enemigos que ha ido encerrando estos años. Sinceramente es una trama simple, pero creada para que de juego con todos los matices que quieren ofrecerte en el juego. A lo largo del juego encontrarás a algunos de los villanos más famosos de Batman, y todos esconden historias más allá de sus peleas referentes al cómic.Hablando del modo de juego. Es muy divertido, aunque con fallos de respuesta en contadas ocasiones que ciertamente no te evitarán disfrutar del juego. Puedes contraatacar, atacar o usar stuns en un modo desarrollado por Rocksteady llamado Freeflow combat. Este sistema permite moverte a gran velocidad entre los enemigos, encadenando diferentes combos con tus artilugios para superar los encuentros.Si no quieres estar luchando todo el día, te entiendo, puedes usar otra variante del combate conocida como depredador. El modo depredador se basa en el sigilo, ataques sigilosos y derribos sin alertar a los enemigos, usar puntos altos para agarrar a tus enemigos o usar los utensilios para destruir paredes, techos, etc... para inclinar la balanza a tu favor.Después del combate, serás recompensado con puntos de experiencia, que son usados para:-Mejorar tu armadura física.-Desbloquear movimientos y utensilios.-Desbloquear mejoras de salud.Acerca de los enemigos. Reaccionan a los actos de Batman. Si encuentran a un compañero inconsciente o son alertados por un superior su nivel de "miedo" aumentará haciendo que adopten diferentes patrones y alterando su comportamiento. Podrán disparar a discreción, destruir puntos altos (como gárgolas), moverse en grupos, explorar el escenario, etc...El diseño tampoco se queda atrás, fue completado en tan solo 2 años. Para que entendáis el empeño del estudio. Uno de los programadores pasó estos 21 meses de desarrollo programando solo la capa, porque necesitaban un movimiento realista y que quedase resaltado por el UE3. Incluso el guión fue cuidado hasta el punto de no incluir más villanos de los necesarios, porque muchos de ellos desentonarían en el ámbito que se desarrolla en Arkham Asylum o por discrepancias con Joker(como Freeze). Y hablando de personajes, los desarrolladores QUISIERON las voces de la serie animada de Batman, si aquella de los 90 que tanto molaba, que hizo Paul Dini. De hecho el mismo Dini acabó ayudando en más de un aspecto del desarrollo. Así que debido a esto tomaron a Mark Hamill y Arleen Sorkin como Joker y Harley Quinn respectivamente y a Kevin Conroy como Batman. Un 10/10 en doblaje.Para finalizar, el juego tiene además una gran cantidad de contenido cuando lo superas. Acertijos, trofeos, mandíbulas de joker, diarios de audio para aprender más de los personajes, etc...Este juego es uno de los que deben jugarse.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is a 2009 action-adventure video game based on the DC Comics superhero Batman. It was developed by Rocksteady Studios and published by Eidos Interactive in conjunction with Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment for the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 video game consoles, and Microsoft Windows. It was released worldwide for consoles, beginning in North America on August 25, 2009, with a Microsoft Windows version following on September 15.Written by veteran Batman writer Paul Dini, Arkham Asylum is based on the long-running comic book mythos. In the game's main storyline, Batman's archenemy, the Joker, instigates an elaborate plot to seize control of Arkham Asylum and trap Batman inside with many of his incarcerated foes. With Joker threatening to detonate hidden bombs around fictional Gotham City, Batman is forced to fight his way through the asylum's inmates and put an end to the Joker's plans. Most of the game's leading characters are voiced by actors who have appeared in other media based on the DC Animated Universe; Kevin Conroy, Mark Hamill, and Arleen Sorkin reprised their roles as Batman, the Joker, and his sidekick Harley Quinn respectively. The game is presented from the third-person perspective with a primary focus on Batman's combat and stealth abilities, detective skills, and gadgets that can be used in combat and exploration.The game received critical acclaim—particularly for its narrative—and won several awards, including Best Action Adventure game, Best Game, and Game of the Year from different media outlets. It held the Guinness World Record for "Most Critically Acclaimed Superhero Game Ever". A Game of the Year edition was released on March 26, 2010, and an OS X version was released in November 2011. Arkham Asylum '​s success launched a series of Batman: Arkham sequels, beginning in October 2011 with Batman: Arkham City.

												A deranged man-child billionaire dresses up as a rodent and beats the mentally challenged until they stop moving- the ultimate BatMan experience!! lol :)Arkham Asylum is the first arkham game, which came out in 2009. It's a simple 3rd-person action game that introduced the best combat system for a video game that had both rhythm, fluidity, and challenge. It also introduced a stealth mechanic that made you truly feel like batman, while keeping with balance so you aren't too overpowered. The game features awesome voice work by Kevin Conroy, Mark Hamill, and Arleen Sorkin and a great story as well.Pros:-Fun campaign to play through-challenges are more fun than the regular story mode -Hollywood voice talent featuring Kevin Conroy, Mark Hamill, and Arleen Sorkin-ground-breaking combat and stealth-Fun detective work-after beating the game, you can expect to only have about 58% of available achievements  -there are 240 riddles and I've only done around 25-30%Cons:-mediocre boss fights -this game is like 30% of the size Arkham City is. -This game is hell for completions with all the 240 riddles

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												At the start of the game I couldn't help but dislike the character of Batman himself, being a tank of meaty flesh but with the grace of a ballerina. However, the longer you play, the less you notice those chiseled butt-cheeks, and the more you appreciate the game itself.The environments are beautiful and suprisingly diverse, especially for being in one asylum and do not lack in detail. Along the way, you can find many hidden dossiers and tapes of villains from the DC universe and of course those famed riddler trophies. I remember staying up all night trying to get all of those darn things. ;)Of course a major seller of the franchise is the combat, which seems to have formed a new kind of standard. At the beginning it can feel repetitive and a bit like button mashing, but ultimately the way Batman fights does depend entirely on the player. You can unlock new abilities to mess with the npcs even more.Overall I recommend this as a solid game, which will engage the player for a good deal of hours.

content:
Posted: January 18
												This game is very good. It starts off where Arkham Origin left off with Batman driving the Joker to Arkham Asylum where the Joker escapes and takes over the Asylum and frees the inmates.The gameplay is quite fun and enjoyable. The combat is your basic "spam X/Left Click until you have to press Y/RMB to counter" for the most part, but it does eventually introduce enemies that have certain weaknesses you can exploit or certain strengths you have to avoid, for example, you mightn't be able to attack certain enemies from the front. The base stealth mechanics are good, but the advanced mechanics are quite interesting. For example, one of the missions has you rescuing Asylum staff, but if you are detected the staff die. But, if you take out any of the inmates, the suicide collars they are wearing go off, which also causes the staff to die. The game runs very well for the most part, but whenever it loads and render in new sections in an area it has noticeable frame drops. This could possibly be fixed by installing onto an SSD, but I think the problem lies within the rendering method employed by the engine. My 1060/6600K rig can hold a locked 60FPS or a locked 144FPS for the entire duration excluding the aforementioned framedrops, though, even at 2560x1440.  See here for how to change your max framerate and other video options that aren't in the options menu [pcgamingwiki.com] . Scroll down even further to find out how to install the ex-PS3 exclusive DLC among other fixes. The levels load quite quickly, even on a 7200RPM HDD. The game has controller support for the XBox 360 controller and autodetects it when it is plugged in. I used DS4Windows to use my PS4 controller for my playthrough of it, though I used mouse and keyboard for a while and found the default binds good and the fact you could rebind each key even better.There are a few puzzles you have to solve, but nothing too major or difficult. You just keep looking from different angles and eventually there'll be a path or solution staring you in the face.The characters are a little dull and boring and don't have any real depth to them, except maybe the Joker. You can  feel  the crazy.Overall, I can highly recommend this game as a must play for anyone who likes the Batman universe or anyone who likes 3rd person combat/stealth games.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
													Arkham Asylum is a solid game with a rich, atmospheric world. The visuals are good, the gameplay is decent, the environments are packed with detail, and the story is interesting.	The characters are portrayed very well. Even though I tend to have a serious, do-good demeanor (does that remind anyone of a particular Dark Knight?), the Joker's off-the-wall humor cracked me up on several occasions. Every main character's performance is on point, but Mark Hamill's Joker is absolutely superb.	Stability-wise, Arkham Asylum seems very well-tested and bugfixed. I've yet to encounter problems more serious than some clipping and physics weirdness, and my perusals around the internet revealed nothing diabolically game-breaking. It seems to be a wonderfully solid game in terms of technical stability, which is infuriatingly uncommon in games these days.ISSUES	Some of these "issues" are subjective, since I had to dig deep to find anything particularly bad about this game. It goes without saying, but that is a very good thing.	The facial animations look slightly robotic. They're not the worst I've seen by any means, but sometimes they're a little too stiff and mechanical.	Arkham Asylum is one of those games with no "after the final boss" scenario. You have to restart at the last checkpoint before the final story sequence, and you can never actually reach a permanent "finished" state. This is a game with many secrets and collectibles; if you want to find them all and haven't by the end of the game, you have to ignore the final boss and leave the game in a state of limbo while you try to get the rest of the collectibles.	That said, when you've beaten the game once, the final boss is no longer a primary objective when you reload the save. As a result, while you can never reach a finished "after-the-end" gameplay state, at least it indirectly acknowledges that the game has been finished before.	There are hidden scenes/objects that you have to visually scan to prove you've found them, as part of a secrets/collectibles sidequest. Some of these scenes require a ridiculous amount of zoom and a pixel-perfect perspective to actually register. Unless the camera is in the perfect position, the game will complain about bad alignment or zoom, even though it's obvious that you've figured out the puzzle. Fortunately, this isn't a huge problem; only a minor occasional annoyance.	Arkham Asylum has a slight case of consolitis. Most of the options can only be changed with a launcher, buttons have multi-layered functions that can easily compromise your control (I'm looking at you, Jump/Run/Activate/Dodge button), the UI is a little messy and oversized, and there are a few other symptoms. However, given its third-person viewpoint and relatively small focus on intuitive camera movement, I actually recommend Arkham Asylum to be played with a controller. It can't beat the intuition of mouse control in some situations, but a controller works very well most of the time.SUMMARY	Overall, Arkham Asylum is a very nicely made game. I give it an 8/10.	Strengths: Stability, gameplay, environments, graphics, sound	Weaknesses: Replay value (almost everything is scripted), consolitis

												Batman Arkham Asylum is no doubt one of the best comic book game adaptations of all time. The game’s style and presentation is completely off the chain, the scene where you enter Arkham Asylum left me stunned for several minutes, and the environment is just flat out amazing. However, Arkham Asylum did not get GOTY due to just its graphics. Its combat system is expansive thanks to the upgrade system and its combat mode keeps the game fresh; some mission requires you to stealthily take out enemies while others drops you in the middle of the action. There are tons of contents and challenges to be had, do yourself a favor and buy this game.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												At the start of the game I couldn't help but dislike the character of Batman himself, being a tank of meaty flesh but with the grace of a ballerina. However, the longer you play, the less you notice those chiseled butt-cheeks, and the more you appreciate the game itself.The environments are beautiful and suprisingly diverse, especially for being in one asylum and do not lack in detail. Along the way, you can find many hidden dossiers and tapes of villains from the DC universe and of course those famed riddler trophies. I remember staying up all night trying to get all of those darn things. ;)Of course a major seller of the franchise is the combat, which seems to have formed a new kind of standard. At the beginning it can feel repetitive and a bit like button mashing, but ultimately the way Batman fights does depend entirely on the player. You can unlock new abilities to mess with the npcs even more.Overall I recommend this as a solid game, which will engage the player for a good deal of hours.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
Product received for free
												I got this game mainly because well, IT'S BATMAN! (No more need to be said there)If you like stealth games and action adventure games you will find this game quite enjoyable.I haven't completed this game or started any other game in the arkham series, but as far as I've gotten I've enjoyed it. I really like the stealth missions, once you take one person out the rest just start squealing and I fricken love it. I also like when you die the person who killed (or the man behind your death) comes and mocks you... Yes, I enjoyed that part.My favourite parts of the story is when Scarecrow gives you drugs and you start tripping. Just the whole platforming minigame on a nightmare where scarecrow torments you just brings me happieness (Don't judge me)My one main complaint is the personality and character being batman himself, he's a wimp! Not in the way that he's scared of anything, no no, he's a complete bad@$$, just he doesn't actaully kill anyone. Now I'm not some 6 year old kid complaining about how it's "Not Violent Enough" no way, in fact to see a game with alot of time and effort put into to it that isn't a VIOLENT MURDER SIMULATOR WHERE THE WATER IS MADE OF BLOOD AND EVERYTHING YOU SEE SHALL DIE!!! kinda game is nice every once in a while, but back to my batman point, he doesn't kill anyone, just knocks them unconscious, and again, I'M NOT COMPLAINING THAT IT'S NOT VIOLENT ENOUGH, but the fact that everyone he knocks unconscious would kill batman with little to no regret is either really nice on batman's part or really stupid. Now for the actaul human beings, FINE, they were human and batman is all about the murder-lifestyle. But when those mindless monster enimies that would tear batman limb for limb carelessly, come charging at batman and he only knocks them unconscious, that's dumb, that's really dumb.But all and all, even though the motives of batman's ways with enimies isn't very smart, it's a great game, and remember, this is coming from someone who hasn't finished the game or played any other arkham game.8.75/10, would recommened

content:
Posted: January 18
												This game is very good. It starts off where Arkham Origin left off with Batman driving the Joker to Arkham Asylum where the Joker escapes and takes over the Asylum and frees the inmates.The gameplay is quite fun and enjoyable. The combat is your basic "spam X/Left Click until you have to press Y/RMB to counter" for the most part, but it does eventually introduce enemies that have certain weaknesses you can exploit or certain strengths you have to avoid, for example, you mightn't be able to attack certain enemies from the front. The base stealth mechanics are good, but the advanced mechanics are quite interesting. For example, one of the missions has you rescuing Asylum staff, but if you are detected the staff die. But, if you take out any of the inmates, the suicide collars they are wearing go off, which also causes the staff to die. The game runs very well for the most part, but whenever it loads and render in new sections in an area it has noticeable frame drops. This could possibly be fixed by installing onto an SSD, but I think the problem lies within the rendering method employed by the engine. My 1060/6600K rig can hold a locked 60FPS or a locked 144FPS for the entire duration excluding the aforementioned framedrops, though, even at 2560x1440.  See here for how to change your max framerate and other video options that aren't in the options menu [pcgamingwiki.com] . Scroll down even further to find out how to install the ex-PS3 exclusive DLC among other fixes. The levels load quite quickly, even on a 7200RPM HDD. The game has controller support for the XBox 360 controller and autodetects it when it is plugged in. I used DS4Windows to use my PS4 controller for my playthrough of it, though I used mouse and keyboard for a while and found the default binds good and the fact you could rebind each key even better.There are a few puzzles you have to solve, but nothing too major or difficult. You just keep looking from different angles and eventually there'll be a path or solution staring you in the face.The characters are a little dull and boring and don't have any real depth to them, except maybe the Joker. You can  feel  the crazy.Overall, I can highly recommend this game as a must play for anyone who likes the Batman universe or anyone who likes 3rd person combat/stealth games.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Arkham Asylum, at the time of this review, is a bit aged (released in 2010, this is 2016), yet still manages to hold it's own admist the newer generation of gameplay and graphics.Already being a fan of Batman and DC since a child, I was extremely excited to try out the first real Batman game, and I was pleasantly surprised with a game that actually is better than many other games, even given it's semi-un-original content and linear storyline based on plot information that most people, even non-DC/Batman fans already know.The game takes place in Arkham Asylum, an island in the city of Gotham, Bruce Wayne/Batman's domain.  The island goes under quarantine after Joker escapes his captivity and leads the various villains and criminals to control the island.As previously stated, the story-line, is semi-unique.  It hasn't been told exactly before (afaik), but it's fairly predictable if you're familiar with the universe.  Even so, the story is rich, characters have backstory and development and well-done voice acting and dialog in general.The combat system is the classic Assassin's Creed II combat system.  Lots of hand to hand and "press Y to counter" combat, with lots of gadgets, specials, combos, score multipliers and other abilities.  The combat is very fluid and fun, but may get a bit repetitive for some after a while.The game world is semi-open.  You have free reign over the island and it's buildings to do the missions, or go explore for collectibles (a lot of these by the way).  This is of course permitting you've reached the story points that allow access to the locations in question.The collectibles, while there are an abundance, are all useful.  Collectibles unlock backstore to the creator of the Asylum and it's history, cell-tapes from various villains, backstory on villains or important characters, concept art and challenge maps.The graphics, for a 2010 game in 2016, are still pretty damn good, so nothing to worry about here.Keyboard and mouse controls are a bit clunky/confusing and don't work to well, due to the console -> PC porting of the game, unfortunately, but with a controller, the gameplay is stellar, and goes without a hitch.Definitely worth picking up, although at $20 for a 6 year old game, personally, I'd wait for a sale, even though the game is very good and still likely worth $20 for most.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												After finally finishing the story mode and most of the DLCs (above all, Scarecrow Nightmare), I have enough experience and knowledge of the game to make a bold review.The game, from start to end, tells you it's going to be about mysteries that need to be solved, places that need to be scouted, and enemies that need to be put down. And of course, there isn't only the Joker, you will have to battle a handful of other much more powerful (but not as intelligent) villains.At first I read the description; "explore every inch of Arkham Island", and I thought to myself "I am limited only to Arkham? Well that can't be big enough, this game is going to be short!”, On the contrary, the island is extraordinarily well designed, and quite extensive. A speedrunner can finish the game within 2 hours, but anybody that has ever played an Elder Scrolls game will squeeze the gameplay hours off this game. With most of the DLCs and all the story, I invested over 10 hours in this game.The combat system is simple, yet it never gets boring. The AI is beautiful, enemies actually feel smart, and combat can be tricky. But the best part is the Assassin’s Creed-like stealth part of the game; if you want to, you can take out enemies without even engage them in combat, one by one. The remaining enemies will react accordingly; they will get nervous, scared, terrified, and more aware of your current situation.I can go on for pages explaining how well designed, well written and beautifully set this game is. But that experience can only be truly known by playing the game. It’s a no-brainer; you get it whenever it’s on sale. Don’t be fooled by the old styled menus and by how obviously this game has aged, it is still one of the best third-person, action/thriller games. And of course, as serious and concrete I want this review to be, we can’t oversee the obvious appeal this game has; it’s Batman.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												Batman Arkham Asylum: Game of the Year EditionPositives:+ The game has an interesting selection of gadgets to use. There's the batclaw, which is used to pull vent grates off walls, explosive gel to destroy structurally weak areas and the cryptographic sequencer, which allows Batman to overload security terminals and gain access to restricted areas. There's also batarangs and the line launcher, which is a portable device that fires a zip line for Batman.+ The characters are good, they all have personality except for Batman himself, who seems to be very straightforward and lacking in emotion. Joker is a particular standout and the audio tapes found around the Aslyum shed light on various inmates who are Batman's foes.+ Decent graphics.+Game length is anywhere between 20-30 hours or so, depending on how many riddles you solve and your desire to play beat em' up challenge mode.Mixed:~ The combat can be fun, but also borderline infuriating at times. Using unlockable Waynetech upgrades, Batman can perform takedown moves, throw enemies and do more critical damage. However, the combat is very unresponsive with regards to countering and in this respect Sleeping Dogs did a far better third person combat system. The fact Batman: Arkham Asylum doesn't detect your counter effectively really lets it down.~ The Riddler's hidden mini puzzles and items add a nice distraction and diversion to the main story, but at the same time they can be a bit boring if you want to complete them all, even if you discover a Riddler secrets map. It was a nice idea and it does add an element of exploration to the game, but 240 Riddler challenges is a bit excessive. My main gripe is that Batman's detective mode is required to find a lot of these trophies and it's quite annoying to be running around all over the map in black and white vision.~ The story is not bad, it's just not fantastic either. It's a bit difficult to follow, despite its simplicity. I know that sounds like a contradiction, but it's true. It just seems that at some point I lost focus on the big picture, there were a couple of confusing parts regarding the titan formula which weren't clarified. There is no in-game journal which explains the story.Negatives:- The boss fights are more or less the same, using evading dives and batarangs to stun. This pattern is repeated throughout many of the boss encounters, nothing really exciting.- Downloadable content is a joke, it doesn't add anything extra to the story or any new levels. It merely adds more beat em' up challenges..Overall Score: 7.5/10Batman: Arkham Aslyum is definitely not a 9/10 game as Metacritic would claim. But it's still good and it's still fun (plus a little irritating too lol). As the first game in the series I'd say it's well worth playing this, be sure to pick it up on sale where it regularly goes down to $5.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												I've never played super-hero games before...always was a Gordon Freeman type of guy.  I bought Batman: Arkham Asylum on a whim when it was on sale at one of the obscenely (sp?) cheap prices during the Steam Summer Sale.  I initially played it over a long week-end, and it turned out to be the best investment I've made in a long time.I mean, even if you're not a comics fan, who doesn't know the legend of Batman and his insanely comical adversaries  (Joker, Riddler, Scarecrow, Poison Ivy)?  The game ended up testing both my combat skills (acquired after long hours as Ezio in AC), and my stealth skills (acquired after long hours as Agent 47), and it ended up being one hella great week-end.Great buy, and at $5 for the GOTY edition, you can't go wrong.  Just pass on your next Big Mac, and you'll find a much more satisfying experience in this goofy offering that certainly caters to our current need for some kind of hero in the corrupt world we live in.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												What is there to say really? This is a phenomenally good game.It has an interesting story, great villains, good combat system, sweet gadgets, enticing collectibles and is actually pretty bug free from what I can tell.You play Batman in 3rd person and you're here to stop the Joker (and various other super criminals), who has taken over Arkham Asylum. On your mission you will be able to explore a relatively open world (The Arkham Isle as well as several enclosed "levels"), in which you can find well hidden trophies and solve riddles by the Riddler, which unlock more lore information and give you some points for your next level up, but nothing really essential. It's a great way to break the monotony of "run, fight, repeat". You will also get several gadgets over the course of the story, unlocking even more ways to fight your enemies and reach new locations.The combat system is just fluent, attack, block, special attacks against certain enemies. A good player would be able to not take a single point of damage in this game, since the system is pretty much flawless and any damage you take is definitely your fault. There is no cheese here. Enemies attack you in succession, but don't swarm you, so you can always block. This is how the system is designed and it works very well. Fighting better and upgrading your combat capabilities means taking out enemies faster.The upgrades usually provide some quality of life changes and some new ways to play the game or make you more resilient. It's not spectacular, but not bad either.You also have access to a "detective mode", which lets you see things you can interact with, such as destructible walls or trophies, etc. The problem is that this mode is so important to actually seeing stuff that you're basically playing the whole game with it being activated and that kinda screws the pretty nice graphics over...My biggest gripe would be with the Batclaw (upgraded), because it takes ages to take down a barrier, while tapping A like a madman, and the "challenges", which are just a set of "fight this for x rounds" or "knock out all enemies in a room as fast as possible". There are about a Dozen of them or so, and they're not that easy to get a good grade on, but I found them rather dull, so I left them out. Apart from that the game is 100% for me, which happens very rarely.A must buy imho if you're either into Batman or 3rd person fighting games with some Metroidvania aspects.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												I'm a huge fan of DC Comics, so for there to be a well recieved Batman game to me was a blessing. A small portion of his rogue's gallery is showcased in the asylum, most well known with a few lesser popular baddies making an appearance. Sometimes the game is just a button mashing punchfest but then you get to unique bosses like Scarecrow and Killer Croc and it's such a treat. I would classify this game as a "3D Beat 'Em Up". And as far as that genre goes, the pacing of fights, is really good. You're Batman so you're encouraged to use stealth, and if walk in a room and see a group of baddies that's usually all you have to take at. Now spawning of what feels like a million minions to button mash through to the point where the game isn't fun. Looking at you Deadpool.Anyways, I love this game as a Batman fan and a Gamer. If you even like Batman a little bit you should play this.

There's the batclaw, which is used to pull vent grates off walls, explosive gel to destroy structurally weak areas and the cryptographic sequencer, which allows Batman to overload security terminals and gain access to restricted areas. There's also batarangs and the line launcher, which is a portable device that fires a zip line for Batman.+ The characters are good, they all have personality except for Batman himself, who seems to be very straightforward and lacking in emotion. Joker is a particular standout and the audio tapes found around the Aslyum shed light on various inmates who are Batman's foes.+ Decent graphics.+Game length is anywhere between 20-30 hours or so, depending on how many riddles you solve and your desire to play beat em' up challenge mode.Mixed:~ The combat can be fun, but also borderline infuriating at times. Using unlockable Waynetech upgrades, Batman can perform takedown moves, throw enemies and do more critical damage. However, the combat is very unresponsive with regards to countering and in this respect Sleeping Dogs did a far better third person combat system. The fact Batman: Arkham Asylum doesn't detect your counter effectively really lets it down.~ The Riddler's hidden mini puzzles and items add a nice distraction and diversion to the main story, but at the same time they can be a bit boring if you want to complete them all, even if you discover a Riddler secrets map. It was a nice idea and it does add an element of exploration to the game, but 240 Riddler challenges is a bit excessive. My main gripe is that Batman's detective mode is required to find a lot of these trophies and it's quite annoying to be running around all over the map in black and white vision.~ The story is not bad, it's just not fantastic either. It's a bit difficult to follow, despite its simplicity. I know that sounds like a contradiction, but it's true. It just seems that at some point I lost focus on the big picture, there were a couple of confusing parts regarding the titan formula which weren't clarified. There is no in-game journal which explains the story.Negatives:- The boss fights are more or less the same, using evading dives and batarangs to stun. This pattern is repeated throughout many of the boss encounters, nothing really exciting.- Downloadable content is a joke, it doesn't add anything extra to the story or any new levels. It merely adds more beat em' up challenges..Overall Score: 7.5/10Batman: Arkham Aslyum is definitely not a 9/10 game as Metacritic would claim. But it's still good and it's still fun (plus a little irritating too lol). As the first game in the series I'd say it's well worth playing this, be sure to pick it up on sale where it regularly goes down to $5.

												The first superhero game that broke a "barrier" and an actual good and innovative superhero game, with all the elements necessary to make justice to the character, the reason this game was so good was because the game simply followed the comic books and tried to stay true to them. The enemies in the game be them bosses or not are well designed and like i said before true to the comic books, the easter eggs, the riddles, the challenges, all of that make the game even more worth it. The combat was the best aspect of the game, enemies would attack you at the same time and not wait for you to beat them one at the time, you could upgrade your character to perform better in fights and do a good variety of combos. This game also has a good stealth aspect which includes hiding, taking down enemies from gargoyles and other things. This is a worthy tribute to the Dark Knight.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
												The Arkham series was one that eluded me till recently, I had always thought that comic book to video game adaptations were often very low in terms of quality having played quite a few of them growing up...I had the chance to get Asylum when it was released but turned it down in favour of Fallout 3. While I dont regret that decision now having Played Asylum I can definately say I regret not playing this Game sooner. It's a beautiful game oozing with stylization and razor sharp in terms of writing, trust me. The story is an absolute must for this game! all the Arkham residents are wonderfully designed and while I cant say Im utterly smitten With Harley Quinns redesign (I much prefer her original outfit) Everyone else has really had the loving touch put towards them with Mark Hamills Joker being an absolute design classic. Gameplay wise it's a mixture of Stealth and Strategy  Platforming. While I loved the Platforming elements (Planning how best to take down a room and using the guards against each other) the stealthier elements often left me feeling like it could have been a bit better. Add to this that controls can be a bit of a mixed bag in particular on keyboard and mouse the Dodge functions are frankly a bit rediculous and trying to platform in a 3D sidescrolling level can at times  be a bit messy. These are however small problems that are probably more me than the Actual controls.  For an '09 game the Graphics hold up remarkably well surpassing many of the games that came out around the same time. Thats before we even get to the fact that Batman is in this game. and as Pop culture will tell us. Batman. Is amazing. Highly reccommended easily one of the Best games 2009 has to offer. Pick it up if bored; you'll not be dissapointed.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												I am a huge fan of his game. The story is good. Certainly not the greatest Batman story of all time, but nevertheless it is still very good. The gameplay is amazing and much deeper than it seems. On the surface the fighting seems shallow, but it is actually very deep and complicated. The gameplay also been copied by numerous other games, none of which were able to correctly recreate the awesomeness of this combat. The scarecrow sections are incredible in terms of gameplay and atmosphere. Those three scarecrow sections are arguably the best moments of the entire Arkham series. I can't personally think of a better moment. The stealth is also awesome and the A.I of the goons is quite good. They really make you feel like The Batman.My only problem with this game is the boss fights. Specifically the fact that almost all of them are Titan battles,  especially the final battle with the Joker. . The exceptions to this rule are the aforementioned scarecrow sections and  the battle with Poison Ivy . Even then, these battles are few and far between and don't really come around enough to make them a big problem.The lore is also incredible. It isn't a chore to 100% this game because of what you earn from getting riddler trophies and answering riddles correctly. There is no completion bonus, but this game is a perfect example of the journey being better more important than the destination. This game is absolutely fantastic. One of my favourite games of all time and definitely one the best Superhero games of all time.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												I've never played super-hero games before...always was a Gordon Freeman type of guy.  I bought Batman: Arkham Asylum on a whim when it was on sale at one of the obscenely (sp?) cheap prices during the Steam Summer Sale.  I initially played it over a long week-end, and it turned out to be the best investment I've made in a long time.I mean, even if you're not a comics fan, who doesn't know the legend of Batman and his insanely comical adversaries  (Joker, Riddler, Scarecrow, Poison Ivy)?  The game ended up testing both my combat skills (acquired after long hours as Ezio in AC), and my stealth skills (acquired after long hours as Agent 47), and it ended up being one hella great week-end.Great buy, and at $5 for the GOTY edition, you can't go wrong.  Just pass on your next Big Mac, and you'll find a much more satisfying experience in this goofy offering that certainly caters to our current need for some kind of hero in the corrupt world we live in.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Im not normally a fan of Superhero games in general.  But "Batman: Arkham Asylum" was really fun.  As long as you keep an open mind, and expect more of a comic book experiance you will have a lot of fun playing this game.dont expect the Christian Bale batman here, this is more like how batman is supossed to be, nearly super-human.  Extremly strong, fast, and intelligent with an unlimited supply of tech gadgets.From grapnel, to batarang, explosive gel and more you will use all your gadgets to foil the jokers plans here.  Some very tough but rewarding fights will be had as well.  this game really lets you step inside the shoes of the iconic batman character.Music and sound effects are excellent, but you would expect that with a big budget game.this game is a definate must try for anyone who is a fan of Superhero games, or fighting games in general.The only drawback ive found is that the main game itself (not the sidegames and challenge modes) is pretty short, clocking in at just over 10 hours of gameplay... and this game wont offer much in the way of replayabilityid give it a solid 8.5 / 10

												I am going to make a confession, I wasn't really that interested in Batman before I got this game. However, I gave this game a shot and I have to say, I am happy I did. You play as Batman, (obviously) and he is sending Joker to Arkham Asylum, but it looks like he let Batman send him there a little too easy. It turns out that this was part of Joker's secret plan and he takes control of the Asylum killing many people in it. There is an amazing combat system in the game, easy to learn and get used to. There is also wonderful stealth sections, those were prehaps my favourite parts of the game. I haven't mentioned everything about the game, like the amazing Scarecrow sections, that is for you to see. Batman Arkham Asylum should take you about 10-15 hours on your first try, and I think it is worth the 20 dollars.

												Batman and Robin are camping in the desert, set up their tent and are asleep. Some hours later, Batman wakes his faithful friend. "Robin, look up at the sky and tell me what you see."Robin replies, " I see millions of stars.""What does that tell you?" asks Batman.Robin ponders for a minute."Astronomically speaking, it tells me that there are millions of galaxies and potentially billions of planets.Astrologically, it tells me that Saturn is in Leo.Chronologically, it appears to be approximately a quarter past three.Theologically, it's evident the Lord is all-powerful and we are small and insignificant.Meteorologically, it seems we will have a beautiful day tomorrow.What does it tell you, Batman?"Batman is silent for a moment, then speaks:" Robin, you idiot, someone has stolen our tent."

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Honestly, I expected better. This is yet another console port (are there native PC games anymore?!), with the usual problems of console ports. Like what? You name it: mediocre controls, especially during fights (there is something with timing and combat flow and all that, it basically means that you have to press the exact button at the right moment the game expects you to do so; more or less equivalent to the ideas behind QTEs); ultra-linear plot (go there, do that, rinse, repeat), repetitive gameplay (you will encounter two main types of ennemies: melee fighters, and ranged fighers. And quite rarely, a stronger melee figher type) with the same strategies all along the way, and so on.Of course there are worse games out there; but we're not searching for the worst game, are we? So to summarize, this game has an experience which goes from amusing to boring, with an average much closer to boring; can cause an impressive amount of frustration at times (especially when fighting, something which is not really interesting to begin with, given the small amount of strategy you can use; it's more of a standardized suite of buttons to press, as an answer to a visual stimuli the game shows you); it has an okay plot, and is worth playing once, provided that you stop playing as soon as you feel the frustration growing in you; and get back to it later. Not a game I would recommend to people prone to easy anger. In any case, the replay value is close to null, and to be honest (I'm writing the review as I do a second play-through, for achievements - I waited two years or so, since I did swear to myself that I would never touch it again, after the first one), I would advise anyone to avoid it at all costs. Too bad, a Batman game would have the potential to be so much better... =/Bottom line: More or less okay game, if possible get it on a sale, and play it once, with small sessions preferably.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												Most superhero games aren’t very good. But Arkham Asylum changed that. It made people say, ‘Finally! A superhero game that doesn’t suck!’ Batman Arkham Asylum is about Batman (duh) getting trapped in Arkham Asylum (also duh). Unfortunately he is trapped with some of the most dangerous criminals in all of Gotham, including the Joker, Killer Croc, Poison Ivy and Scarecrow.The game controls aren’t too hard to figure out. You use the mouse to look around and to attack and block. Space to run, and ctrl to crouch. Every time you knock down a thug you get experience points. Get enough of them and you can level up. Levelling up allows you to pick an upgrade, such as armour improvements and new abilities. Obviously you can’t have a Batman game without gadgets, so throughout the game you will unlock many, including batarangs, grapple gun, and oh, did I mention explosives?The Boss fights/Areas are quite varied, from overcoming Scarecrows fear gas, to sneaking through the sewers trying not to be eaten by Killer Croc. Although one problem I had with the game was the fact that Bane wasn’t smart. Instead all he does is through things at you and ram you. But that’s pretty much my only problem with the game.If this game was a spoon, it would a good spoon.I’m giving this game spoon/10

content:
Posted: November 8, 2013
												In this game you're Batmen, The Knight of Darkness. The title of the hero is very misleading, as he isn't even a knight. He doesn't have a sword, he doesn't ride a horse, he never goes to the jousting area, he doesn't fight for the hand of the pure maiden. Instead he runs through some kind of hospital and then on the rooftops, throwing pieces of metal at everyone he doesn't like. Given how utterly ridiculous the "knight" is, I'd say there's no way this game isn't Japanese.His enemies include the Prankster (big boss but funny) and his girlfriend Hairy Quinn (complete rip-off of a name of Leauge of Legends champion. She doesn't even have a bird!), Searching-Lights Man (scary), that green enemy thing from Hulk (I love when they use the characters from the same universe) and many more. They are strong, but not as strong as Batmen. Maybe it's because I used cheat codes.I loved the initial metagame battle (most likely prepared by Prankster) of "Game for Windows". It truly made me feel like I'm playing a superior PC version. I laughed at the top of my lungs when I found out my randomly generared name was PrecutRainbow20. Like, they had to cut a twenty pieces of rainbow to make the game work! Prankster truly is the master of pranks.Overall I give this game this game a score of  3.211336+e of 3.7

Short ReviewArkham Asylum is a great portrayal of Batman and the lore surrounding him and those related to the asylum. Although the game is a bit linear without an open world (Gotham - as seen in Arkham City/Knight), it is still a great game and requirement in order to enjoy the Arkham series. The game mechanics is a bit outdated comparatively to teh other entries in the series but it still plays rather well, including the famous combat style. ScoreMasterpiece- 10/10

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												This game is pretty cool. It's too arcady for me but I like it sometimes. 90% of the game seems to be collectibles and solving mysteries and stuff and the rest of the 10% is fighting bad guys.Boss fights are pretty much what you'd expect in a fighting game, the big guy charges you and you gotta jump to the side to make him smack into the wall and incapacitate himself.It's not that impressive, really. It's fun at times though. Such as when you look at someone with the batvision and you can see their heartrate and see if they're nervous or calm. The gadgets are pretty cool aswell. It doesn't really feel like you're playing Batman though which kinda ruins it for me. It's too cartoony. Some people love that but I don't. This game is the old Batman where the Joker isn't a "normal" guy but instead someone who fell into toxic waste.If you like running around trying to find three thousand collectibles while fighting generic bad guys with kinky leather collars on as Batman then this game is for you.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												If someone were to ask me what was my favorite Superhero game. Arkham Asylum would pop into my head first. It's as close to being Batman(aside from it's sequels) as it gets.Game starts out with Batman having captured the Joker yet again and brought him back to the asylum. Shortly after bringing him in, Joker escapes custody and it comes apparent that he had planned this all along and Harley Quinn had taken control of the Arkham's security systems. So Batman sets out on the hunt for the Joker to stop him from whatever he is planning.The visuals are stunning and still hold up and they convey Gotham's dark Gothic scenery perfectly. The audio work is equally as good with solid voice acting from everyone especially Mark Hamill's Joker. The combat in the game utilizes a fluid simple to use but difficult to master system allowing you make to make combos from one enemy to the next. Batman also carries a wide variety of tools and gadget to allowing him to fight crime such as his trademark batarang for knocking out enemies and his grappling hook for reaching ledges from a distance as well pulling on enemies or opening new ways to go and  in his cowl he has system that allows him to detect pretty much everything around, like evidence, location of enemies and more. He acquires more as you play through the game.Aside from the main objective there are also a ton of extra things to uncover like riddles and prizes that the Riddler has hidden all over Arkham Island. There are also tapes with treatment sessions with some of Batman's greatest adversaries and markings left by a mysterious unknown called the Spirit of Arkham.Main storyline is great and involves many of Batman's greatest enemies and will leave you satisfied at the end when you beat it and when you do you'll have a ton of riddles and secrets to keep you busy for awhile longer.Gets my thumbs up!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2012
												Fantastic game. I thought that the amazing reviews were wrong or askew or something, but this really truly is an amazing game. The gameplay mechanics and controls are really fluid and easy to get used to, you really feel like you're controlling Batman. The music is almost as good as the actual Hans Zimmer Batman soundtrack. The story is great and makes me actually care about the characters. It feels like a ramped up arcade game or something, it's just done sooo well. The only downside to it is that it's hard as♥♥♥♥♥♥and extremely frustrating, especially towards the end. The two boss battles before the final one are mindblowingly difficult, especially with the controls you're given. However, the final battle is nothing much, so it's a bit underwhelming. All I can say is that if this game is this good, and everyone is saying that Arkham City is better, then I can't wait to try that out. 10/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2013
												I'm not much of a Batman fan, but even so, this game is just amazing.It looks great, the fighting feels superb and is absolutely fluid (although it may look a bit weird at times) and the voice actors are top notch, although Mark Hamill (ya know, Luke Skywalker) as Joker easily steals the show.Discover Arkham Asylum, one of the most (in)famous places in Gotham City as one of the best known comic heroes of all times.Use a wide variety of gadgets, fight lots of bad guys, normal and super and discover the dark secrets of Arkham.There's also a lot to find! Riddler trophies are hidden everywhere, unlocking character bios, artwork and infos. And while I liked the amount of detail in these things, I'm not a big fan of running around the level over and over again to catch 'em all, but if you're into that, you'll have a great time ;)Fantastic game, all things considered!

content:

												Batman: Arkham Asylum is a different take on Super Hero games.  While you are a super hero, you are a man with gadgets...blah blah blah, you know who Batman is.This game is incredible because the flow of combat is amazingly fluid and works extremely well.  There is no one way to attack a group of enemies, and the story really wraps you in to this world of Arkham.Mark Hamill and Kevin Conroy do the voices of the Joker and the Batman, so you already get that great feeling listening to the Joker laughing at the Batman that you are a kid again.This game is really fun, and i have beaten it twice a year since it has been released.5 out of 5

content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
Will update as I progress :)What I Like:- Hand-to-Hand Combat: "Easy to learn/hard to master combat system"- Beautifully designed game- Tutorials: Are very clear and interactive and the upgrdes are progressive- Replayability: Plenty of bonuses and riddles to find, some of which require items that will be unlocked later in the game- Steamworks Integration: Achievements, Trading Crads, etc- Side Missions: Stealth, and speed runs- The Joker: :) The character is designed and voiced nicely - Face your fears : Scarecrow missions- Upgrade weapons and skills as you progressNeutral:....Wish it had:- Custom Waypoints The option to add custom waypoints on the map would have been nice- GPS: An optional added visual GPS would assist some users- Fights: Some fights can be tedious and frustrating, especially with armed thugs thugs with electrical bats, and a combinantion of Titans and thugs - May cause you to Rage Quit :( Take a break try again :)- Drag Bodies: Batman is unable to drag bodies after a stealth takedown (contrast that with Far Cry 3)- More Driving Missions: The ability to drive around in the batmobile and bike (perhaps as a side mission), would enhance the gameplay options- Swimming: Batman is unable to swim :(My NotesJust some notes that I can come back to when I play later :)- Strike: LMB- Stun: MMB- Counter: RMB- Batarang: Q- Batclaw: C- Multiple Batarangs: 6- Use Objects: RMB then LMB- Detonate: RMB then MMB- Titans: Batrang when they are charging at you- Electro Melee: Evade and jump behind them, then attack - Armed: Gargoyles, inverted, silent, corner, etc

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Amazing. Do recommend. One of my favourite games for many reasons:Story -  a great story is present in the first installment of the Arkham games. You roam Arkham Asylum, the mental institute situated on an island not too far from Gotham City. Baddies keep trying to ruin your night and as Batman you need to stop them.Gameplay - The combat and flow of the game is smooth and amazing. You actually feel like Batman while pulling off amazing combos and using all your gadgets that are at your disposal.Graphics - Such a turn on. The graphics hold up well. The whole atmosphere is almost perfect for the setting.Length - I found the length to be great as well. Not too long not too short. You won't get bored because you keep unlocking new gadgets as the story develops.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												If someone were to ask me what was my favorite Superhero game. Arkham Asylum would pop into my head first. It's as close to being Batman(aside from it's sequels) as it gets.Game starts out with Batman having captured the Joker yet again and brought him back to the asylum. Shortly after bringing him in, Joker escapes custody and it comes apparent that he had planned this all along and Harley Quinn had taken control of the Arkham's security systems. So Batman sets out on the hunt for the Joker to stop him from whatever he is planning.The visuals are stunning and still hold up and they convey Gotham's dark Gothic scenery perfectly. The audio work is equally as good with solid voice acting from everyone especially Mark Hamill's Joker. The combat in the game utilizes a fluid simple to use but difficult to master system allowing you make to make combos from one enemy to the next. Batman also carries a wide variety of tools and gadget to allowing him to fight crime such as his trademark batarang for knocking out enemies and his grappling hook for reaching ledges from a distance as well pulling on enemies or opening new ways to go and  in his cowl he has system that allows him to detect pretty much everything around, like evidence, location of enemies and more. He acquires more as you play through the game.Aside from the main objective there are also a ton of extra things to uncover like riddles and prizes that the Riddler has hidden all over Arkham Island. There are also tapes with treatment sessions with some of Batman's greatest adversaries and markings left by a mysterious unknown called the Spirit of Arkham.Main storyline is great and involves many of Batman's greatest enemies and will leave you satisfied at the end when you beat it and when you do you'll have a ton of riddles and secrets to keep you busy for awhile longer.Gets my thumbs up!

content:
Posted: October 30, 2011
												I'm not a fan of super heros, for the most part. They're generally extremes of either corny and childish, or trying too hard to be mature and edgy.That being said, as far as games go, this was was actually fresh, varied, and consistantly fun throughout its entirity. I didn't have to like the whole comic book ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t to appreciate it, which is a plus. Variety of platforming, stealth, buttonmash fighting, detectivising, and movement puzzles.I don't really have much to say aside from that though, I mean the storyline was pretty bland, the character development was virtually non existant (largely in part to the characters already having-been developed on paper), and it's always a little weird that batman is cool with throwing sharp metal♥♥♥♥♥♥at peoples' faces, yet doesn't just carry a gun or tazer, and make it simple.All in all, worth checking out, not a waste of money. Nothing amazing, but plenty of fun while it lasted. I mean, ♥♥♥♥, at least it's not another call of duty.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2012
												I AM THE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ BATMAN.So the first time I played this game, I didn't like it very much, and I didn't keep playing it. A few months later, I realised I clearly had a slowness of the brain and set about fixing this. Who doesn't want to be Batman? No one, that's who. If anything, this game should appeal to the raging man-beasts who use Steam as it shows you a number of ways to sneak up on unsuspecting victims. Girl giving you a hard chase in the club? She won't be when you hang upside down from a nearby decorative cornerpiece in the gothic-themed club you're in and swing her through the air. Getting bullied IRL by your local thugs? E.Z. Once you dress up as a bat and run at them growling you're not going to have ANY problems anymore.THIS GAME WILL CHANGE YOUR LIFE.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2013
												Ever want to be a super hero, wear awesome gothic, skintight outfits, and beat up bad guys with state of the art weapons? With this game you can!Batman has just recaptured The Joker and is taking him back to Arkham Asylum. Once there however, the Joker turns the tables on his nemesis and, with the help of Harley Quinn, takes over the asylum. It's up to you, as the Batman himself to chase down the Joker and defeat him once and for all! Or at least until the next time he escapes! This game is packed with so much to do, it'll take you days to finish everything. From hidden items to challenges to DLC, this game will keep you entertained and occupied for quite awhile. Definitely worth a purchase.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2012
												I AM THE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ BATMAN.So the first time I played this game, I didn't like it very much, and I didn't keep playing it. A few months later, I realised I clearly had a slowness of the brain and set about fixing this. Who doesn't want to be Batman? No one, that's who. If anything, this game should appeal to the raging man-beasts who use Steam as it shows you a number of ways to sneak up on unsuspecting victims. Girl giving you a hard chase in the club? She won't be when you hang upside down from a nearby decorative cornerpiece in the gothic-themed club you're in and swing her through the air. Getting bullied IRL by your local thugs? E.Z. Once you dress up as a bat and run at them growling you're not going to have ANY problems anymore.THIS GAME WILL CHANGE YOUR LIFE.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												I am not going to make any comparisons to Arkham City and just discuss this as a standalone game.  The game is fun although relatively easy.  The fight mechanics provides you with a fun stealth and combat system that allows you to approach situations involving enemies  in your own way.  I liked the story in that it incorporated many Batman villains and I really liked what they did with Scarecrow.  However the part with Killer Croc is stupid and I can't even describe how dumb the ending with the Joker is.  Also, there was never any reason to turn off your "detective vision" that revealed hidden paths and secrets, so unless if you really want to admire the art and environments, you can play the entire game with detective vision turned on.  It's a fun, although flawed, game that does a decent job at breathing life into the Batman comics.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												If someone were to ask me what was my favorite Superhero game. Arkham Asylum would pop into my head first. It's as close to being Batman(aside from it's sequels) as it gets.Game starts out with Batman having captured the Joker yet again and brought him back to the asylum. Shortly after bringing him in, Joker escapes custody and it comes apparent that he had planned this all along and Harley Quinn had taken control of the Arkham's security systems. So Batman sets out on the hunt for the Joker to stop him from whatever he is planning.The visuals are stunning and still hold up and they convey Gotham's dark Gothic scenery perfectly. The audio work is equally as good with solid voice acting from everyone especially Mark Hamill's Joker. The combat in the game utilizes a fluid simple to use but difficult to master system allowing you make to make combos from one enemy to the next. Batman also carries a wide variety of tools and gadget to allowing him to fight crime such as his trademark batarang for knocking out enemies and his grappling hook for reaching ledges from a distance as well pulling on enemies or opening new ways to go and  in his cowl he has system that allows him to detect pretty much everything around, like evidence, location of enemies and more. He acquires more as you play through the game.Aside from the main objective there are also a ton of extra things to uncover like riddles and prizes that the Riddler has hidden all over Arkham Island. There are also tapes with treatment sessions with some of Batman's greatest adversaries and markings left by a mysterious unknown called the Spirit of Arkham.Main storyline is great and involves many of Batman's greatest enemies and will leave you satisfied at the end when you beat it and when you do you'll have a ton of riddles and secrets to keep you busy for awhile longer.Gets my thumbs up!

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												I'M BATMANNNNNNor, rather,YOU'RE BATMANNNNNin the best possible way ever.The original, best Batman game, probably ever. It's fantastic. It plays sort of like a metroidvania, in the sense that there's plenty of places to explore, but you can't get into every locked box or clearly breakable wall just right away, no, you have to backtrack to come back to those after you've got the proper kit for it. A great, fantastic game. The combat is a slightly more watered down version of Assassin's Creed. There's two moves, essentially, hit bad dude, or 'parry' bad dude - read: redirect his clumsy attack, and use it to beat him into unconsciousness.I've played it through a couple times now. And I cannot say they could have done better with it. With voice actors from the animated series, fans of that are sure to recognize the cheery tones of Mark Hamill as the Joker (and honestly I still think he did it best).The best part of this game is by far the boss fights. They're all rather easy, you always know exactly what you have to do to beat every boss, but that's not necessarily a bad thing, I think I'd prefer to know what's going on, rather than have to guess work my way through every fight. And the segments with Scarecrow... oh wow. Oh wow. Those are the best part of it.The game also looks beautiful. I mean spectacular. Batman has never looked so good.If you are into Batman, or merely curious as I was, here you go, an excellent introduction to the character, and basically all the enemies that have ever mattered.

Posted: September 6, 2013
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is a different take on Super Hero games.  While you are a super hero, you are a man with gadgets...blah blah blah, you know who Batman is.This game is incredible because the flow of combat is amazingly fluid and works extremely well.  There is no one way to attack a group of enemies, and the story really wraps you in to this world of Arkham.Mark Hamill and Kevin Conroy do the voices of the Joker and the Batman, so you already get that great feeling listening to the Joker laughing at the Batman that you are a kid again.This game is really fun, and i have beaten it twice a year since it has been released.5 out of 5
